Chapter 10:
Story


o player will be happy to produce
characters who participate in

activities that lack a coherent narrative.
Fighting,                      role-playing, and problem-solving are
essential, but there is no flesh for the skeleton
without some idea of a plot. Adventures are not
intended to push characters into predetermined
outcomes, however. How can the GM avoid
leading players by their noses?

Avoiding this problem is simple: adventure
plot                           hooks need to fit the group’s style and
expectations. PCs need plausible motivations
and goals. Sure, making an interesting
adventure is up to the GM, but players are also
expected to follow story hooks. Otherwise, why
play a fantasy adventure game? The Game
Master does not decide each game session’s
outcome but instead allows fate and player
character decisions to determine outcomes. A
good Game Master ensures his players
experience a sense of danger without the fear of
certain doom and reserves the ability to use or
dump rules whenever necessary.

Story Arcs

Stories generally follow an arc that rises and falls
from                             set-up (background, character objectives),
through a build-up (actions and events as characters
try to achieve something), to success or failure and
then a wrap-up (things are more-or-less resolved).
The story unfolds through collaborative storytelling
and can be determined by participants’ actions,
whether NPC or PC.

Before any objectives have been decided, the GM
should                            suggest that each character has something in
common with the others. For instance, choose one or
more of the concepts below to give players the
reason for their common bond.

• Common allegiance to a patron, noble or
ecclesiastic.

• Compatriots in a network, established adventuring
party,                             or a heroic guild.

• The characters are all blood-related or loyal to the
same state.

• All previously lone adventurers seeking fortune
and                          fame but with a common enemy.

• Met at the tavern and now friends. Easy enough,
although rather uninspired.

Once each player has a common bond in mind,
determining                               their characters’ motivation is easier.
But for many fantasy adventures, you do not have to

259


STORY


have a more complicated motivation than “get
wealth, power, and fame.”

A goal that encourages all characters to pursue a
common quest is important, but remember, they can
get boring if things get too predictable. In addition to
the expectation of player characters being “open to
seeking adventure,” the Game Master should
maintain a range of alternatives to determine
individual character goals.

Individual goals may include clearing one’s name
for                              an uncommitted crime, an urge to explore a
mythical place, seeking revenge on a nemesis, or
thwarting a noble or cult’s evil machinations.

Story Elements

The rising action begins with a strong opening, a plot
hook of some kind. The action includes everything
you would expect; questing, combat, exploration,
role-playing, and problem-solving.

The rising action of a role-playing game session is
a                           narrative in constant flux. With the right story
hook, players will get into the action quickly.

Key information can be discovered during actual
play,                               as revealed through information gathering and
conversations with NPCs.

In any case, the Game Master is wise to limit time
length.                               The structure of fantasy adventures remains
relatively constant, despite the game form’s free
flow, unpredictable nature. The adventurous heroes
complete each milestone, eventually culminating in
a single “story-arc.”

There may be many turning points on the road to
completing the story, or it could be a simple one-
shot with a straightforward mission.

Heroes gain reputation or disrepute, improve their
abilities,                              store up their present conditions, rest, and
reflect on their experiences' impact.

Then, naturally, trouble finds them again. A final
resolution only occurs when players retire their
characters, or all heroes are tragically killed. We all
hope it is the former situation.

Story Hooks

Plot hooks are incidents designed to propel the
characters                              into the plot’s rising action. Action can
consist of a single adventure or several linked
scenarios with myriad objectives and obstacles.

Problem-solving may be any challenging dilemma, a
problematic barrier or terrain, or learning how to
thwart the machinations of a recurring and evasive
villain.

There is no reason for action without a good hook!
Listed                              below are various nutshell ideas to lure the
adventurers into the plot with the promise of
adventure, whether for glory, wealth, or personal
motivations.

Story hooks often involve an NPC, one who entrusts
heroes                            with, pleads with heroes to undertake, or
lures heroes toward various possible objectives. This
goal could be local monsters' extermination,
exploring hazardous locations, questing for
legendary artifacts, or rescuing creatures or people
of significance.

260


Common story hooks

•A mission for the player characters asked for by
their patron.

•A powerful or important NPC sends out a plea
for                          help.

•There is an ally in trouble.

•A dire threat to the realm.

•Some NPC or monster has a grudge or seeks
revenge against the PCs or a person or place
important to them.

•NPCs are hindering the progress of the PCs in
an overarching way so that they cause them to
fail in their overall career as adventurers.

•A mysterious stranger shows up with a mission
for                             the player characters should they choose to
accept.

•A mundane message in the proverbial bottle or
some mystical and mysterious message that can
lead to adventure.

•Rumors and legends with a definite tie-in to
the                              next possible event kicking off an adventure.

•An unexpected attack or ambush against the
player characters for reasons they have yet to
learn about.

•Unjustified accusations put the player
characters                            on the defense and they must clear
their names and discover then defeat the ones
who would frame them.

Locales

When building adventures, it is useful to think of a
handful of key locations and sketch out the function
of each significant encounter in each place. Use the
following lists as a brainstorming aid, rolling
percentile dice if you wish.

Common Scene Locations

•Castle

•Catacombs

•Caves/Cavern (limestone, volcanic)

•City or Town

•Community

•Donjon (keep tower)

The GM will sketch out some plot-driving
contingencies,                           which require resolving several
obstacles before triggering another event. Any story
obstacle, hook, or new prospect for adventure can
incorporate something that sets other story
functions in motion.

Sometimes, a single action is required before
another                           encounter is triggered, but it is impossible to
anticipate all future character actions, so it’s advised
that the GM play a narrative shell game with the
story elements, moving things around as needed.

You may want to create random or even inevitable
encounters                           unbound from planned scenes.

In such cases, only certain actions, including skill
or                           ability use, lead to encounters with NPCs.

Below are some common themes for creating
conflict                         and opportunities to move the plot from
session to session.

261


STORY


Battle

Combat Revenge: A friend or place dear to the hearts
of                                an ally or one of the PCs has been attacked,
murdered, or desecrated, or violated. Such an act
must be avenged. Skills useful to the task include
bluffing (infiltration), disguising oneself (to
infiltration), the abilities of an escape artist, forgery
(infiltration), gathering information, intimidation,
sense motivation.

Rising Evil: An NPC or monster has risen as an
enemy                               and must be subdued or killed. Or, a place
must be cleared of danger or opposition, down to the
last man or beast. Then it must either be occupied,
destroyed, or rebuilt. Skills useful to the task include
prowess and associated specialties, focus in combat,
and tactics.

Clear Locale: some dangerous place (a cave or classic
dungeon) must be cleared of danger or opposition,
down to the last man or beast. Then it must either be
occupied, destroyed, or rebuilt. Skills useful to the
task include anything related to combat and tactics.
Skills and abilities related to combat are always
helpful.

Escape

Escaping some locale could be a prerequisite to doing
anything (often including sleeping). The PCs have
been imprisoned, held hostage or the Locale is
doomed by some looming disaster or cataclysmic
event. But there are guardians at the gates of
freedom, enemies who would see the PCs dead or
wish the populace to remain doomed. The escape
might be required of the PCs alone, or the heroes
could be expected to help the innocent evade harm.

Useful skills: balancing (for escaping from
precarious                             places), disabling devices (for bypassing
traps), disguising oneself, the abilities of an escape
artist, animal handling (for stealing mounts),
hiding, jumping (to freedom!), listening (for
guards), moving silently, opening locks, riding skill,
searching (for keys), sensing motivations of others
(for bribes), sleight of hand (for palming objects),
general survival skills, swimming, tumbling, and
others.

Explore

The PCs must explore, survey, and map a place for
themselves or their patron. Such exploration is
necessary to prevent the party from going astray and
getting lost in places where food and other resources
are scarce.

The place could consist of catacombs, caves, ruins,
mines,                             islands, labyrinths, necropolises, trackless
wilderness, or similar locations. The expedition’s
goal might be to determine whether a viable threat
exists and whether rumors and legends of the place
are accurate.

Useful skills: balancing, climbing, disabling traps,
the                            skills of an escape artist, jumping, listening,
riding, searching, spotting things, general survival
skills, and swimming (most actions falling under
Prowess → Agility, or Competence → Expertise or
Skulduggery).

262


Investigate

Some magical, divine, or psionic lore poses a danger
to                               the heroes, their home, or their allies. The threat,
typically someone who carries such knowledge and
cannot be trusted, must be eliminated. Usually, such
an entity is a sage of evil alignment who possesses
knowledge that he threatens to employ under the
right conditions.

Useful skills: deciphering scripts, forgery, gathering
info,                          sensing motive (will the person possessing the
knowledge use it?), sleight of hand (to steal and
destroy material knowledge), broadly falling under
Competence and Prowess.

Discover

Perhaps there is a place containing a person, thing,
knowledge, or force which must be found and used.
But, alas, its location is unknown.

This place could be anywhere: Hallowed and
unhallowed ground, fountains of youth, the River
Styx, hidden mage towards, lost caves, forgotten
ruins, and unmapped places of yore.

Useful skills: knowledge (history, arcane, ancient
history,                              et cetera), gathering info, travel, evaluation,
hunt, luck, ranging, mental resistance (to withstand
magical emanations or traps), or precision-based
abilities for tricks and stealth.

Spells that discern the truth are helpful.

Espionage

Uncover plots and conspiracies, criminal plans,
enemy                           strategies and tactics, troop dispositions, and
so on. To go incognito is a must to spy on or infiltrate
on the enemy ranks, at least temporarily, whether
required of the adventurers or one of their allies.

Skills useful to the task include bluffing (avoid
detection),                         disguising oneself (avoid detection),
forgery (change identity), sense motivations.

Useful skills: powers of evaluation, one’s
Competence → Perception, general scrutiny,

adeptness with stealth, roguish tricks, and urbane
knowledge.

Seek

The player characters are set on a quest to find a
person,                             place, or thing. Perhaps some powerful
artifacts must be found. It could be something used
to avert disaster or cataclysm or a symbolic item that
has the power to calm social or political strife. Or it
could be one piece of a shattered item that must be
restored.

Neutralize Mysterious Evil

It could be that some magical, divine, or psionic
items                                or artifacts threaten the heroes, their home, or
their allies. This threat must be eliminated.

Useful Skills: Competence-based actions include
appraisal                              (to detect decoys), divination, crafting (to
create decoys), deciphering scripts (to read ancient
treasure maps), disabling devices or traps (or else
get blown up), specific knowledge (any sort relevant
to the item), and searching, the abilities of an escape
artist (when the item itself can entrap), general
arcane or divine knowledge, and spellcraft to identify
magical hazards.

Seek Knowledge

This objective involves hard-won knowledge. It
concerns                        scholarship, so much information or study
will be needed. Knowledge must be obscure or
esoteric, but information about any profession or
craft may be lost. Only the largest number of sages
and experts (NPCs only) will access this knowledge.
Implied here is the exposing of lies and
misinformation.

Useful Skills: Deciphering scripts (the truth
sometimes                                is in old documents), diplomacy (people
who are liked are more apt to find the truth),
disguising oneself (attain truth by infiltration),
forgery (to get into places where truth can be found),
gathering information (the universal failsafe skill),

263


STORY


intimidation, sensing the motivations of others, spot
(for                           visible clues).

Search for Individuals

A known and (as far as is known) living person is
missing                              and must be located. They hold some
important item, fact, or expertise required before the
final goal can be attained.

Useful skills: diplomacy (to win friends of those who
may be protecting their whereabouts), disguising
oneself (to fool those who protect the person’s
whereabouts), forgery (to seem official when
inquiring), gathering info, intimidation (when the
person knows the person’s whereabouts but is
stubborn), sensing the motivations of others, spot (if
the person happens to run by…).

Unravel Mystery

The identity of some mysterious NPC, creature, or
supernatural entity must be discovered. Terrible
events have been associated with this mysterious
figure, a legendary figure, the key to the treasure,
etc.

Useful skills: gathering information, sensing others'
motivations, and the best magic spells for ferreting
out somebody who hides.

Diplomacy Objectives

Adventurers will not only accomplish their goals
with                              sword and spell! In fact, there will be occasions
when diplomacy and negotiation will be their most
effective weapons. Diplomacy objectives requires
that you use your persuasive abilities and knowledge
of cultural practices and customs to achieve your
objectives. It may be necessary to negotiate peace
between warring factions, persuade a recalcitrant
NPC to provide information or aid, or convince a
ruler to alter a harmful policy.

Diplomacy requires finesse and tact, and those
skilled                            in this art will achieve great success. Only
through a profound understanding of the world’s

complexities will you be able to successfully navigate
its                         complexities. The addition of diplomacy to your
arsenal of skills and abilities will give you a new way
to approach challenges in the game, emphasizing the
importance of social skills and communication in
addition to physical and investigative abilities.

In this realm, a silver tongue and a keen
understanding                               of others’ motivations will serve thee
well. Choose thy words with care, adventurer, for
they may prove more potent than weapons!

Negotiate Peace between Two
Warring Kingdoms

Two neighboring kingdoms are on the brink of war,
and                               the player characters have been tasked with
negotiating a peace treaty between them. The
kingdoms have long-standing grievances against
each other, and tensions are high. The player
characters must navigate the delicate political
situation, gain the trust of both sides, and find a way
to broker a lasting peace.

Useful Skills: Diplomacy, bluffing, sense motive,
knowledge of cultural practices and customs,
history, and politics.

Convince a Stubborn Ruler to Change
a                     Harmful Policy

A ruler has implemented a policy that is causing
harm                                 to the people in his or her kingdom, but refuses
to change it. The player characters must find a way to
convince the ruler to alter the policy for the
betterment of the realm’s subjects. However, the
ruler is known for stubbornness and is unlikely to
change his or her mind easily.

Useful Skills: Diplomacy, bluffing, sense motive,
knowledge of cultural practices and customs,
persuasion, and charisma.

Players’ Introduction

Ainerêve, the Eldritch Realms, and Crossroads

AINERÊVE

Ainerêve

The cloud-capp’d towers, the gorgeous palaces,


Ainerêve is a fantasy world, shaped by the dreams of
Earth: it has normal lands and peoples, as well as
mythical monsters, fantastic races, working magic,
and otherworldly influences. It is made up of settled
lands (stable areas) where most adventuring takes
place, and unsettled lands (areas in flux), which are
more dreamlike, and provide the means for
interdimensional jaunts. Some of the lands were
established in the past by folk magically transported
from Earth.

Player characters are assumed to be natives of or
visitors                                to the Eldritch Realms, a group of settled
lands in Ainerêve. To the north is Dalmavand, a
proudly independent kingdom, culturally an
amalgam of Norse and later medieval society, shaped
by Nordic myth. Its hardiest heroes are descendants
of the Varangian guard. Centrally situated is the
Forest of Meath, a place defined by Celtic mythology,
whose native shee clash with Persian peris and
deevs. To the south lies Psarmorum, peopled by a
lost company of Templar Knights and pilgrims
tricked into worshipping a demon. Westerly lies
Maedoen, a kingdom of pre-Roman Celtic/Welsh
culture, but changed under the influence of the shee.

The town of Crossroads is situated in Maedoen, on
the                               edge of the Forest of Meath. It functions as a kind
of neutral city state. It is an active trading center,
and a natural meeting place for travelers, both from
the Eldritch Realms and further afield, since it
contains the Equinox Portals, magical gates to other
realms. It also features the Guardians’ Guild (an
explorers and adventurers group), a Mages’ College,
and many collegial inns and taverns. Player
characters of any kind and background can be easily
introduced to the setting, a perfect springboard for
those in search of adventure.

The solemn temples, the great globe itself,
Yea                         all which it inherit, shall dissolve;
And, like this insubstantial pageant faded,
Leave not a rack behind. We are such stuff
As dreams are made on, and our little life
Is rounded with a sleep.

— [ The Tempest (IV i) ]

Ainerêve is a dream world, a shadow realm, an
alternative                          dimension. It coexists undetectably with
the Earth that we all know so well. Its essence may be
primordial chaos, raw protomatter left over from the
creation of the universe, or perhaps the aether of the
ancients: the fifth element, breathed by the gods and
forming the soul. Whatever its basis, its substance is
mainly shaped by thought and takes local form from
the beliefs and imaginings of humankind. Ainerêve is
thus something like a phantom Earth — it has lands
and seas, mountains and rivers, sun and moon — but
reality there is unstable, and areas of normality are
set like mosaic pieces in a changeable flux of dream
and caprice.

In general terms, Ainerêve is made up of settled
lands                             and unsettled lands. These terms are in
common use, in one form or another, across the
dream world. Settled lands are stable regions,
internally consistent and relatively static. Physical
phenomena and those things that depend on them
(such as travel) are normal. There can be weird
things in settled lands, things that no person on
Earth ever saw, but even the weird things there are
somewhat predictable, being folk beliefs and so on
conceived of on Earth.

Ainerêve’s primordial protomatter has a receptive
intelligence,                            literally reifying the thoughts and
dreams it responds to. It fills in the gaps from the
Earth it swirls through, so when a forest or herd of
animals is imagined, each tree and beast is real and

268


indistinguishable from its earthly model.
Extraordinary                            creatures are extrapolated from this
basis, so they are mostly real, and for instance, a
shee (one of the fairy folk) can mate with a human.
Sentient beings have free will and, in some cases,
their own souls. In short, things are pretty much like
a fantastic Earth. Walk down the road to the baker,
and he’ll always be there. Houses don’t get infected
with some sap’s random thought of Baba Yaga and
walk away on their owners. It is beliefs, solid and
lasting, that create settled lands. Over time, as a
mythology or religion refuses to fade on Earth, it
creates a place in the infinitely malleable Ainerêve.
That is where settled lands come from.

Unsettled lands are lands unclaimed by any belief,
and                               they are ruled by dreams. Whereas lasting faith
or consistently-held ideas forge a settled land and
stabilize it, the quicksilver dreams of humanity keep
the unsettled lands in constant flux. Far stranger
things happen or live there than in the settled lands,
and they are far more dangerous. A location in the
unsettled lands can be concrete and real in
appearance (even if thematic), dreamlike, or
completely abstract, and may sometimes change
with the ideas of the moment. Love may create a
blushing pink-and-red area with soft curves and
some razor-sharp angles. Cult beliefs might focus on
the cult leader and vague savior figures, perhaps
with the cold, blue and white backdrops of
unswerving dedication.

Proximity in Ainerêve’s Unsettled lands is dictated
largely                             by conceptual nearness. That is, two places
are only as close as the dreams or beliefs that color
and shape those locations. To travel from an
unsettled place based on fear of death to one based
on fear of the dark is a short jaunt — the emotions
are the same, and both are shadowy unknowns.

Going from the idea of a circus, complete with spun
sugar and clowns, to a wealthy fantasy kingdom
requires a longer trip. Worse, in the unsettled lands
you can never be sure if going the same direction
means you’ll get to the same place each time.

Ainerêve’s definition of nearness means that the
settled                             lands, defined largely by a single belief
system, surround themselves with related concepts.
Travel out of a Buddhist settled land, and the
unsettled lands will be more Hindu or Taoist than
Christian or Norse. Still, it usually takes a significant
period of traveling through unsettled lands to reach
a settled land not one’s own. Leaving the Buddhist
region, one is likely to come across pseudo-Buddhist
unsettled ideas first. Buddhist-like religions, ideas of
peace, reincarnation, vegetarianism, and other
Buddhist precepts will abound. Next might come
admixtures of Buddhist and Hindu concepts, and
then near-Hindu beliefs before the traveler finally
reaches a Hindu-flavored settled land.

The change is very gradual. Settled lands exert their
stabilizing influence over a significant area. Leaving
one means that a traveler will experience a slow
change in general wilderness décor as one belief
melds into another, and from the various ideas that
have seeped in over the years. It is only far from any
settled land that a person finds places that change as
he watches and where a misstep can mean a
thousand years of pain. There are not settled lands
for every religion and belief, or Ainerêve would all be
settled lands, with a slow change in nature as one
traveled across it. Instead, the criterion for becoming
a settled land is the sort of imaginative energy that
resonates with the realm.

One can navigate unsettled lands in two ways: in
the                          educated manner, following the chain of
concepts from one settled land to another; and by
conventional (settled land) navigation, which may
function as intended, but usually depends more on
instinct. In the end, both are equally effective — or
ineffective. Skilled travelers of unsettled lands are
very rare, and usually mix the two methods to find
their way in and out more than once.

Beyond conceptual similarity, there is one other
thing                               that can bring two places together in the dream
world. Repeated and shared experience can solidify
parts of the unsettled lands to make a reliable (if not

269


AINERÊVE


necessarily safe) path between two unalike locations.
This                          happens only rarely.

Inhabitants come to Ainerêve from two sources:
Earth                              dreams and beliefs, and Earth itself. The first is
more common, as the imaginations of the Victorian
era conjure figures like Dracula into being, or as the
fears of early American settlers give rise to
nightmarish entities reflective of their own
prejudices and tales. Entire unsettled lands have
been populated this way, though the inhabitants
generally fade over time and disappear unless
reinforced with belief. People from Earth
occasionally travel to the dream world through a
form of unknown magic. Once there, most end up
making their lives there and beginning a new society
in whatever settled land they can find. Usually,
people from Earth only find their way through to
settled lands to which they are close — those based
on beliefs similar to theirs.

The Eldritch Realms

This book concerns itself with a very small section of
Ainerêve. It involves settled lands with enough
concepts in common that they grew together over
long periods of time.

To the north is Dalmavand, a proudly independent
kingdom,                           culturally an amalgam of Norse and later
medieval society, shaped by Nordic myth. Its hardy
heroes are mainly descendents of the Varangian
guard.

Centrally situated is the Forest of Meath, a place
defined                               by Celtic mythology, whose native shee clash
with Persian angels (peris) and demons (deevs). To
the south lies Psarmorum, peopled by a lost
company of Templar Knights and pilgrims tricked
into worshipping a demon in a twisted simulacrum
of Christianity.

Westerly lies Maedoen, a kingdom founded on the
Celtic/Welsh culture that preceded Roman
occupation, but changed forever under the influence
of the powerful shee.

The War of Cultures

Psarmorum is evangelistic and conformist, and their
discovery of the heathen Maedoens on the other side
of the Forest of Meath roused them to another of
their many holy crusades. This one has been going
on intermittently for at least a hundred years, but
it’s hard to be certain. On the Maedoens’ part, they
war for their way of life and their shee brethren.

The Forest of Meath, apparently stuck in the
middle,                         manages to flourish despite soldiers
tromping back and forth through it. The northern
kingdom of Dalmavand is neither powerful nor
populous, but stands out for its fiercely free spirit
and savagery in combat. Its people are a sturdy,
high-hearted race, sound in body and ardent in
spirit, and produce adventurers aplenty.

Cosmology

In Ainerêve, reality is born from the dreams of
Earth’s                          creatures. These inner visions, shaped by
imagination and desire, merge with the ethereal
substance known as Meterea—the plane of
manifestation—to form an alternate reality. Symon
of Dalmavand, often dismissed as mad, proposed
that beings within Meterea progress through stages
of solidification. Emerging first in a liminal, semi-
existent state within the unsettled lands, they
gradually cohere as the collective unconscious of
Earthbound minds lends them definition, until they
pass into more concrete realms of being.

Spirits of the Unsettled Lands

A location in the unsettled lands can be concrete and
real                                in appearance, dreamlike, or completely
abstract, or even change with the ideas of the
moment. Where a location is more abstract or
dreamlike, it is common to encounter spirits called
Inklings. Where a location is more real or thematic, it
is more likely to encounter Extantars, and other
beings of more discernable forms and types.

270


Extantar: When something of more defined form,
purpose,                               and intelligence is imagined by dreaming
humans on Earth, its idea may be elaborated upon,
written in stories, drawn in imaginative books, and
take various forms. These creatures are mortal, but
exist mostly in the unsettled borders of the Meterea.
They typically take the shape of something
humanoid, animal, or mythical creature. Some can
even fly, depending on the dream seed from which it
was born. Gazing upon and examining an Extantar
directly is difficult. They seem to constantly morph
and shift their form in an unsettling way that tricks
the eyes and makes it difficult to pinpoint their exact
position. Extantars are known to be subject to
perceiver's own beliefs about what he or she is
seeing, thereby slightly shifting in appearance, so no
two people see the same thing, though it will be
similar.

Inkling: A shadow of an idea, usually manifesting
only                                 as a sort of will or purpose, sometimes good,
sometimes evil. These spirits are like shreds of
dreams, unformed with only emotions or intent
apparent. They take the form of shades, sometimes
humanoid, sometimes animal-like, their coloration
shades of grey, from nearly white to black; the
darker the shade, the more ill-will or malice is
apparent. They emanate their intent and can harm or
heal if encountered.

Creatures of the Settled Lands

Settled lands are represented by entire mythologies
and                              belief systems that merge within the Meterea, its
constituent dream seeds attracted to each other by
centralizing motifs in their prevailing time and
cultures, the vision of a place concretizing in areas of
the dream world like “reality bubbles,” its borders
defined largely by a single belief system, slowly
dissolving out into unsettled protomatter at its
edges.

Reifient: Any creature native to the Eldritch Realms
whose                            reality solidified into an archetypal being is
classified as a Reifient. Although the first of these
beings may be born of chimeric energy, stepping out
of the dream to walk upon the settled ground, it is
not entirely understood how the various fantastical
species proliferated. Once made manifest in the
Eldritch Realms, such creatures tend to procreate
and multiply as would their near counterparts on
Earth, or by some means dictated by their
unknowing creators’ collective imagination. All
alfar, fay, elves, dwarves, goblinoids, giants, gods,
and dragons alike are classified as Reifients.

Sojourners and Outlanders: Sojourners are spirits of
humans in astral travel, sometimes blown by astral
winds through the Meterea into Ainerêve. Outlanders
are humans of Earth, real by definition, and brought
into Ainerêve through a revorage rift (aka dream
storm). Sometimes this is a single individual, and
other times it is an entire town, but what they have
in common is that where they cross over is generally
dictated by their collective experience, beliefs, and
the reality with which they are familiar.

271


Volitional Demiplanes

The Volitional Demiplanes emerge from the
determination                               of powerful entities, shaped by the
deliberate shaping of Ainerêve's foundational
material into autonomous and distinct realities.
These realms reflect the visions, desires, and

AINERÊVE

Dream Storms; Reveorage Rifts

A dream storm, known estoerically by sages as
Reveorage Rifts, is a particularly vivid dream
experience shared (but not always recalled) by a
group, arising from the collective psyche.

Should this psychic squall encounter a drift of


occasionally the trepidations of their creators, going
beyond simple physical spaces and often displaying
characteristics vastly different from their
geographical surroundings. These domains are
under the control of Reifients—gods, demigods, and
other influential figures, each realm mirroring its
creator's hopes, fears, and dreams.

Accessing these demiplanes varies greatly
depending                                on the intent of their creators. Some may
require mastery of arcane rituals, expertise in
traversing ethereal dimensions, and the strength to
withstand the mental and physical challenges
encountered during such expeditions. Conversely, in
other cases, one might inadvertently find themselves
in a demiplane while meandering through a forest.

The perception and nomenclature of the Volitional
Realms                          differ across cultures, shaped by local
legends and mythologies. In Dalmavand, they are
honored as "Echoes," seen as dwellings of deities.

Maedoen views them as "Sanctuaries," approached
with                                a combination of trepidation and awe as
residences of enigmatic powers. In Psarmorum, they
are referred to as “Sanctums,” erroneously believed
to be dens of demonic entities. Meanwhile, the
Meath forest inhabitants know them as “Fertile
Glens.” Spanning from the lush landscapes of
Meath's Fertile Glens to the daunting urban expanse
of Dys, each embodies a unique reality.

magical energy it can form a revorage rift, a gate

between the real and dream worlds. This affects only
certain areas and times that are or can become ‘thin
spots’ in the fabric of reality.

— Excerpt from the chapter ‘The Nomological Law of
Manifestation,’ from the Tome of Unreality, written by
the heretic Magister Esprit-Faucon of Psarmorum.

“These realms are a tapestry of an eldritch dream
becoming                             manifest, some law of the universe strangely
reifying the dreams and nightmares of humankind. So, in
my epiphany, I have discovered a dream, a rêve
transmogrified into a nightmare. I hate this revelation
and loathe to share it with the unenlightened. It would
drive most mad to know that we are each the
epiphenomena of a parallel reality, with no essential
selves but that dreamed of in another place and time. It is
a place of hateful dreams, an entire plane I henceforth
call Ainerêve. Maybe some can embrace its chaotic and
chimeric nature, but I cannot fully comprehend the
implications regarding the Outlanders.

The Outlanders, through this intuition, being humans of
Earth, are more real by definition than am I and brought
into Ainerêve through a Revorage Rift, as would a
visiting god. And no, this will not do. There must be a
way to reverse the flow of manifestation, to upend these
laws so that one like myself can create them rather than
the other way around. Through an understanding of
magic, this may one day be achieved.

Take, for example, the commonalities of the humanoid
creatures                                 in these realms. All is explained by the
independent origination of similar biological forms and
functions in the imaginations of humanity. Still, it is
through the common motifs of the myth that we are
made real. One day, we of Ainerêve will turn the tables,
and the people of Earth will become our dreamt-of

realities.”

272


The Calendar of Ainerêve

The calendar of Ainerêve was devised by a sage of
Crossroads, a man named Symon, currently a
member of Crossroad’s Octocirculi Academy, and a
worshipper of the god Chronos. Symon is one of the
very few scholars in the Eldritch Realms who
recognized that the universe of Ainerêve consists of
homogenous reality “bubbles,” each sphere
reminiscent of the cultures of the people who
collectively dream of them, unlike the Fertile Glens
created by singularly powerful beings who craft their
own realms within extradimensional spaces in the
forest of Meath.

Symon figured that although time does march on,
as                                 on all worlds, it is not fixed around the rotation of
the sun as it is for Earth. So he used Earth’s
Gregorian Calendar as a starting point and changed
the names of the months and days, mixing local
languages and added the suffix “rêv” to the end of
each month, meaning a turn of an Astral Dream
Cycle, which is a full month of the generative dreams
of every living creature on Earth.

A full dream cycle representing the solidifying
power                                 of one month of Earth’s dreamers slowly
altering reality in unsettled lands, its influence
slowing seeping into the edges of settled lands.
Among the scholars in the Eldritch Realms familiar
with Symon's theory of a dream-based reality, few
are convinced of its veracity; however, a handful of
Outlanders, who have survived the passage through a
dream storm from Earth, find such truth in their
newfound, surreal existence.

Regional Descriptions

Having established a solid understanding of the
overall                          structure and milieu of the Eldritch Realms,
we now venture into a closer examination of each
distinct region. These pages offer a thorough
exploration of every area, revealing their distinctive
traits, key personalities, and concealed mysteries.

This in-depth insight enables you to deeply engage

with the world, create compelling stories, and shape
memorable adventures.

Population: Small villages and hamlets, focusing on
specific trades like agriculture or fishing, maintain a
traditional way of life. Moderately sized towns serve
as trading hubs, offering diverse professions and
services. Large cities, populated by merchants,
scholars, and adventurers, provide opportunities for
knowledge, wealth, and intrigue.

Economy: Details the economic framework, key
industries, and unique trade practices of a region.
Provides insight into the prevalent types of
businesses and the overall economic health of the
area.

Local Pantheon: This section explores the religious
and                          spiritual landscape of a region. It includes
descriptions of the major deities worshipped, the
nature of religious practices, and the influence of
these beliefs on the daily life and governance of the
area.

Local Authorities: Who lays down the law? Well, this
is                             where you go to find out.

Important Entities: Whether Game Master-
controlled                        characters or well-known monsters and
organizations, they will be described and given
statistics here if they’re important to the region.

Only the most influential or mighty creatures
deserve                           definition on the grand scale of a nation, so
most end up within a specific location. Also in the
individual character descriptions will be some rough
directions for rivalries, alliances, and how else
things might play out in a game.

Noteworthy Places: This tells you what all pilgrims,
travelers,                          locals, or sightseers recognize about the
place, what’s famous or infamous, and what isn’t
well-known, but still may be important. Great
pyramids and great whorehouses both fall under this
category.

274


Relics and Treasures: Famous bits of loot or
powerful                            artifacts that can be found in the region.
Anything important enough to draw a petty thief’s
eye but too well-guarded for him to steal falls under
this category, as do other interesting prizes.

Vendors and Dealers: Every good adventurer needs
someone who can turn the treasures he or she
“finds” into lovely, lovely cash. These are the good
ones (and sometimes the bad ’uns, too). These can
also serve as “fixers” for some mission-style games.

Guilds and Training: Not every place is large enough
for                        organizations to be present, but when they are,
this is where you find them. Thieves’ guilds, mage’s
guilds, churches, and the like. Also, when a character
wants to find a teacher for some skill or the other,
guilds and individual teachers or independent paths
listed here to fill that need.

Regional Monsters: Here you find a description of
the                              sort of thing your heroes can find to fight in any
given place, along with sample statistics.

Adventure Hooks: This is just about the most
important                             entry in the whole list. Sure, you need to
know what a region looks like and how its
inhabitants act, but you really need some good ideas
for your games. This is where you find them. (There
are also plenty of potential adventure seeds in the
text should you wish to develop them.)

Crossroads

Located near the Forest of Meath in Maedoen’s
Kingdom                                of Croisrath, Crossroads is a haven for
adventurers and mystics. Bustling markets teem
with life, guild halls are filled with tales of bold
deeds, and the renowned college of magic attracts
seekers from across the Eldritch Realms. Here, Alfar
and humans—an uncommon sight in Maedoen—
gather, drawn by the town’s converging ley lines and
the mysterious Equinox Portal at its heart.

At the center of the town stands the imposing
structure                           of the Guardians’ headquarters. This
adventurers’ guild hall, surrounded by lively
marketplaces, is a bulwark against the untamed
dangers lurking in nearby lands and the Forest of
Meath.

Under the spiritual watch of the matriarchal Gan
Creadigeath and the wise rule of High King Gwalter
ap Dagda, Crossroads balances druidic traditions
with regal authority. The influential Black Standard,
an independent mercenary group, is also subtley
involved in the towns’ security and politics, with
many members joining the town guard.

In the heart of the town, Duchess Sibyl, the regent
of                            Croisrath since King Verurteilt’s demise, has
forged strong alliances with the Guardians’ Guild,
the druidic Sisters of Gan Creadigeath, and the
esteemed leaders of the mage College, united in their
sworn duty to safeguard and prosper the region.

Rising majestically from the heart of Crossroads is
the                               mage College, also known as Octocirculi
Academy. This esteemed institution is a visual
marvel, its four towering spires and spiraling turrets
piercing the skyline like magical innovation. Within
the hallowed halls of the academy, individuals from
all walks of life converge, united by their pursuit of
magical knowledge and understanding that
transcends linguistic barriers.

275


AINERÊVE


Also near the central part Crossroads lies the
Equinox                          Gatehouse, harboring the infamous Equinox
Portal – a gateway to realms beyond.

Population: Moderate. The town is an active trading
center,                              with a surplus of farm produce and timber
and a constant flow of mundane and exotic goods
and those trade in them. Many people pass through
Crossroads, including some especially strange
denizens who arrive via the guarded Equinox Portals,
which open to a dimensional rift twice a year. Those
who travel through unsettled lands are drawn to
Equinox Portals, which sit on the nexus of ley lines.
This brings in to Crossroads travelers from different
cultures, as well as otherworldly places in Ainerêve.

Economy: Strange travelers from Meath Forest,
wayfarers                            once lost in unsettled lands but stumbling
upon this town, and merchants from both Maedeon
and Psarmorum create an economy of barter and

trade in Crossroads, especially in exotic teas and
coffees.                               A small number of other-realm adventurers
(and monsters) filter through to Maedoen and
Psarmorum, making Crossroads the perfect place to
find black market items, magic items, and weapons
and armor uncommon to local realms. It’s a great
place to hire a ranger guide or typical mercenaries.
Information is also a big commodity in Crossroads.
The Guardians’ Guild and Mages’ College are the
prime sources.

Local Pantheon: Crossroads recognizes and tolerates
the                           followers of many pantheons, accepting all
deities so long as they do not represent forces
opposed to the towns very existence, although most
of its temples and shrines are dedicated to the array
of deities belonging to the pantheon of the Tuatha
De, the Celtic Mythos holding greatest sway among
the majority of the towns denizens.

Local Authorities: Duchess Sibyl oversees Crossroads
and                              pays homage to Gwalter ap Dagda, the King of
Maedoen who sits on the throne of the city of
Grimsete. She knows the town is particularly
hazardous, situated as it is on the nexus of major ley
lines, and thus prone to infiltration or outright
attack by powerful monsters. The town guard is paid
handsomely and helps keep dangerous beings from
entering the town or raiding farms and is sometimes
supplemented by unusual members of the
Guardians’ Guild.

The town is considered a “neutral zone,” as
enforced                               by the Guardian’s Guild, and that fact has
attracted adventurers from myriad backgrounds,
including Bertran Forthwind, who famously set up
the most esteemed magic school in the realms, the
Octocirculi Academy. This was in part to help Virgil,
the guild leader, and the Duchess protect the two
kingdoms of Maedoen from the dangers of the
Equinox Portals of Ainerêve.

The guard is led by a goblinoid half-orc named
Throk:                             he was captured outside town, exposed as a
smuggler leading black-market criminals into

276


Crossroads, and was to be executed by the Duchess.
The                           Duchess is fervent about controlling any
criminal element in Crossroads, especially regarding
goblinoid creatures, whom she personally dislikes.

But an elf named Nathal, one of the Gan
Creadigeath’s                         emissaries from the Seelie court
stepped in and saved Throk’s life on the condition
that he serve the town forever. Nathal claimed that
the half-orc’s human side had some shee blood–as
do all Maedoens–and, therefore, Throk was not a
complete abomination.

Throk. Occupation: Captain, town guard (warrior).
Half-orc                           male. Competence d6 → Perception d10.
Prowess d12 → Melee d12 (Threat +2) + Precision d6.
Fortitude d8 → Endurance d12 + Strength d10 +
Willpower d8. SP (Spirit Points): 14, Active DP: 24,
Passive DP: 30. Armor: d8 (chain).

Notes: Throk is a half-orc, an unfortunate fact few
have                             failed to recognize due to his exceptionally
homely appearance. His origin was one of violence
and tragedy. His human mother was called “Mère
Aufahm” by her mercenary hirelings and “The
Whore of the Orcs” by the goblinoid tribes. She was
no victim but a perpetrator, a blackheart who forced
the women of her remote town to copulate with the
local Orc chieftain, only to sell the unnaturally
strong babies as warrior slaves to nomad tribes in
the far reaches of Psarmorum. “Throk” was named
after the sound made when she’d smack his large,
crooked nose. He was an exception to her business
model, her own child raised solely to protect her.

But her luck ran out, as did Throk’s, when Lucalla
tribe                           members raided and slaughtered her and all of
her half-orc slaves. Throk fled into Meath forest,
met many strange allies, and emerged a year later
near Crossroads, where he suddenly appeared to help
the elf Nathal escape a band of marauding harpies
near the forest border.

Equipment: Great Axe of Shattering (a roll above 8
bypasses armor if attack exceeds defender’s chosen
Active Defense. Opponent’s armor must make an
item saving throw versus double its die rank (i.e.,

leather 2d6, Chain 2d8, etc.) or be reduced one die-
rank                             until repaired. Also, defender’s shields, if used,
have a 2% chance of shattering per threat point
inflicted with Throk’s Axe (including Common
magical shields). He also owns several spears and a
sledgehammer.

Treasure: Throk carries beef jerky, a few coins, and
his                           weapons. Now and then, he may have a severed
head in his bag as a temporary souvenir. He’s not
known to care much for treasure.

Duchess Sibyl. Occupation: Duchess of Crossroads (&
Queen Regent of Croisrath). Human female.

Competence d10 → Expertise d8 + Perception d6.
Prowess d4 → Precision d6. Fortitude d6 →
Willpower d10. SP (Spirit Points): 20, Active DP: 4,
Passive DP: 6. Armor: None (+2 DR azure cloak,
works like a shield).

Notes: Duchess Sibyl is tall and regal, usually seen
wearing                            beautiful flowing sapphire gowns and
valuable but understated jewelry (one item of which,
a garnet ring, is the focus for her spells, adding +2 to
her ability tests). The daughter of a Psarmorum
prince, she was promised in marriage to King
Verurteilt, the petty king of the region of Croisrath, a
lesser kingdom of Maedoen, as a peace offering. The
Duchess understood the value of good alliances and
relished the power the marriage afforded her,
despite the common knowledge that Verurteilt was a
fool. She confidently expected Verurteilt to undo
himself sooner or later, which he gratifyingly did
when he slipped from atop a turret when drunk and
fell to his death. She has a keen mind and is a good
judge of character, so she was adept at navigating the
political strife attendant on stepping into her late
husband’s role.

Her friendship with Virgil of the Guardian’s Guild
and                             Bertran Forthwind of the mage College was
fortuitous, allowing them to shield her from rivals,
and secure the land the Duke had once claimed,
building it into Crossroads as it is today. The Duchess
afforded herself a unique amount of power and
prestige among the lords of Maedoen. She was also
appointed a proxy of the Eldritch man to protect the
borderlands of Meath and therefore granted the aid
of Nathal, a Seelie Emissary of the Gan Creadigeath.

AINERÊVE


Equipment: Dagger of the Moon (20 energy points
(EP))                               can activate the spells Full Body Illusion and
Illusory Attack, like a wand. Magical azure cloak (–2
DR as a shield, before Active Defense). The Staff of
the Unsettled (3d10, 24 EP. This is a Jaunt Staff (see

“hoards” (see treasure table in GM Guide): 2000–

Nathal. Occupation: Gan Creadigeath Seelie
emissary,                       adventurer. Elf male. Competence d10 →

Prowess d8 → Precision d10 (Ranged Threat +5) +

Notes: Nathal is a high elf and one of the Shee
nobility,                                 a son of Titania, Queen of the Fair Folk of
Meath. He is kind-hearted and soft-spoken but of
steely resolve when facing evil and injustice. He is
tall, with platinum hair (matching his scintillant
armor), fair skin, and golden eyes, earning him the
appellation “The White Lion.” He represents the
Seelie Court as a liaison between the shee and the
druids in Crossroads and presides over the annual
Council of Renewal between the humans of Maedoen
and the Tuatha Dé Danann.

Equipment: Sword of Fae +4 harm, bypassing
mundane                           shields and armor on any attack roll
totaling over 13. Magic Breast-plate and elven chain
armor 2d8. Cloak of Invisibility (20 energy points).

Treasure: Carries only a few coins (20–200) with
him;                             has a hoard, 1000–10,000 coins value in gems
and “arboreal” art in his domicile.

The council is a tradition that began with the pact
made by the earliest human with the natural
creatures of the land, which established the Dagda

Priesthood. Although Nathal does not quarrel with
Mali,                            leader of the Gan Creadigeath, he deeply
questions the legitimacy of the matriarchal order.
His mother Titania was a party to the treachery that
destroyed the older, male, druidical order of
Cernunnos.

He was also there centuries ago when his father
decreed                             that the Cernunnos bloodline be honored by
making the son of Mab, daughter of moon goddess
Arianrhod, the first Eldritch Man (which has proved
to be a curse to those who hold the “honor”). Nathal
knows that Mab has since joined the Unseelie Courts
planning retaliation against her father, Oberon.

Despite the shee’s tumultuous history, Nathal is not
a                           proponent of their leaving Maedoen for another
fabled realm deemed their homeland, and shuns
pilgrimages to Adweth Hill. He thinks the foretold
exodus is a misreading of legend and that the people
can make the realms their heaven with enough
vision. In this, Nathal finds an ally in Mother Mali
because she wants to integrate the human culture
and shee.

Noteworthy Places

The Duchess’s mansion is constructed of marble,
brick,                                and timber. On the same site is the shrine of
Dagda, housing that priesthood. There also is a small
Temple of Astra, whose shrine serves as a neutral
zone for merchant travelers from Psarmorum.
(Astra, one of the aspects of their god Sol Invictus, is
called the savior by many in Psarmorum. Some
believe he soon will return to the realm and end the
war, heralding an age of peace.) Sol’s followers are
protected by Virgil’s Guardians’ Guild, who prevent
the apprehension of travelers deemed unwelcome by
the Nation of Maedoen. They have saved many from
murder by the Dagda Priesthood.

The Mage College (Octocirculi
Academy)

The Octocirculi Academy in Crossroads is Maedeon's
foremost                            institution for magical education and the
only official school of wizardry. The campus features
eight towers, each representing a distinct magical
discipline: Arcanum, Elementalism, Thaumaturgy,
Sorcery, Druidry, Hieraticism, Mysticism, and
Oneiromancy. Led by Archmage Bertran Forthwind,
the Academy plays a crucial role in both magical
research and political affairs. The annual Council of
Renewal brings together the two Kings of Maedeon
to reaffirm alliances, showcases mages' discoveries,
and fosters cultural exchanges. The Eldritch Man's
recitations, offering insights into ancient magic, are
a highlight of the event.

Bertran Forthwind. Occupation: Chancellor,
Octocirculi                         Academy. Human male. Competence d12

→ Adroitness d8 + Expertise d10 (Spellcraft +5) +
Perception d8. Prowess d4 → Agility d8 + Melee d6 +
Precision d6. Fortitude d6 → Willpower d10 (Vitality

+5). SP (Spirit Points): 22, Active DP: 18, Passive DP:

6. Armor: none. Level: 5, Mastery D12. Signature
Foci:                           Wand (Warp Strike: d12+d10+5). Magic Path:
Thaumaturgy.

Notes: Despite his adventurous spirit, Bertrand
Forthwind                               is a man of unwavering convictions. Of
average height and build, he presents himself
unassumingly, often clad in a simple tunic and cloak.
His unassuming attire belies his mastery of
thaumaturgy, as he carries several gnarled wooden
wands tucked into his belt, along with an athamé, a
ceremonial dagger. Bertrand, along with the
academy's eight designated archmage mentors, is
committed to harnessing the societal benefits of
thaumaturgy.

Equipment: Wand of Binding, 3d10 incapacitation,
maintainable.                           The want is crafted to incapacitate
enemies non-lethally. When activated, it binds the
target with ethereal bonds, immobilizing them for a
duration determined by Bertran's Mastery Die (D12).
The wand works within a moderate range and can
affect one target at a time. Targets may attempt to
break free each round, requiring a difficult Fortitude
or Willpower test. Wand of Psionics, adds 20 to all

279

Sorcery threat points (200 energy points), single
target                               or area effect. Wrhydri bracers (magical
leather), +1 to passive armor, and +6 DR once/round
vs. any spell-based threat points. Also carries an
athamé (more often used as a focus item).

Treasure: Bertrand keeps only a few items on his
person,                               like his wands, and little to no coinage.
However, the college is a practical museum of
strange and dangerous artifacts, the value of which
is indeterminable. A thief may loot the college’s
treasury and come away with several hundred
thousand coinage worth in wealth, with 100% chance
of 3d12 magic items in the haul (many cursed), but
it’s unlikely any but the most legendary footpads
would ever make it out alive.

The Eight, as the academy staff calls themselves,
secretly                            wish to convince Gwalter Ap Dagda to allow
Nerthach, the Eldritch Man, to seek asylum within
their walls as a blatant challenge to the ancient pact
that holds the realms in thrall to the Seelie Court.

Bertrand sees as a golden age the days when the
druids                             were the powerful masters of nature rather
than the mere proxies of the fairies of Meath forest.
He’d wish for the peaceful return of the order of
Cernunnos, not to destroy the Gan Creadigeath, but
to integrate and reform, but he understands that
peace is an unrealistic expectation should those
circumstances arise.

The academy accepts ten students a year, male or
female,                                  of any intelligent (and even innately
magical) race, so long as they show latent talent and
are not associated with the Gan Creadigeath, whose
power Bertrand believes weakens and stifles society.
The Gan Creadigeath, in turn, underestimate his
influence and vision for a more advanced and
decidedly arcane civilization. Travelers will note that
the college grounds are testament to his vision, with
lamps lit by magic and details like a small sourceless
stream running moat-like around the academy,
softly aglow at night. The beautiful, circular meeting
table in the main meeting hall can display an
explorable map of the known realms, like a
mahogany scrying surface. Even the college’s sewage
system and aqueducts are magically aflow. Bertrand


AINERÊVE


happily entertains townsfolk each year with
fireworks                           displays, and throws feasts for nobility
with meals cooked by invisible hands, magic, and
elemental fire. The academy recognizes gods and
goddesses but does not encourage worship so much
as have a healthy respect for their power.

The Equinox Portal of Crossroads

The Equinox Portal is housed inside a large stone
archway                              near the centrally located adventurers' guild
house and is heavily guarded. Delegates from the
kingdom, warriors, and mages hold a ceremony
twice yearly to herald the gate's opening during the
spring and autumnal equinoxes. Nobody knows who
or what will come through the gate at those times.

The Equinox Portal of Crossroads is one of many
scattered                          throughout the Eldritch Realms, all of
which serve as magical conduits to distant places,
and some believe they are all connected by ley lines.
Mages, equipped with appropriate knowledge and
skills, can use these portals for travel to different
locations within the Eldritch Realms. The portal
shifts from one realm to another, the places
predictable only by augury.

The exact place follows an unpredictable pattern, as
dictated by humans’ dreams, hopes, and fears on
both sides of the gate. For those attempting to walk
through the gate, the destination is always
somewhere on the outskirts of settled lands in
Ainerêve; it is inherently dangerous. Some travelers
pass through the rift and travel to the realm of their
choice: perhaps in an induced trance or with the aid
of an artifact that allows quick passage through
unsettled lands. (e.g. jaunt staves.)

Relics and Treasures

Bestiary of Beings Diverse and Malign: This tome is
a                            treasure trove of knowledge about dangerous
creatures that inhabit various realms. It's closely
guarded within the Octocirculi Academy and the
Guardians’ Guild, making it a valuable resource for
those who wish to understand or confront these
monstrous entities.

Artifacts of the Octocirculi Academy: The academy's
treasury                         houses a collection of arcane relics, some of
which may carry curses. Among these items are
historical artifacts, magically potent objects, and
mysterious items with intriguing backstories. Each
artifact has the potential to spark its own adventure.

The Equinox Portal: The Equinox Portal in
Crossroads                                 is more than just a gateway; it's a marvel
of ancient power and construction, offering passage
to other worlds. This symbol of Crossroads'
connection to the wider cosmos is fiercely protected
by the Guardians' Guild, who recognize its strategic
importance. Knowledge and control over the Equinox
Portal are highly sought after, making it a central
point of conflict and intrigue within the city.

Guardians’ Guild Vaults: Rumored to contain
artifacts                               and wealth from numerous expeditions, the
private vaults of the Guardians’ Guild are shrouded
in secrecy. Only the highest-ranking members of the
Guild have knowledge of their contents.

Magic Items of Notable Power: In the bustling
bazaars                             and hidden corners of Crossroads, one can
discover items imbued with rare and potent magics.
These include:

Jaunt Staves: These rare staves, crafted by Virgil
himself,                             are invaluable for guiding travelers through
treacherous, uncharted lands.

Equinox Bands: Wristbands resonating with the
energy                               of the Equinox Gates, facilitating safer and
more precise travel between realms.

280


Leyline Compasses: Intricate devices that detect the
subtle energies of ley lines, indispensable for
navigating the chaotic energies of Ainerêve.

Vendors and Dealers, Guilds and

There are many places to seek rest, entertainment,

Travelers will find several alehouses, a general store,
an apothecary, blacksmith, horse trader, falconer,
gambling house, fishmonger, and wagoners. Other,
more prominent places include:

• The Guardian's Guild and Martial Training Hall, an
imposing structure blending Gothic and
Romanesque styles. Its robust stone façade, adorned
with stained glass and legendary statues, symbolizes
the Guild's strength and the rich tapestry of tales
within.

• Guardian’s Bank; an actual bank — owned
collectively                            by adventurers and explorers and
overseen by Virgil.

• The Boatwright (offering rides along the river that
runs                               next to the town).

• The Octocirculi bookshop, stocked with tomes,
manuals, and scrolls from exotic places.

• Mage College (with its striking spiral towers).

The Guardian’s Guild

The Guardian's Guild, a pivotal hub for mercenaries,
seekers,                            and explorers within the Eldritch Realms, is
at the core of the bustling town of Crossroads. As a
renowned organization teeming with seasoned
explorers, daring swashbucklers, and bold
adventurers, it offers an easy starting point for

characters pursuing camaraderie and adventure.
Situated                         near the Equinox Portals, the Guild is a
gateway to many opportunities and challenges,
drawing in those who thirst for adventure and
beckoning them toward the untold mysteries and
adventures that lie beyond.

The Guild is a common ground for characters from
diverse backgrounds and fantastical species; its
diverse objectives and membership foster most
character motivations and backstories. Characters
can thus pursue quests and treasures or engage in
battles that align with their personal and guild-
driven goals. The Guild's resources further support
this endeavor, providing immediate assets for
characters' adventures, thereby streamlining the
campaign setup.

Integrating new players into an ongoing campaign
centered                             around the Guardian's Guild is
straightforward. Newcomers can be woven into the
story as recent recruits or inducted through the
unfolding narrative organically.

The Guild Hall

The Guardian's Guild building is a striking example
of                              Gothic and Romanesque architecture. Its imposing
stone façade features sturdy buttresses and arched
windows, giving it an air of fortitude and elegance.

The building seamlessly integrates with the
surrounding                        landscape, with ivy and other climbing
plants partially covering its walls.

The Guild is surrounded by well-maintained
grounds,                            featuring a combination of open courtyards
for gatherings and shaded areas for more private
discussions. The main entrance is a large, arched
wooden door reinforced with iron bands and adorned
with carvings depicting scenes of heroic deeds and
mythical creatures.

Large, stained-glass windows are a prominent
feature,                      casting colorful light on the stone paths
leading to the entrance. These windows depict
various historical events and legendary battles.

281


The roof is steep and tiled, with several towers
rising                            above the main structure. These towers serve
various purposes, from lookout points to private
meeting rooms for high-ranking members of the

While the building is not a fortress, subtle

Narrow slits for archers are cleverly disguised in the

practicality and ethical adaptability, recognizing the

leaders understand the need for flexibility in
extenuating circumstances, allowing adventurers to
uphold the Guild's principles while navigating the
challenges they encounter on their missions and
quests. The Guild's broad and malleable principles
are designed to accommodate various individual
character interpretations and playing styles,
empowering players to chart their unique path
within the Guild's framework.

282


Whether adventurers opt for deep integration into
the                             Guild's core activities or prefer a more peripheral
association, players, including the Game Master,
choose the level of involvement that aligns with their
preferences.

I. Guild Loyalty and
Representation

• Guild Identity: Represent the Guild with pride.
Individualism is valued, but actions while wearing
the insignia reflect on the entire Guild.

• Discretion in Using the Insignia: Understand the
influence of the Guild's insignia. It symbolizes
capability, not necessarily altruism.

II. Conduct in Pursuit of
Interests

• Pursue Diverse Goals: Whether
treasure              hunting, monster slaying,
or heroism, pursue your goals
determinedly. The Guild
accommodates myraid ambitions.

• Pragmatic Engagement: Engage
pragmatically.                      Unnecessary cruelty is
discouraged, but "collateral damage" can occur.

III. Responsibility and
Independence

• Guild's Oversight: Members are held accountable
for                          actions undermining the Guild's power,
reputation, or key alliances, especially with
Maedoen's crown.

• Repercussions for Missteps: Actions jeopardizing
relations                          with key allies or misrepresenting our role
face severe repercussions, including expulsion.

• Engaging with External Parties: Conduct outside
activities                          without attracting negative attention to the
Guild. Independence is respected, but not at the cost
of collective reputation.

• Duty to Report: Report actions risking critical
damage                           to the Guild's reputation or alliances.
Collective interests are prioritized over individual
transgressions.

• Guild's Right to Intervene: In severe misconduct
cases,                           the Guild may intervene directly.

IV. Contribution and Support

• Supporting the Guild: Fulfill tithe obligations to
contribute to the Guild’s prosperity.

• Tithe Requirement: Members tithe 10% of annual
earnings                                 to support services and foster camaraderie.

• Enforcing the Tithe: Annual auditing
ensures              compliance. Penalties for

non-compliance may include
suspension or expulsion.

Leniency is possible in
extenuating      circumstances.

• Share Knowledge Wisely:
Share         experiences and
knowledge, but be mindful of

sensitive information.

V. Conflict and
Dispute Resolution

• Self-Regulation: Members are expected to resolve
disputes                       independently.

• Dueling and Challenges: Dueling is a recognized
means                               of settling disputes, conducted honorably and
without disrepute to the Guild.

• Condemned Actions: Actions like treason or
espionage against the Guild are expressly
condemned.

• Avoiding Factionalism: Avoid creating factions
within                             the Guild. Differing opinions are natural, but
division for personal gain is frowned upon.

• Respect for Guild Leadership: Respect for Guild
Leadership: While dissent is part of the Guild's

283


AINERÊVE


dynamic, actions undermining leaders are naturally
frowned                              upon

VI. Operational Integrity

• Avoid Undermining the Guild: Undertake missions
with                              a balance of boldness and discretion. Avoid
actions that weaken the Guild's position.

• Review and Disciplinary Committee: Handles
misconduct cases, ranging from warnings to
expulsion.

• Mitigating Potential Harm:The Guild may
undertake                           reparative missions or public disavowal to
mitigate damage caused by members.

VII. Membership

• Insignia Tattoo or Insignia: Full members receive a
mystical tattoo of the Guardian's Insignia.

• Loss or Removal of the Tattoo: Re-issuance
process                              for lost tattoos due to injury. Unauthorized
removal triggers an alert.

• Detection of Imposters: Imposters risk detection.
The                         "Discern Soul" spell reveals imposters when
cast by authentic members.

The principles emphasize balancing individual
autonomy                           and collective responsibility, shaping the
Guild's identity and operational ethos.

Founder of the Guardian’s Guild

The Guardians are led by Virgil, an eccentric older
man                              who set up the Guild to protect outcast warriors
and renegade mages.

Virgil. Occupation: Adept; Leader of the Guardian’s
Guild.                           Human male. Competence d12 → Adroitness
(Cleverness +2) + Expertise d12 (Wizardry +5) +
Perception d8. Prowess d10 → Agility d10 + Melee d10

+ Precision d6. Fortitude d10 → Willpower d12. SP
(Spirit                            Points): 24, Active DP: 30, Passive DP: 10.
Armor: d8+4 (Wrhydri Chain). Level: 5, Mastery: d12.
Signature Weapon: Rapier of Banishment — Medium

— Slashing; 2d10+2.

Equipment: Virgil’s Jaunt Staff. Like most of the
traveling                             staffs Virgil created, the Jaunt Staff is
attuned along ley lines in Maedoen and Psarmorum,
allowing him unhindered travel via the gates in
either realm. The staff is an artifact capable of
manipulating Ainereve’s protomatter within the
unsettled lands, amplifying Virgil’s “dream vision”
during travel, actually reshaping the terrain, leading
him to where he wants to go like a divining rod, as
long as the place is adequately named and described.
The jaunt staff has a crystal ball affixed to its top,
which amplifies Virgil’s imaginal journey vision,
helping him find his way. It is also imbued with the
following spell-like powers: Dispel Effect
(Thaumaturgy), Flux Bolt, Teleport Object, Teleport
Self.

Rapier of Banishment. Medium — Slashing. Striking
a                          supernatural creature with this legendary rapier
triggers an opposed roll of 3d10 versus the creature’s
Saving Throw, or the summoner’s Competence →
Expertise → Wizardry branch, whichever is more
relevant. Failing this save means the creature is
instantly banished. It’s a permanent item with its
banishment properties always on (therefore, no
energy points required). Wrhydri Chain (d8+4): non-
magical potential harm cannot bypass this armor.

Virgil also possesses many other magic items,
including                            many potions of healing and protection
and perhaps some means of prolonging life since he
is now very old indeed.

Treasure: Virgil owns a bank, and his net worth
amounts                              to that of a dragon’s hoard (something the
Duchess is fond of reminding him): 10,000–60,000
coins value and 50% chance of 2d12 magic items.

Although the guild is independent in outlook, over
the                              years, the group developed into a major force for
weal globally; the amassed skills, expertise, and
daring of its members having proved particularly
effective when dealing with menacing monsters and
dark magic. The guild takes a percent fee on
treasures gained by its members in return for
providing access to information, training,
employment, and other services. Virgil pays a tax to
the Duchess and respects the high king of Maedoen,
but looks the other way when its members’ activities
might be at odds with the king’s interests.

284


The Guardians’ Guild also maintains a labyrinth of
concealed pathways through the Forest of Meath and
beyond, offering alternatives to the Safe Road for
those daring to venture through less charted
territories. These routes are under the vigilant watch
of the Guild, ensuring they remain as secure as
possible.

The Guild's outposts, strategically placed along ley
lines,                               serve as hubs for organizing expeditions and
managing the balance between the known and the
wilds. In exceptional circumstances, where the paths
through the unsettled lands become treacherous, the
Guild may authorize the use of a Jaunt Staff. These
rare artifacts, while not common gear, provide
guidance through the most unpredictable regions,
allowing for expeditions that might otherwise be
impossible. However, it is the bravery and expertise
of the Guild's members that stand as the true
bulwark against the dangers encroaching upon the
kingdoms of Enwys and Croisrath.

The Guild Hall has large books of places and
creatures                         cataloged: some identified by travelers
passing through the Equinox Portal; other
information revealed by captured unfriendly beings
(there is a Guild prison for interrogation of such).

Members may have the Guild’s information for a
price — a very steep price for non-members.

Crossroads Adventure Hooks

Roll up, Roll Up! Canguistine the Magnificent is a
showman beyond compare. All he needs is a show.
Since Crossroads is known to have many monsters,
he has come here to capture a menagerie of beasts
that he will take on tour to the seven corners of the
cosmos — or so he says. Canguistine is slender, dark,
energetic, charismatic and just a little sly: his magic
is showy but of little substance, as is his personality.
He has money and will pay for the capture of rare
creatures — he might go so far as to use the network
of ley lines and the Equinox Portal to summon a
particularly spectacular monster, with the intention
of capturing it of course. He just needs a hand… and
guess who he wants to recruit to give it to him?

285

Nathal’s Fear: The elven emissary has received word
that                                 a dark mirror realm — one that is a duplicate of
Crossroads but a mirror image, where that which is
evil has become good and vice versa, is drawing
metaphorically near to the Equinox gateways and
that an overlap will occur. The duchess has dismissed
his concerns since the sage Signoret has detected no
such dangers, and neither have any of her seers. But
Nathal has not been misled, and a shadow is about to
fall over Crossroads that will see some of its
residents intertwined with their mirror images — a
Crossroads where the Guardian Guild oppresses
rather than protects and evil entities are welcomed
through the portals…

Maedoen

Description: Maedoen is a land of mountains, rivers,
and                             rocky beaches washed by cold waves. It is like old
Wales, and its nature and legends resemble Welsh
and Celtic mythology.

Maedoen occupies the southern part of a peninsula
shaped                              like Earth’s Britain (with Dalmavand
occupying the northern area where Scotland would
be). To the west lies the cold ocean and several large
islands. To the north and south lie great seas,
difficult to cross, separating the Maedoens from the
dangerous unsettled lands. Directly in the center of
the nation’s eastern border lies a hundred-mile
stretch of land that ties the peninsula to the Forest of
Meath and through that to Psarmorum, with which
Maedoen wars. Traveling on the seas around the
forest almost always brings one to unsettled lands
that resemble, but are not, Psarmorum. Meath
cannot be entered on that side; it does not even
appear to connect to the continent, though explorers
believe that it somehow must.

History: Ages ago, what would become Maedoen was
an                             island of warring kings, and the shee who lived
there played mischievously with the inhabitants
instead of looking out for them. At some point, the
sea to the east became fecund, and trees grew out
from the water and floated there atop it. Their seeds
planted more trees, and the trees grew outward from


AINERÊVE


the sea over centuries until they touched Maedoen on
the east and the far land on the west, making the sea
unnavigable. Exploring it, the people of that ancient
land found the sea-forest as stable as any that grew
on the land and more fertile for vegetation and
magic, and soon they forgot its origin and knew it
only as the strange forest.

An unknown period later, the first Knight Templar
emerged                               from the forest, and the war between
Psarmorum and Maedoen began shortly after that. It
has lasted centuries. In addition, great horned
demon-shee attack from the west regularly and with
great ferocity. Their ships sail the waves preceded by
long, iron horns under the waterline, and their great
drums roll with their rowing after they drop sails for
an assault. They have immense strength and
endurance, and if they can capture rather than kill,
they do. These ship-borne monsters are the most
regular threat to the Maedoens from the sea.

Maedoen has two leaders, one spiritual and one
temporal; the Eldritch Man and Gwalter ap Dagda.
The Eldritch Man is the nation’s official spiritual

leader. He is the sole male member of the druidic Gan
Creadigeath and their chosen representative to the
shee creatures of Meath and Maedoen and the gods.
Some believe the Eldritch Man lives forever, but he is
replaced periodically by a properly-trained young
