man. His name is never known, and he spends nearly
all his time among the fay creatures and legendary
gods of Maedoen. Though the Eldritch Man is
supposed to guide the spiritual life of Maedoen, he is
seldom there; the Gan Creadigeath guide the people
in his name.

Ruling over Maedoen in the realm of economy, law,
and                               war is currently Gwalter ap Dagda. The title “ap
Dagda,” meaning “son of the Dagda,” is appended to
every king’s name, and it indicates that the great
blessing and goodwill of the Dagda is with the king.
By the nation’s most ancient law, the product of a
forgotten pact with the land’s natural creatures, the
Maedoen high king is half-shee. Once a king is
crowned and married, he travels with a small retinue
of Gan Creadigeath to find the ‘proper’ shee, as
determined by the king and his advisors. The shee,
once found, spends one night with the queen and
disappears, leaving only a guest gift behind. The next
king is born later. It is rare, but if the king’s heir is
unfit to rule (or simply declared so), the king must
repeat the process (usually with a new wife). Human
blood is always stronger than shee, so the
miscegenation must continue each generation.

Gwalter is a strong king. His sway over Maedoen is
undeniable, and the Gan Creadigeath sorely misses
the great influence they wielded during his father’s
reign, Maddox ap Dagda (Maedoens ignore the
surrogate shee). Gwalter has the strength of arms
and will to lead men well. The Maedoens respect
him, and his position’s strength makes it difficult for
the Gan Creadigeath to refuse his requests of them.

Local Pantheon: The pantheon of Maedoen is
primarily                                an admixture of Celtic and Welsh
mythologies, with the Dagda and Math ap Mathonwy
as the principal deities. The Dagda, the chief deity,
embodies life, death, agriculture, and druidry,

286


wielding powerful artifacts. Math ap Mathonwy is
the                              god of wizardry, encouraging knowledge and
skill. Cernunnos, the Horned God of Nature,
represents untamed nature and druidic traditions.
His story involves a tragic love for Arianrhod and
betrayal by Mab and Arianrhod. Other significant
figures include Arawn, the god of death and justice,
and Brigit, the goddess of life and fertility.

Population: Sparse. Maedoen has a substantial
population,                           enough to guard it against the
depredations of troublesome shee and the
implacable forces of Psarmorum, but they live spread
out. When Maedoens congregate in larger groups,
they never number more than what Psarmorum
would consider a “town.”

Economy: Maedoen is an agrarian society, but all
men                               and many women of age are capable enough
with weapons to defend themselves. At a pinch, the
Maedoens can rise up in arms to defend their homes.
Most of the nation’s economy is internal, involving
trading grains and other foods for woven cloth, iron
tools, and services.

It’s notable that, while the Maedoens do mine and
refine iron ore, they carefully never use iron shaped
while cold. Cold-wrought iron has properties that
make it dangerous to the nation’s shee allies.

Denizens of the faerie realm are also averse to hot-
forged                               iron and steel for this reason, though it does
them no special harm. Since many a poet calls steel
“cold iron,” perhaps this contributed to the
confusion, but it would be unpolitic of Maedoens to
carry steel weapons commonly in any event. As a
result, most of the nation’s tools that require great
sharpness or hardness — mostly for tools of war —
are made of bronze. Because bronze is harder to
come by than simple iron, the uncomplicated folk of
Maedoen still use ordinary wrought iron to make
their knives and simple tools. The ‘cold-wrought
iron’ weaponry is of course only available via black-
market suppliers and by paying massively exorbitant
prices and often is unauthentic. Only kings can or

must spend the effort and money to distribute all-
bronze weapons and tools to their subjects.

Of course, not all fairy folk are friendly; when one
foresees encountering a troublesome shee, there is
little stigma in carrying a knife of cold iron for
security, although the other shee one might meet
with may not agree.

Externally, Maedoen trades to some extent with the
shee. The Gan Creadigeath, led by the Eldritch Man,
takes on this difficult task because the shee require
strange and hard-to-acquire goods or services. In
exchange, Maedoen receives long-lasting spells and
glamor, enchanted objects, and advice. Some
individuals choose to barter for shee goods and
blessings without the protection of the Gan
Credigeath. Only the clever succeed.

There is little trade with Dalmavand, since the two
nations produce similar goods. Some brave
merchants manage to trade reliably with
Psarmorum, more often via Dalmavandish
intermediaries. They regularly bring back weapons
of excellent steel and foreign arts and craftwork;
from Maedoen, they take local woodwork and things
of fay make. The best make a great living, but they
are few. One of the secrets that none have been able
to bring back from Psarmorum is making good steel.
Over the last two hundred years, many have tried,
but without a single success.

Most Maedoens who think about it believe that the
smiths of Psarmorum must be supremely protective
of their crafts, or the close-mouthed government is
skilled at killing those who acquire that knowledge
for Maedoen. In truth, it is the fay of the Forest of
Meath, and the shee of Maedoen, who are to blame.
They stop those who would carry the process to
Maedoen; the forest fay do it to spite them, the allied
shee of Maedoen do it because they prefer bronze. To
the shee, bronze is a soothing alloy.

287


Local Authorities

Gwalter ap Dagda has authority over Maedoen in
secular matters, and the Gan Creadigeath, led by
Mother Mali, directs the Maedoens in the spiritual

AINERÊVE

the creatures of Hell. While avoiding direct
involvement                            with Sol’s corrupted High Priests, the
Guardians aid and protect Psarmorum’s warriors
against Satan’s legions. Psarmorum crusaders are
protected in the town of Crossroads and guaranteed


aspects of life. Tradition separates Maedoen into two

distinct regions, each called kingdoms, each with its
own                               ruler. Gwalter ap Dagda ruled only one region,
Enwys, directly; in the other region, named
Croisrath, there was a lesser ruler (without the “ap
Dagda” title), named King Verurteilt, who ruled in
the Dagda’s name and who was succeeded by his wife
as queen regent, the Duchess Sibyl of Crossroads.

Each king has the right to call upon the men and
women                                of his kingdom for war, and they
occasionally war with each other, but Gwalter has the
right to command each warrior of Maedoen
individually and so can end wars when necessary.

Important Entities

The Guardians’ Guild

The Guardians’ Guild is an association of
swashbucklers                               and explorers. Members are usually
independent adventurers and treasure hunters, often
viewed as mischief-makers outside of their nerve
center, the town of Crossroads. Sworn members have
access to superior equipment and training and a far-
reaching network of potential allies across Maedoen
and Psarmorum. In return, the Guardians tithe a part
of their earnings back to the Guild’s leadership,
whose mission is to gather treasure and knowledge
to eradicate evil.

The Guild is charged with preventing the evils of
the                             forest, unsettled lands, or equinox gates from
entering their realm of Croisrath and especially with
stopping threats from crossing over into the
Kingdom of Enwys, where Gwalter ap Dagda, high
king of Maedoen, sits upon the throne of Grimsete.

But despite that charge and in full knowledge of the
war between Maedoen and Psarmorum, the guild
often partners with the State of Psarmorum against

asylum so long as they do not raise a sword against
any                        Maedoen native.

The Black Standard

Eons ago, the nation of Maedoen (then a fractious
and                             warring land known by a hundred different
names) became the chosen victim of an unknown
force. Armies of terrible fiends swarmed out of the
oceans on all sides onto the peninsula. Though
vaguely human in shape, these monsters were
always pale white and malformed in numerous ways
that marked their ranks or types. The shee named
them the cythraul, and the shee were afraid.

Their first ferocious assault took the people of the
land                               by surprise. The cythraul scythed through rank
after rank of each petty king’s armsmen, using
weapons, claws and mind-rending spells. Worse,
they also took prisoners. Men and women taken by
the devil creatures could be heard for miles,
screaming, begging, pleading, and making less
recognizable sounds until they stopped. Children
stolen fared worse. Early in the onslaught, the
warlords’ fortresses would open their gates to what
appeared to be small bands of children who claimed
to be refugees escaping death. Blood and terror soon
taught those who survived otherwise, and the child-
things dissembled less and ravened more as the war
wore on.

Despite the horrifying tales carried from the sea by
rivers of refugees, the hundred kings of early
Maedoen did not put aside their personal feuds.

Perhaps the refugees were not convincing, or the
kings                              had no ears for words that didn’t please them.
Who can know? But the land’s many lords paid little
heed to the cythraul sweeping in from the shores,
until much later when the whole of the north (now
Dalmavand) was overrun.

288


Without walls to shield them from the hell
Maedoen                                was becoming, the people could not ignore
the threat. Ruled by kings who would do nothing, the
people decided to defend themselves. The first to
raise a banner was an old farmer who had once
served as an armsman. His banner was black and
plain because it was the only large and sturdy cloth
he owned, but the word that soon spread was of black
against the cythraul’s white faces, and plain against
the creatures’ multifarious bodies. The black banner
and unnamed farmer drew a surprisingly large army
unaffiliated with kings. Men, women, and sometimes
children volunteered, and all were accepted. Most
rulers denounced the force as unlawful, and many
would have set their personal armies against it if
their soldiers had not refused or even defected to
follow the black banner themselves.

This was the turning point. Members of the Black
Standard,                                 as it came to be known, blunted the
spearhead of the invading fiends. Though they rarely
stood up to the cythraul in direct battle, they delayed
or deflected many attacks so that they fell upon
evacuated villages or well-defended fortresses. They
did not end the war — that happened when a group
of young women made a pact with the land’s shee,
planting the seed that would become Maedoen — but
they prolonged it until it could be ended.

In the earliest years after the war, a score or more
of                              the then-kings tried to outlaw the “dangerous
rabble.” They did not remain kings for long. And as
the hundreds of kings dwindled to ten, the Black
Standard forced the kings to accept their existence.
The kings swore that they and their successors, for
all time, would let the Black Standard cross their
lands freely, so long as the Black Standard did not
march against them.

None of the kings swore to give the Black Standard
a                             home. The roughshod army didn’t ask, because
they knew no home would be granted. An army not
under one’s control is a frightening thing to have
around, and armies consume much and produce
nothing (more like locusts than people, oftentimes).

289

As the threat dwindled, so did the army. Many of
the                             soldiers had family waiting, or farms and
livestock and old friends to see again, and so
departed. But some of the Black Standard kept
marching from one kingdom to the next, watching
and ready for threats that the kings would ignore.
And they found them. The core of the Black Standard
army that remains can call willing farmers and the
like to it when the need arises. Maybe there’s
something magical about the Black Standard; maybe
the spirit of the farmer who first decided to fight
walks with them as a rallying spirit, but whatever the
reason, shepherds and green boys all fight better
when they march under its banner.

Although one hundred kingdoms had coalesced
into                              two, Enwys and Croisrath, both regions were
ultimately ruled over by one king, Gwalter ap Dagda
of Enwys, with queen regent Sibyl ruling over
Crossroads.

The Black Standard is still unaffiliated with any
king                                 or lord. This has made most kings in recent
history more than a little nervous. They still do not
like it. Gwalter ap Dagda, in particular, considers the
existence of the Back Standard a slight on his ability
as the ruler and protector of Maedoen. He also sees it
as a black mark on the records of all kings who
preceded him, both because they could not rid
themselves of the Black Standard and because they
needed it.

Gwalter ap Dagda and Fergus the Black do not get
along;                             though Fergus keeps his nose out of politics,
as he believes the Black Standard should, Gwalter is
more than eager to find some way or reason to
disband the man’s army and absorb its soldiers into
his own armsmen. Fergus is a friend of the
Guardians’ Guild, and in fact, guild members march
with him, but he is not himself a member. His
allegiance is to his own.

The Black Standard is small right now. Fergus the
Black                               leads a band of barely more than five hundred,
small enough that none of the provincial rulers of
Maedoen worry about him. Only Gwalter ap Dagda


AINERÊVE


has concerns, and Fergus pays the great king little
mind.                           Centuries and centuries of tradition stand
between Gwalter and Fergus clashing unless one
were to directly attack the other’s men. Fergus would
never be so stupid as to start such an altercation,
even if he had the slightest inclination, which he
doesn’t.

Fergus knows that the Black Standard is
undermanned                               and could stand against very few
important threats but is not worried about this. He
had reasons to let the Black Standard’s ranks
diminish. First, a farmer away from home needs
someone to farm for him — he consumes but does
not produce. By dismissing soldiers, Fergus allowed
more food and goods to be produced. Second, a
soldier needs to eat. Since the Black Standard is
forbidden to settle in any kingdom, it is always on
the move (if not always quickly), and a moving army
quickly drains resources. A smaller company puts
significantly less strain on the villages it passes
through. Third and last, a smaller Black Standard
puts the rulers at ease, making it easier for the
company to scout out dangers as Fergus likes and
otherwise get along without difficulty.

Gathering extra soldiers only as required is part of
Fergus the Black’s strategy. The men of the many
companies he disbanded when he was elected to the
command are now farming, fishing, or smithing, but
they still know how to soldier. And Fergus has
recruited more farmers and farmers’ sons, who have
promised, some eagerly, to come if called. He can
send out twenty fast riders within ten minutes and
have a sizeable and suitable army marching to meet
him as quickly as any king could gather his troops.

Fergus doesn’t know what he might encounter, but
he’s ready. He hopes.

Still, the commander sometimes worries that he
may                          discover a tremendous threat to the kingdom
that will devastate the Black Standard before he can
gather its full strength.

Fergus the Black. Occupation: Commander of the
Black Standard. Human male. Competence d6 → 

Adroitness d6 + Expertise d10 + Perception d4.
Prowess                               d12 → Precision d12 + Melee d12. Fortitude
d12 → Endurance d12. SP (Spirit Points): 6, Active DP:
24, Passive DP: 24. Armor: d12+2 special and Shield
d6 (see below).

Equipment: Fergus the Black wields a massive
oversized                          greatsword (Pionós an Bháis, meaning
death sentence). The weapon is so large it requires a
Fortitude → Strength roll over 2 simply to lift it, and
a roll of 4 or better every round to wield it (although
Fergus need not roll). The sword adds +5 threat
points. Its size means damage can be carried over
from a primary target if additional targets are in the
path of the swing, stopping only when all threat
points are used up or there are no more targets in
range! He carries a round, magic shield (d6 with
active defense) that shines with a deep, dark hue,
nearly black as night. His ebony armor is padded
with heavy fur that offers a layer of protection even
in the gaps normal in armor. The heavy padding and
thick armor convey astounding protection from
physical and elemental harm (d12+2 vs. both regular
attacks and elemental attacks penetrating active
defense). Fergus rides astride his warhorse Eccher,
whose barding matches its rider’s armor.

Treasure: Fergus has access to thousands in coins
and                             gems, but much of it is used to pay for the
army’s needs. He usually carries 200–2000 worth in
valuables, with a 30% chance of 4 magic items
beyond those mentioned above.

Notes: Fergus the Black has access to many weapons
as                             leader of a powerful army but prefers large swords
and maces. He has no spells or other powers but
relies on his great physical strength and military
genius.

The Gan Creadigeath

The Gan Creadigeath is a matriarchal order of druids,
based                             out of the fortress temple of Cartrefol Cyfain,
who act as intermediaries between the humans and
shee of the forest of Meath with pacts forged
hundreds of years ago.

The only male associated with the order is
Nerthach,                                the Eldritch Man, whose role is one of
ambassador and symbolic of the treaties between
humans and creatures of faerie. The Gan Creadigeath

290


commands most aspects of Maedoens’ spiritual lives.
All                             women but for the Eldritch Man, they tell the
gods’ stories, soothe the fay when necessary, and
read the omens in chicken entrails and the flights of
birds. It is the Gan Creadigeath who say when the
gods have blessed the planting, and when it is
fortunate to remove tons of copper and tin from the
mountains that bear them. Their influence is
ubiquitous in Maedoen.

A member of the Gan Creadigeath is usually called a
druid, or “sister Gan Creadigeath.” The wisest
woman in the order, decided by various tests, is
addressed as “mother” and guides the Gan
Creadigeath.

Sisters and mothers travel the length of Maedoen
annually                              to find new members. They visit each town
or village, even ones no more significant than a pair
of hovels by a spring, and examine all children
between the ages of four and nine. Those they find
acceptable, they claim for the Gan Creadigeath, often
to the dismay of their parents. A daughter lost to the
druids is one that cannot plant, weave, clean, or
marry to bind families.

A child the Gan Creadigeath wants looks fair —
somewhat pretty, if not of startling beauty. The child
is smart and insightful. Finally, the child has active
shee blood. The first two criteria test aspects related
to fairy ancestry, but a small magical examination
reveals if the third criterion is met. Many Maedoens
have some blood of the fay, having lived so close to
them for so long, but it often doesn’t express itself. A
child only needs a little active glamor in her blood to
be eligible, but it must be there or the girl cannot
treat with the shee on Maedoen’s behalf.

While such criteria are not shared with anyone
outside                               the order, some parents guess the first two.
They try to dirty up their girls when they know the
sisters are coming (which they rarely do), but do not
often go so far as to knock out teeth or bruise them.
They instruct them not to answer a druid’s questions
(asked privately) or to answer poorly, but the Gan
Creadigeath know how to tease real answers out of

291

children. After being chosen, a girl travels to the
Cartrefol                               gan Cyfain, where she receives her
education in what it means to serve the Maedoen and
the shee to keep both healthy and happy. The length
of education depends on the individual, but it is
typically between three and seven years. The order
does accept children as young as four, but their
training changes even the fastest students into
reserved, mysterious sisters by the time it is
complete. Even seven-year-old druids speak well
and with wisdom.

Cartrefol gan Cyfain

Often just called Cartrefol Cyfain, this low fortress
consists                            entirely of sloping earthworks covered with
grass and flowers, with thick, thorny bushes as
crenellations and massive trees serving as towers
and strong points. It is home to the Gan Creadigeath.
Resting in Maedoen’s east, it is near the spiritually
strong south and the mystical Forest of Meath. The
latter is most important, as the shee who live there
are less friendly toward Maedoens; they are not
bound by the ties between Maedoen and its native
creatures. From Cartrefol Cyfain, the sisters Gan
Creadigeath can present a unified front to the more
dangerous shee.

The natural-seeming fortress also serves as the
home                               and path for all girls and young women
training to become full members of the order. Until
they are ready to journey with a full-fledged sister,
they remain here and study the secret runes,
tongues, and spells of the Gan Creadigeath. Though
it is pleasing to the eye, Cartrefol Cyfain is a very
defensible position, especially when guarded by the
sisters and any allies they are able to call to their aid.

History proved the fortress’s strength over seventy
years                             ago, when Evan ap Dagda called all the armies
of Maedoen down on it in an effort to bend the Gan
Creadigeath to his will. When his siege was broken,
so was his rule, and it took three decades before the
ruler of Maedoen had regained the power that Evan
ap Dagda had lost. Druids outside of Maedoen often


AINERÊVE


have other regional names and titles that apply,
depending                           on whom addresses them or where they
grew up.

Mali, Mother of Gan Creadigeath

Mali. Occupation: Druid. Human female. Competence
d12 → Adroitness d8 + Expertise d10 (Spellcraft +5) +
Perception d8. Prowess d4 → Agility d6 + Melee d6 +
Precision d6. Fortitude d6 → Willpower d12. SP
(Spirit Points): 24, Active DP: 16 Passive DP: 6 (see
below). Armor: d6 (magic cloak).

Equipment: Mali uses a gnarled, magical, yew-wood
quarterstaff in battle. She can use the staff’s power
to fire a bolt of primordial energy for 3d12 harm,
manifesting as any of the five elements. It also
grants 10 points of DP. The staff is a permanent
magic item with 120 energy points. She also wears a
magic cloak given to her by the fay that adds 50
points to her Passive DP and acts as d6 armor.

Treasure: $500 on person, $1,000,000 in domicile at
Cartrefol Cyfain.

Notes: Mali is the current “Mother” of the Gan
Creadigeath,                           guiding them with a firm hand. She was
a rare prodigy, chosen by the traveling sisters at age
four and completing her training in Cartrefol Cyfain
by age seven. By the time she had completed her tour
of Maedoen, she had already allied with a dozen shee
and earned the respect of many of her sisters. Mali’s
ambition as the Mother is to achieve greater
integration between the human and shee
populations of Maedoen.

She believes that with their fundamental
cooperation,                               she could guide the nation to greater
wisdom. The unique perspectives of the shee would
inspire the more mundane inhabitants, while the
baser natures of the human Maedoens would ground
the shee in reality, teaching them to use their
fantastic skills for everyone’s spiritual gain.

Under Mother Mali’s direction, the druids of the
Gan                         Creadigeath have been making entreaties to the
shee courts. Although she considered involving
Gwalter ap Dagda, she correctly believes that he
would resent her intrusion into the realm of the

people’s everyday welfare. She knows many
Maedoens                              would not properly understand her goal,
which is why she is currently dealing mostly with the
shee. Mali is confident that if she can forge an
agreement with the shee of Maedoen and entice
them to intermingle with the human population, the
humans will not resist, or not for long.

Despite her ambitious vision, Mali does not neglect
her                              other duties. Sisters continue to travel Maedoen
in the long-established and complex patterns that
keep their arrival times unpredictable. They find and
bring new sisters to the Gan Creadigeath’s
stronghold, where the Mother and other sisters teach
them.

Mali directs many emissaries yearly to the various
shee                             courts in pursuit of common needs: subtle
spells recast, new wisdom revealed, exchanges of
goods, and secret aid given to various ailing towns
and villages. To her most trusted sisters, she assigns
the crucial task of carefully watching and herding the
Eldritch Man, ensuring he remains suitable for his
mission among the fairy folk. This task is vital, as
losing him would jeopardize their favor with the shee
and derail Mali’s greater plans.

However, Mali is acutely aware of the darker
undercurrents                          within her order. The Gan
Creadigeath's ascension was born from treachery
and bloodshed, orchestrated by Arianrhod and Mab,
and some within the order still harbor resentment
and misanthropic tendencies. Mali must constantly
balance her progressive vision with the lingering
shadows of the past, ensuring that the Gan
Creadigeath remains a force for good while
navigating the complexities of their history.

Nerthach, The Eldritch Man.
Hierophant.

Human (Shee Blood) Male. Competence: d10 →
Expertise                             d10 (Fairy Lore +5, Shee Courts +5) +
Knowledge d12 (Anthropology d10, History d12,
Religion d12). Prowess:** d8 → Precision d10 (Melee
Threat +5, Swords +5) + Ranged d10 (Bows d12).

Fortitude: d4 → Willpower d12 (Resistance d8,

292


Persuasion d10). SP (Spirit Points): [Variable,
considering                               his abilities and powers]. Active DP: 24
(Agility d8, Reflexes d10, Speed d6), 174 with magic
ring. Passive DP: 12 (Fortitude d6, Endurance d6), 112
with magic cloak. Armor: Magic ring of protection,
Magic cloak

Equipment: Druidic yew staff capable of producing
all                           Nature sphere spells. Short bow (+2 harm) with
magical sleep arrows. Magic quiver with 80 arrows.
Ring of protection (adds 150 points to Agility DP).
Magic cloak (adds 100 points to Fortitude DP).

Signature Spells: Mastery in all listed Invocation
(Nature)                           spells at D12. Staff with 240 energy points,
capable of stunning or incapacitating opponents
(3D10 per use). Specialized artifacts (ring and cloak)
that disintegrate if worn by anyone other than the
Eldritch Man.

Abilities and Powers: In sylvan areas, Invocation
abilities                        improve to D20 with an Active DP of 100, a
gift from the shee.

Treasure: Approximately $4000 in rare druidic
accouterments, jewelry, gems, and Maedoen
coinage.

Even among the Shee and Gan Creadighe,
Nerthach—the                            Eldritch Man—remains a mystery.
He personifies the universe’s essence, possessing
immense power that could alter reality itself. Linked
to both natural and mystical realms, he draws upon
fundamental energies, channeling ancient magic and
profound knowledge. Yet, he is unaware of the full
scope of his abilities—a power that, once awakened,
might lead to creation or destruction.

Nerthach’s deep connection to Cernunnos, the
ancient                              god of the wild, ties him to forces beyond the
Gan Creadighe’s comprehension. As an embodiment
of untamed nature and life’s endless cycles,
Cernunnos mirrors Nerthach’s universal essence.

This bond enables him to surpass the confines of the
Eldritch Realms, aligning with the core truths of
existence.

Additionally, Nerthach is linked to the Meterea, the
fundamental force behind both creation and
destruction, serving as a channel for the raw
energies that shape the universe. Within him, order

293

and chaos intertwine, illustrating his capacity for
benevolence or devastation. His existence represents
a fragile equilibrium that could be disrupted, causing
consequences felt across the realms.

The most insightful among the Shee—Brigit,
Arianrhod,                            Mab, and King Gwalter—are aware of
Nerthach’s true power. They conceal this knowledge,
dreading the turmoil that revelation might bring.

Recognizing that his abilities could be exploited to
unsettle                                the world, figures like Symon and Magister-
Espirit also keep this secret, understanding the risks
of such power in the wrong hands.

The implications of Nerthach’s awakening are
enormous.                                His anger over past manipulations could
unleash chaotic forces and dark magic, altering the
landscape and endangering countless lives. The
delicate harmony between the Shee and humans
might collapse, igniting a war that engulfs the
realms. If he rejects his destiny, it could fracture the
Gan Creadighe, leading to unforeseen outcomes.

Yet, an alternative path exists. Guided wisely,
Nerthach                              could use his power for good—mending
the divide between the Shee and humans, restoring
balance, and revitalizing the land itself. His journey
depends on those around him, with the Game Master
steering his awakening, should it occur. The choices
and challenges faced by the players will significantly
influence whether Nerthach becomes a source of
destruction or a beacon of hope, ultimately shaping
the fate of the Eldritch Realms.

Mali, a perceptive member of the Gan Creadighe,
senses                             that Nerthach is more than he appears. Her
instincts hint at his connection to something
predating the order itself. While she doesn’t fully
grasp his ties to Cernunnos (and the Meterea), she
notices the signs. Her guidance could be crucial as
Nerthach begins to realize the extent of his abilities.

Nerthach’s links to Cernunnos and the Meterea
underscore                           the interaction between order and
wildness, the familiar and the unknown. Despite his
involvement with these cosmic forces, his true
strength lies in this fundamental bond, illustrating


AINERÊVE


that genuine wisdom comes from embracing all
facets of existence.

Noteworthy Places

An ancient land, Maedoen has many places known
across                              the nation.

Anluan Sanctuary: Near the southern edge of the
Elden                           Heights or by Lac Miroir, known for peace and
healing

Banríonau: The Regency of Banríonau is a land of
Celtic                               and Nordic influences, forged by the
convergence of those cultures, across a diverse
landscape of majestic mountains, founded by a
visionary leader from Dalmavand and established
with the blessing of King Gwalter, now led by the
wise and strong regent Lady Brynhildr Járncridhe,
who carries on her father's legacy, guiding the realm
with reverence for the Tuatha Dé Danann and the
harmonious fusion of Celtic and Norse heritage,
where the proud and independent people are known
for their exceptional craftsmanship and vibrant
bardic tradition.

Bru Na Bard Bridge: In central Maedoen, a legendary
bridge                         echoing the history and songs of the realm.

Coilltean Fánaí: West of Kaariloft in northwestern
Maedoen,                          stands defiant - a verdant barrier against
the encroaching shadows that linger along the
foreboding Dragonlord Mountains. This mystic
realm where the arcane energies of the feywild bleed
into the mortal world is protected by the satyr
guardian Muirecán.

Dunvalder: In northern Maedoen, renowned for its
skilled craftsmanship, thriving on trade routes.

Eochaid’s Hearth: Potentially in Banríonau Nau or
Dunvalder, a famous inn.

Fortress Draugrheim: In the northeastern reaches of
Maedoen, this fortress guards a crucial crossroads,
standing firm against encroaching threats.

Glenndanach: In southwestern Maedoen, a city of
wisdom influenced by Psarmorum’s scholars and
elemental knowledge.

Kaariloft: Kaariloft, located in the northwest of
Maedoen,                                is a town with a rich yet troubled history.
Once, humans, dwarves, and elves collaborated here,
bringing prosperity through the renowned Soul
Forge, powered by croslamite crystals extracted from
nearby Coille Creige. This era ended when Frode and
his Quasidead cultists, followers of Nigma, destroyed
the town in their obsession with immortality. Over
decades, Kaariloft was rebuilt, largely due to the
efforts of the heroes Sage and Atril. However, the
town’s past lingers; Nigma’s followers remain,
unsettling its peace. Today, Kaariloft stands as a
symbol of resilience, attracting scholars and
adventurers intrigued by its history and the
remnants of its magic.

Olafort: This squat, sprawling fortress lies several
miles                              from the effective border between Maedoen
and the Forest of Meath. It is less than two hundred
years old, a rare thing in the old land of Maedoen.
Olafort is the easternmost defensive construction for
the country, built and manned by the unrescinded
order of an earlier king. The soldiers there are ever
watchful for invasion from Psarmorum (and, less so,
for the incursion of Meath’s shee), against which
they are the first line of defense.

So far, the fort has fallen twice, but each time it has
held                                 off the Templar Knights until reinforcements
could push them back through the forest. Olafort has
enough financial and political support from Gwalter
ap Dagda that its commander has actually managed
successful raids through Meath into Psarmorum. The
smaller size of the Maedoen raiding parties lets them
avoid the similar encampment on the Psarmorum
side.

Sechdraic Valley: This valley distinguishes itself
from                              the majority of Maedoen's temperate, wooded
areas with its undulating hills and pronounced
geothermal activity. The valley's erratic behavior

294


causes ground quakes and landscape alterations,
where                            geysers erupt, projecting clouds of steam into
the sky. Warm, steaming waterfalls cascade over the
hillsides. Legends speak of dragons sleeping beneath
the earth, purported to be the source of the heat. At
times, the valley resonates with the faint sound of
ancient chanting.

Within this valley lies the Sanctuary of Cernunnos,
a                             unique Volitional Demiplane in Maedoen. It is a
hidden oasis of greenery, created by Eochaid, a
demi-god and devoted son of Cernunnos. Eochaid's
realm is a lush and mysterious land teeming with
rare wildlife. His fury over Cernunnos's banishment

has given rise to fiery geothermal activity outside the
sanctuary, fueling rumors of legendary dragons.

Eochaid, born from the union of the wild god and a
mortal woman, shared a unique bond with nature
and harnessed ancestral magic to reshape the land.
His world was shattered by the banishment of his
father through the machinations of Mab, Titania,
and Arinhod. In response, Eochaid established a
lasting tribute to Cernunnos, carving a sanctuary in
the heart of the Sechdraic Valley as a refuge for the
surviving druids.

The Sisters Gan Creadigeath, followers of Brigit and
The Morrigan, view Eochaid and his realm with
caution, concerned that Cernunnos's return would
disrupt their established order and lessen their
influence. Yet, Eochaid's power is linked to the
Sanctuary, affording him immense control but also
binding him to it. The Sanctuary's existence hinges
on Eochaid's continued presence and willpower. His
departure could lead to its destabilization or
vulnerability to external threats. Recognizing the
importance of his connection to the Sanctuary,
Eochaid is aware that leaving it could jeopardize all
that he has built and safeguarded.

Yr Gwethva: Also called the White Graves; these are
the                             three highest mountains in Maedoen, quite near
each other in the peninsula’s southeast. The circular
valley they create between them is one of the

traditional burial grounds of the Maedoen kings. By
this                              point in the nation’s history, over three hundred
different sons of the Dagda are buried there. Each
one has its own burial mound of two to five
chambers, containing the body lying in state,
treasured possessions, and occasionally favored pets.
In some cases, minor shee watch over a tomb to
protect it, or to attract robbers to it out of mischief.

The hidden fortress of Annwn is somewhere within
the                           White Graves, guarding the threshold of
Neogrange, home of the Tuatha de Danann.

Adventure Hooks

There are many quests to be had in Maedoen; just
look                               at ancient Welsh legends for inspiration. But
here are a few ideas.

Escaping Providence: The Eldritch Man has
disappeared,                           and all of the Gan Creadigeath are
searching for him. Why has he left, and where is he
going?

The Eldritch Man has figured out that he’s more of
a                             prisoner than anything else, a toy for the shee, and
he’s decided not to take it any longer. En route from
one shee glen to another fairy court, he stepped off
the path and disappeared into Maedoen. The spells
and secrets he learned over his years in the many
shee courts now serve to keep him hidden. If nobody
finds him, the shee will break off with Maedoen, the
king will lose the Dagda’s blessing, and Maedoen will
descend into chaos. With Psarmorum waiting like
jackals, that can’t be allowed. The players’
characters are the ones who find the Eldritch Man,
whether they were seeking him or not. Stuck
between his misery and refusal to go back (willingly,
at least) and the great potential harm for the entire
nation, the heroes have some thinking to do. Do they
return him to the Gan Creadigeath and the shee, help
him escape, or go about forging a new pact with the
shee that keeps Maedoen together?

Or maybe the Eldritch Man’s disappearance is an
inspired bit of foreign sabotage. When their spies

295


AINERÊVE


figure out that it is the Eldritch Man upon whom
Maedoen’s                            treaty with its native shee depends,
Psarmorum attempts to destroy its enemies from
within. A small squad of stealthy commandos enter
Maedoen and track down the Eldritch Man, then
kidnap him. It is up to the heroes to rescue him
before the Knights Templar escape with him behind
their battle lines, or before the shee decide the pact is
completely broken.

For a situation with more ambiguity, the men from
Psarmorum did not kidnap him. They pulled the wool
from his eyes, helping him see that he’s more of a
prisoner than a diplomat. Now, they’re helping him
escape, and he is their willing ward. Can the heroes
return the Eldritch Man when he does not want to
go?

Missing Soldiers: A small unit of Gwalter ap Dagda’s
soldiers,                               about fifty strong, has disappeared
completely. They left one guardpost but never
reported to the next while traveling through a lesser
king’s kingdom. Gwalter is not one to suffer such an
affront, and if the disappearance isn’t resolved
before he hears of it, the great king is likely to ruin
anyone he considers responsible. What’s more, the
Black Standard passed through the same area around
the same time, and Gwalter would love an
opportunity to blame them and have them disbanded
permanently. Either the local king or Fergus want to
get to bottom of the disappearance, and the players’
characters are there to help. The simplest option is
that they encountered a band of monsters or
unfriendly shee, which was the end of that. The
heroes either need to prove it somehow, or find and
rescue any surviving unit members for eyewitnesses.

More complicated, the soldiers deserted. As a unit,
they                            decided to flee the military and try to disappear.
When they passed through the territory of a king
Gwalter doesn’t trust and the Black Standard came
by, they saw an opportunity and took it. Letting the
politics of the situation cover their tracks, they got
out of there as quickly as possible. Heroes can track
them by asking the right questions in nearby

villages, where a suspicious number of men may
have                               come through to pick up supplies, or by finding
a hillside shepherd who saw the soldiers disperse. Or
the soldiers may have deserted to join the Black
Standard. Knowing that Gwalter would be furious but
unable to turn away men who want to serve, Fergus
requests the heroes’ help to confuse the issue and
perhaps direct suspicion onto the lesser king.

Return of the Druids: Not all druids of Cernunnos
were                            destroyed by Arianrhod’s treachery (see
Equinox Gates). Many perished in the unsettled
wastes beyond space and time, but the strongest
survived, and became heirophants with powers and
perspectives far exceeding those of mortal men. At
some convenient equinox, these patriarchs of the
ancient order will exit the Equinox Gates in style,
wreathed in power, and fully apprised of current
affairs by Cernunnos. Their most powerful members,
currently unable to leave the They can, amongst
other things, snuff out any spell used by a mortal
with a simple opposed roll (vs 1d12).

They could completely overturn the current order,
but                                do not wish to damage Maedoen overmuch. They
can still cause as much turmoil and NPC
consternation as the GM desires. Most likely they
will seek their natural allies, Gwalter ap Dagda, the
Guardians Guild, and the Eldritch Man (who is of the
blood of Cernunnos), and gradually try to return
spiritual life and mankind to what they were. Their
attitudes towards the “silly little girls” of the Gan
Creadigeath and suchlike are very old-fashioned.

They do not trust females, and will definitely wish
to                             train more male human druids — perhaps such
PCs could be their harbingers, trainees of
Cernunnos’ emissaries in Meath. The heroes could
aid them, oppose them, try to broker a compromise
between parties, or take advantage of the ferment
they cause in some way.

296


Grimsete

Description: Grimsete is Maedoen’s only city. It is
also                             home to the king, Gwalter ap Dagda, and serves
as the nation’s capital. It is here that Gwalter holds
court, houses his close family and advisors, and
garrisons his personal armsmen. From the walls of
Grimsete Castle, Gwalter’s edicts guide all
Maedoens, especially in the war against Psarmorum
that he inherited from his father, his father before
him, and so on back two hundred years.

The people of Grimsete are used to war. Ancient
kings                           built the castle, in times forgotten, to help
guard the coast against coastal raids, and it serves
that purpose still.

The people of Grimsete are used to war. Ancient
kings                               built the castle, in times forgotten, as a secure
central redoubt to house forces against coastal raids,
and it serves that purpose still. Homing pigeons
carry warnings from coastal watchtowers to the
castle, and troops are deployed where needed, via
swift horses on good roads. The horned demons have
not stopped raiding, so the soldiers of Grimsete have
not stopped fighting them. But in the period since,
nearly twenty thousand Maedoens have come to live
in the city, once ramshackle but now strong and
stone, outside the castle. The city has its own wall,
and even more live outside it, tending the many
hundreds of acres of planted crops and livestock.

Local Pantheon: The people of Grimsete primarily
worship                              the Dagda, the chief deity of Maedoen, who
embodies life, death, agriculture, and druidry. The
Dagda is often associated with oak trees, symbols of
strength, wisdom, and endurance, and his followers
believe that the oak tree is a conduit to the
Otherworld. A small order of druids, known as the
Order of the Sacred Oak, resides within Grimsete
Castle, serving as advisors and spiritual guides to
King Gwalter ap Dagda. Unlike the old, banished
order of Cernunnos, this order includes both men
and women and is tolerated by the Gan Creadigeath.
Their rituals and ceremonies focus on maintaining

the king's connection to the Dagda's lineage, the
land, and the Shee, ensuring the prosperity and
protection of the kingdom.

In addition to the Dagda, the people of Grimsete
also                          acknowledge Licha, a Shee countess who dwells
beneath the castle. Licha, while not a deity, is seen as
a guardian spirit of the castle and is offered tributes
and respect by the king and his subjects. She
demands little other than occasional company,
tastes of all foods prepared for the king to detect
poisons, and brief moments alone with condemned
men before their execution. Licha enjoys the
company, the food, and sustains herself on the
criminals' fear of death.

Population: Heavy. Grimsete is the only place in
Maedoen                            with this many people in this small a place.
Anywhere else, the population is going to be
moderate at most.

Economy: A bastion of war, Grimsete has great need
of                           weapons. It can buy iron, copper, and tin ore to
forge its own, if necessary, because the castle has a
foundry in its depths and there are many
metalworkers in the city. It is easier for the garrison
to purchase weapons, as smiths are often busy
repairing weapons or dealing with other projects.

Home to many people, Grimsete is too large to
sustain                              itself on locally produced foodstuffs, and the
city needs to import 15–25% of its comestibles each
year.

Gwalter ap Dagda. Occupation: King. Human male.
Competence d10 → Expertise d10 + Perception d4.
Prowess d10 → Agility 4 + Melee d10 + Precision d8.
Fortitude d8 → Willpower d6. SP (Spirit Points): 16,
Active DP: 24, Passive DP: 8. Armor: d10 (plate).

Equipment: Gwalter possesses all manner of
exquisite                         weapons, certainly the finest of any
weapon mastered. He carries a magic greatsword
called Táethen, an item of fay make, +5 threat
points, which upon command directs 2d20 of
eldritch fire (physical harm) in a searing arc
following his swing toward any foe within 40 feet.

297


AINERÊVE


Treasure: $6000 on person, and $2,000,000 in
domicile.

Noteworthy Places

As one of the largest cities in Maedoen, Grimsete
certainly                             has a few tourist attractions.

Grimsete Castle: The castle that started it all stands
tall                                over the rest of the city. Situated advantageously
on a low hill above Grimsete itself, the castle’s three
towers are strong and its wall is thick. Rumors that
the castle was built on a shee mound are wrong
(Licha came to live in the castle of her own accord),
but it does have strange qualities. Viewed from
above, the pattern of the castle’s interior and
exterior walls form something very like a Celtic knot,
which lends resilience to Grimsete Castle’s defenses,
subtle strength to its men, and mystical power to
druidic enchantments cast within. The second
mystery is that of the castle’s founders. The name is
written clearly at the gate and in the grand hall for all
to see, but it is foreign to the local tongues. Even the
druids have not been able to decipher its origin. In
truth, visitors who came long ago from a distant
land, in peace instead of war, designed Grimsete
Castle and laid its first stones. Its magic is of their
invention, and they left as peacefully as they came.

Adweth Hill: Gently sloping and covered with lush
grass,                              but just taller than a man from its base to its
peak, Adweth Hill is exactly one mile south of
Grimsete’s southernmost point. It has always been
so, since there was nothing more than a castle and
despite the many years of Grimsete’s slow
expansion. This is one of its magical properties. Few
notice, because it’s hard to notice something that
moves so slowly, and the memory plays tricks to
make it seem normal.

Adweth Hill is a very comfortable place for a picnic
or                               an outdoor lesson. The springy grass makes a
natural cushion, and the slight trees on the hill
provide cooling shade. Despite being a popular place
to visit, it is never crowded. Adweth Hill subtly

directs those approaching it to an unoccupied spot or
grove; if there is no good place vacant on the hill,
people just find themselves going elsewhere on their
walk. They never notice. One going just to see the
hill, not to occupy a place, never has any trouble
getting there.

There are also a few noticeable peculiarities about
Adweth                                 Hill that make the local populace think of it
as something special. Whenever there is a storm, one
and only one lightning bolt strikes the hill. There is
never any evidence of the strike afterward. People
who sleep on the hill all dream of the same thing:
themselves, onboard a vast ship of silvery-blue
wood, sailing into a storm. No one knows what it
means. Despite these strange qualities, the Gan
Creadigeath has not forbidden going to the hill, or
even mentioned it, so the people of Grimsete feel
confident in visiting it. In fact, the oldest treaties
between the Gan Creadigeath and the shee states that
no law, rule, pact, or treaty may address Adweth Hill.
The Gan Creadigeath cannot warn people away from
it without breaching the old agreements. The reason
for the shee’s stipulation is that Adweth Hill is where
the shee of Maedoen must gather for their foretold
mass exodus to their homeland. When they return to
the land of the fairy from the hill, life in Maedoen
will change immensely.

Vendors and Dealers

In a city the size of Grimsete, there’s a buyer for
almost any prize.

Porreth Bazaare: A few minutes’ walk from the city’s
northeastern gate, the stone buildings open away
from the street to reveal a wide, cobblestone plaza
over half a mile across. Hundreds of large booths and
small stands spread out before visitors to the city,
and scores of dancers, jugglers, barkers, other
entertainers, and salesmen compete with each other.
There are people there whose sole tasks are to
welcome travelers to Porreth Bazaar, where anything
and everything can be bought or sold. Many

298


hundreds of merchants and traders come to Porreth
Bazaar                               to pick up new merchandise or divest
themselves of their wares. There is almost always an
interested buyer, no matter how common or rare the
item in question, and only the most completely
worthless things go unsold. Nothing but cold-
wrought iron is illegal here (and even that can be
part of an under-the-table exchange). The criers
who welcome people to the bazaar call to them to
leave their cold iron behind; booths at the bazaar’s
border keep items for people until they return with
the claim ticket.

The reason for the restriction on cold iron goods is
that one-tenth of the fair’s grounds, that in the very
center, is given over at all times to the shee. The
beautiful, taffeta-and-velvet tents there are not
always occupied, but there are strange trades to be
made when they are. Some fairy folk happily
exchange solely normal goods, trading bales of
cotton for bronze blades and shields, and there is
always at least one such among the shee crowd.

Where the goods they trade come from is a happy
mystery                              to most who receive them. Others exchange
something exotic for something normal. In one
direction, a mortal might trade the memory of a
beating for a collection of fine carving woods; in the
other, one might give an expertly-made metal
puzzle for the ability to control one’s dreams.

Finally, some of the shee deal only in the strange and
magical. These are the ones who can give you a new
face in exchange for your true love, or a mighty
enchanted sword for a firstborn child.

Surrounding Porreth Bazaar are many large
warehouses                             where merchants carrying stock in bulk
can stow goods until they sell them. The warehouses
offer another function as well as space: providing
exchange tokens. When a set of goods is registered,
the warehouse factor verifies what is to be sold with
a series of tokens. These are generally about the size
of a palm, cut from wood, and painted to represent
common lots of trade goods, like bales of hay, large
quantities of foods, weapons, and so on. Marked with

the trader’s name or sigil, they can be taken into the
fair                               and sold, whereupon the buyer can bring the
tokens to the warehouse to claim his purchases.

The king in Grimsete also uses the warehouses to
calculate                               taxes. There are few alternatives to
dropping one’s goods off there, and limited storage
room in the bazaar itself, so the warehouse factors
record the goods and declare a tax on behalf of the
king. Some factors are corrupt, some are fair, some
lax, and careful merchants make sure they know the
factors they deal with. Most smaller goods go
untaxed in Porreth Bazaar, despite the law that
anything sold for a certain amount or more be
reported. Just in case, the king has shrewd agents
who wander the stalls, keeping their eyes peeled for
anything that the king would want to know was
being traded in Grimsete. Sometimes such objects
are confiscated, sometimes confiscated with
compensation, sometimes they are taxed, and
sometimes they are ignored. Not that it’s too difficult
to trade without attracting any attention, which is

299


AINERÊVE


the preferred option for grave robbers, thieves, and
other “treasure hunters.”

Argoel Artaith: Argoel is an ancient witch. Her age
and                          provenance are unknown, but her tinted skin
and her strange magic mark her as foreign to
Maedoen. Sisters Gan Creadigeath used to visit her
often to inquire about her methods, but she rebuffed
them all and now they keep away. People whisper
that she came from a far land and took a new
Maedoen name, and they are right. But she never
speaks of her past.

The witch makes and sells potions, tinctures,
salves,                           ointments, and other mixtures, all with
special properties. Many of them are simply for
healing, but they work surprisingly well and
sometimes even leave no scars. Some of her oils do
other things, like speeding plants’ growth,
strengthening woods or metals, or bursting into
flame when opened. Argoel Artaith is constantly
ordering myriad exotic ingredients for her
concoctions, including quicksilver, gold, silver,
cinnabar, and many rare herbs. She pays well for
them, and never seems short of coin or barter goods.

Guilds and Training

The Armsmen of the King: There are not many guilds
in                           Grimsete. Gwalter’s armsmen are closest to a
group of guildsmen or people offering weapons
training. One may join them with a simple oath of
loyal service to the king, at which point one is
expected to live with them, sup with them, and train
with them. It is an occupation, not just a club.

Without joining for life, a warrior can train with
them                                for a small bit of coin. They may be loyal to
their king, but he’s never told them not to spar save
with brother armsmen. So it isn’t hard to learn a
little sword or spearwork from the king’s skilled
men, but going for lessons every day of the week will
see the armsmen urging a warrior, especially a
skilled one, to join them. After all, the pay is decent,
the food is okay, the lodging is certain, and one more

person in the ranks means a greater chance of
leaving the next war alive.

Adventure Hooks

Here are a couple of possible adventures in Grimsete.

Rebellion: Two would-be lesser kings, acting
together,                              have surprised Gwalter ap Dagda and
besieged Grimsete and the castle while the bulk of
his armsmen deal with an incursion by horned
demons many miles north. The warlords have
refused to obey Gwalter’s commands despite his
right of rule. Together, their armies outnumber the
remaining men Gwalter can field from his local
garrison, and he hasn’t been able to get the word out
to his forces elsewhere or his still-loyal kings.

Gwalter is a fierce warrior and a skilled tactician, but
even he can’t beat a force four times his size, one
that also has the advantage of preparation. Gwalter
needs some help, which is where the players’
characters come in.

Most simply, they can slip or break through the
siege                               lines to bring word from Gwalter to some of his
manned outposts. Alerting enough soldiers means
that the two kings trying to depose Gwalter will end
up trapped between a new army and the hard walls of
Grimsete. More directly, the heroes could seek out
and kill or kidnap the two rebelling kings. Gwalter
would prefer to have them alive, because it would be
more politically advantageous to defeat and chastise
the kings than to kill them and be replaced by
revenge-minded sons. Still, either action will end the
siege.

The heroes could also supplement Gwalter’s army
with                          diplomacy or creative warfare. The shee in
Porreth Bazaar may be willing to sell military aid for
some price, who really knows? And the potions of
Argoel Artaith could do interesting things to a
besieging army, especially when catapulted on top of
them en masse.

Theft: Something of value has been stolen from
Grimsete Castle, and it’s time to catch the thief.

300


Emlyn Steward is certain that the criminal did not
have                              time to leave the city before he shut the gates
and stopped letting anyone in or out, and that there
was no other way out of the castle. Tension is
running high in Grimsete, especially as traveling
merchants lose money, people are getting hungrier,
and no one even knows what’s disappeared. If the
players’ characters want to leave, they’ll have to
sneak past all the king’s guards (and the two small
armies that have since settled in outside the walls, if
you want to combine this with the first scenario), or
find the thief.

But what’s been stolen? It could be something as
straightforward as a great treasure. Perhaps it’s the
Heart of Grimsete, something Gwalter would
certainly want back, and he wouldn’t want any more
people than necessary to know it was missing. On the
other hand, the stolen object might be a private
message from Gwalter, giving away the king’s
intention to do away with the lesser kings or weaken
the Gan Creadigeath, neither something he would
want his targets to find out.

Psarmorum

Psarmorum is home to racial and religious purists
descended                            from the Templars and pilgrims. They
derive their magical strength from their
unrecognized demon blood and worship Sol Invictus,
whom they call the Lord and the one true god, but
who is actually a powerful demon, Baphomet. The
government is headed by the Grand Master and
strongly influenced by the politically powerful Order
of Knights, the Bishop, and other noblemen and
religious figures.

Geography

Geographically, Psarmorum is bounded on the west
by                              the Orllewin Sea. This is the Maedoen name,
which the Psarmorum settlers eventually adopted,
having originally named it after an ocean of Earth.
The nation is structured much as France is, with

coastal plains giving way to hilly forests and
mountainous                            terrain in the south and southeast,
although none of the landmarks are specific analogs
to those on Earth. Between the plains and the forests,
the center is a small desert area with several small,
fertile valleys. There, the first settlers of the area
found an abandoned city that reminded them of their
destination: today, it is the site of the new Temple
Mount.

As one travels farther south or north, the land
becomes                               less settled and more dangerous. There are
strange, ungodly things; monsters and abominations
that hunger for the flesh or dreams of man. Ships
that sail too far out to sea, beyond the small and
desolate islands off the nation’s coasts, do not
return. The Istigh Sea is unnavigable because of
maelstroms and monsters.

Only to the west do the settled lands continue, and
then                               they become significantly dangerous. Along the
northern half of the nation’s western border is the
Forest of Meath, where demons and angels dwell.

The uneducated believe that the forest is a gateway
on                              Earth to both Heaven and Hell. Wiser heads know
that it is a place of frightening magic, which serves
as a passage to the heathen nation of Meath, and
contains gateways to Heaven and Hell.

Strange nomads dwell beyond the nation’s borders,
on                               the edge of the unsettled lands, or beyond. Often,
they are not quite human. Many of them have
strange eyes, hair, or skin; usually, a unique tribal
trait. These tribes are universally heathens in the
Templars’ eyes. The people of Psarmorum and these
barbarians often war. They are one reason why the
Templar Knights and their armies, much larger than
those of Maedoen, have not crushed their Celtic
enemies.

History

The generally known history of Psarmorum is soon
told.                                A large band of Templar Knights, including
members of all ranks, protecting a group of several

301


AINERÊVE


thousand on a long pilgrimage from France to
Jerusalem,                           somehow found themselves in a new and
different land instead. Separated from the world they
knew and with no way back, the knights organized
the “immigrants” to ensure survival. That began the
pattern of government by the Poor Knights of the
Faith that continues to this day. The Knights claimed
the new land for civilization, named a Master
Templar of the region and a provisional bishop
(pending approval by the Pope), and went about
making the land livable.

After a century or two of defending themselves
against                               the nightmares of Ainerêve (records are
vague), the Templar Knights named the land with
some forgotten Latin tag as a sign of pieType: this
name soon was shortened Psarmorum. They raised
their master to Grandmaster and decided the Pope’s
approval was implicit, accepting that their
separation from France and Rome was permanent.
The nation flourished, growing mighty in battle and
strong in faith; its priests working miracles and its
leaders advised by angels. So far, the war of two
hundred years with Maedoen is just a grace note on
the nation’s already long history.

The nation’s secret histories, recorded only within
the                           Temple Mount vaults, are not so simple. The
outer circle of Psarmorum’s elite — low-ranking
Templars, nobles, ecclesiastics, those holding office

— know more of the nation’s early years. Angels and
archangels of the Lord came to the knights and
pilgrims lost in a strange land, offering blessings,
aid, and guidance in founding a new nation and
renewed church in Ainerêve. As part of this aid, these
celestials shared their essence and nature with the
Templars, imbuing them and their children with the
heavenly strength and righteous power needed to
combat the strange enemies that assailed them. The
first generation of half-angel children was called the
Nephilim; the angels trained them to be guardians of
the realm. Legend has it that they still live and patrol
the far reaches of the land, guarding it against
incursion.

The Church Celestial, whose colors of gold, red, and
white fly above Psarmorum’s cathedrals and armies,
was but a change of lineaments for the old church
since it made sense to use new names and forms of
worship for a fresh start in a new land. The holy
trinity of Sol, Luna, and Astra (sun, moon, stars) is
much as it ever was. Celestials (angels to the
unlettered) still confer their wisdom upon those of
high rank and may aid any station’s pious.

The inner circle of Psarmorum’s elite, the highest-
ranking                          Templars and nobles, know more of the
truth. The leaders of the original band of Knights
Templar secretly worshipped the demon Baphomet.
Knights adjudged worldly and wicked enough were
initiated into occult rites and promised wealth and
power. When the stars were right, the demon could
use the link magically forged by worship to summon
the Templars and the pilgrims they escorted from
Earth to Ainerêve. It was not angels who came to the
aid of the pilgrimage, but Baphomet’s vassal demons
in heavenly guise, who granted the power to survive.
Today, the blood of demons flows, to lesser or
greater degrees, in the veins of all Psarmorum’s
nobility, kept strong by periodic reinfusion.

Since its beginning, the demons who started the
slow                             process of corruption have guided and shaped
Psarmorum through always plausible and wise-
seeming advice to the high and mighty. The Church,
too, has changed, and the faith is not what it was. It
was close at first, and there were genuine saints early
on whose relics now have power in this magical
world. The celestial imagery was a cloak, though, and
the change of names essential to Baphomet’s plan
since names have power.

Sol Invictus

Baphomet is the true ruler of Psarmorum, but
presents                            himself as Sol (Invictus), a pure,
implacable, and warlike god, whose other aspects
(Luna, Astra) deal with facets such as mercy and a
savior figure. Through his priests, Baphomet talks of
brotherhood, purity, and faith to harness those who

302


believe in such things to work for him. Over time,
relying                               on faulty human memory, he has magically
changed scripture to stress unquestioning
obedience, fierce piety, conformity, and intolerance
of mystical creatures, outsiders, or any that are lax in
devotion. Even so, redemptive aspects remain and
clues for the truly perceptive.

Baphomet, like many demons, sought power.
Unlike                                the rest, he had cunning and patience, kept
his bargains, and achieved it. He and his vassal
demons left Satan’s court in Hell when his plans
were ripe. With the aid of two other entities, he was
able to work the great magic that opened a major
revorage rift to bring the knights and pilgrims to
Ainerêve. In exchange, they gain some measure of
power via worship as Luna and Astra’s aspects in his
unholy trinity. (Luna is his consort, Lilith; Astra’s
identity is unknown.) To harness the full strength of
(demon-tainted) humanity over the long term,
Baphomet needed to have good and evil serve him
alike, so he had to maintain the illusion of
righteousness. His ‘celestials’ thus include disguised
demons and peris, recruited from the stable land of
Persian myth.

Peris are good, very attractive fay with magical
powers,                               long life, and mortals’ passions, who often
take winged form. They are happy to help deserving
souls in angelic ways, so Baphomet employs peris for
such lesser matters and to keep up appearances, and
at times to bolster troops’ morale when raiding
Maedoen. In return for their aid, he promised them
help in their eternal war with the cruel and ugly
deevs (Persian demons). Peris often need help from
mortal heroes in this struggle, and Baphomet
supplies them knights of great prowess who prove
not to be “morally flexible” enough for high rank. He
keeps serving peris out of his way in the Forest of
Meath, where they clash with other demons (all
deevs to them).

Baphomet now has a temporal and spiritual power
base                              in Psarmorum: a nation of fierce warriors
dedicated to him (in his persona as Sol Invictus),

with little of the fickleness of pure demons. What his
plans are, only he knows — world domination? True
godhood? Only the wisest of sages know enough to
speculate.

Baphomet’s success infuriated Satan and his
demons                             beyond measure, and they strive against
him and his people just as hard as they ever fought
against good. In turn, Baphomet makes sure that
Psarmorum’s rulers ruthlessly hunt down and
destroy those demons not in thrall to him, and those
people they “turn from the light.” This helps keep
the populace on their toes, suspicious, and in a state
of fear, and thus more easily controlled. And since
Church and State are “fighting the good fight”
against genuine servants of darkness, creatures of
the pit, and devil-worshippers, who could doubt
their essential virtue?

The People: People living in Psarmorum come in two
basic types: citizens and brothers. Brothers are those
who served in the army. They are typically accorded
more freedom and authority than citizens, that is,
everyone else. Citizens can be influential by noble
birth or wealth, and brothers can get trod upon, say
if they were simple infantry in the military but have
returned to civilian life. A person’s status as brother
or citizen is secondary. A wealthy citizen still has
power over a poor mason, but a brother mason has
an advantage over a citizen mason down the street.

Baphomet’s demons have often been surprised by
the people they think they control, for instance,
when the Knights Templar decided there was no
return to Earth and avoided a complete civil war.

Still, they are pleased with their work. As strictly
conformist                            as the country is now, the demons could
leave it alone for years without the risk of it
becoming any more tolerant or pleasant in nature.

Baphomet sees the benefit of alloying evil with
some                            good to make it stronger and gradually
extending the inner circle of true initiates. His
demons are more impatient and would like to see a
wholly dissolute nation that openly worships

303


AINERÊVE


Baphomet (which would, of course, burn itself up in
an                               orgy of demonic debauchery in a generation or
two). Baphomet keeps them on plan, working on the
very slow corruption he knows is the only way to
retain his power. The demons still compete through
their charges, as is their nature. They have a lot of
work to do, but that’s what they get for starting on a
people as dedicated as a large group of knights and
pilgrims.

Population: Moderate. There are some very densely-
populated cities in Psarmorum, but there’s a lot of
space devoted entirely to farming or lies unused.

Economy: Since Maedoen is the closest nation, and
the                             people of Psarmorum consider them godless
heathens, there isn’t a lot of real trade between
them. Individual merchants sometimes brave the
forest to sell and bring back goods that bring high
prices, but there is nothing on a significant scale and
no “official” exports or imports.

What the people of Maedoen most prefer to
purchase                            from Psarmorum’s brave traders is the
weaponry they manage to get through Meath.

Psarmorum produces sturdy, sometimes excellent, if
not exceptional, weapons and armor, and Maedoen is
happy to have them. Merchants traveling between
the two nations (not to mention just to and from the

Forest of Meath) also make good money selling
each’s                     regional artwork.

There is more trade with Dalmavand, although it is
smaller and farther away, since it is seen as less
threatening and has good-quality coal and special
mineral ores that are used with Psarmorum’s own
iron ore to make good-quality steel. Dalmavand gets
finished arms in return. Dalmavandish
intermediaries have also been used for trade between
Psarmorum and Maedoen when there are active
hostilities.

There are tribes of heathens, usually barbaric, who
live                            beyond the nation’s boundaries and threaten the
people’s welfare. But even so, some traders make
their money selling good steel weapons to the
warlike tribes or bringing back their native arts as
oddities. These carvings, musical instruments, and
hide paintings are occasionally considered beautiful
works of art but are usually treated as little more
than cheap curios.

Internally, Psarmorum is largely agrarian, as it
must                                be to feed its populace. Many large farming
communities have reliable buyers in the middlemen
who transport and sell the crops (mostly grains) to
the major cities. Threats to the nation’s welfare —
from barbarians, monsters, demons, demon
worshippers, and others — are common enough to
keep the military elite in control of the country and
the military well-funded. Danger from the west is
rare and often more easily faced on land, so
Psarmorum’s navy is weak.

Local Pantheon

The Holy Trinity (Sol, Luna, Astra), and the
Celestials                               (the host of angels). Opposing them, Satan
and his demonic hordes.

People of Psarmorum may not be faithful to a man,
but                             those that aren’t pretend to be. To call its
atmosphere that of an inquisition would be
excessive, but not by a great deal. One who does not
go to church weekly gets funny looks, less business,

304


and sometimes social abuse (thrown vegetables and
the                              like). A person or family who is not pious enough
is encouraged to change, and those who do not
change convincingly enough must go on a state-
organized pilgrimage to find their faith. People
suspected of demon worshipping in any form
whatsoever are thoroughly investigated and, if found
guilty, executed or sentenced to hard labor.

Farther from the nation’s centers of population,
some                           villages are harsher or laxer. There are even
some villages where they worship not at all or the
wrong god. When the Templar Knights learn of such
a place, they punish the disbelievers.

Local Authorities

Psarmorum maintains an army large enough to
withstand                                a prolonged assault from a serious force.
They have had to do so several times over the
nation’s long history, so nobody questions the
choice to have the army now. Only the Templar order
is allowed to field an organized and armed force
larger than ten people, so all citizens belong to the
military order (if only loosely). The army is called
“the Sword of Invictus” officially, but the title is
rarely used outside formal writings. In conversation,
it is simply “the army,” “the military,” or “the
sergeants’ lesser brothers.”

The army has five main stations in Psarmorum.
One                                 is near the Temple Mount, and the other four are
near clusters of significant cities or tactical
importance points. Most cities also have smaller
garrisons to provide police services and local defense
until the larger units march to relieve them.
