Noteworthy Places

Most landmarks are better described on a local level,
but                               a few stand out.

Astra’s Threshold: This is a giant archway formed
within                              the trunk of a massive, ancient oak tree,
leading into a giant, dark hollow for most of the year.

The Bishop of Psarmorum, head of the Order of
Chaplains,                           gathers here with the highest-ranking of
the priesthood during the summer solstice to greet
the angels (peris), who often lead them into battle.
This site is actually one of the mysterious Equinox
Gates, a transdimensional portal commandeered by
the will of Baphomet and the strong beliefs of
Psarmorum’s devout. Legend has it that the tree
absorbed the fallen Shee Lords’ souls during Astra’s
Last Battle, their blood fusing with its sap. The
ceremonial use of shee blood can wrench the gates
open during the equinoxes. The local devil
worshipers have tried this on several occasions, but
the Poor Knights of the Faith guard Astra’s
Threshold well.

This site is a transdimensional portal
commandeered                                 by the will of Baphomet and the
strong beliefs of Psarmorum’s devout. Legend has it
that the tree absorbed the fallen Shee Lords’ souls
during Astra’s Last Battle, their blood fusing with its
sap. The ceremonial use of shee blood can wrench
the portal open during the equinoxes, so perhaps this
portal is related to the mysterious Equinox Gates of
Crossroads. The local devil worshipers have tried to
perform this ceremony on several occasions, but the
Poor Knights of the Faith guard Astra’s Threshold
well.

Cathedral Astra: In western Psarmorum, Cathedral
Astra                                is a towering religious edifice known for its
celestial architecture. Made from a rare, luminous
stone that glows softly in the moonlight, it is
adorned with intricate carvings of religious symbols
and stained glass windows depicting Sol Invictus and
his three aspects: Sol Invictus, Luna, and Astra.

Worshippers gather here for sacred ceremonies,
unaware                               of the true nature of their deities. As a
bastion of faith and administration, Cathedral Astra
serves as Bishop Mallory's headquarters, from where
he tends to both the spiritual and secular needs of his
flock.

306


Codexhall: In central Psarmorum, Codexhall is a
grand                             library and center of scholarly pursuits,
housing ancient tomes and serving as a repository of
vast knowledge.

Divinitas Spire: In western Psarmorum, Divinitas
Spire                               is a towering religious edifice known for its
celestial architecture. Made from a rare, luminous
stone that glows softly in the moonlight, and
adorned with intricate carvings of religious symbols
with stained glass windows depicting Sol Invictus
and his three aspects. Worshippers gather here for
sacred ceremonies.

Echolight: In southern Psarmorum, Echolight is a
sacred temple where sound and light converge to
create mesmerizing phenomena, believed to be
divine manifestations of the Lord Sol. Harmonic
chants by the Monks of Luna resonate within
echoing halls. Encased within the temple is the
Equinox Gate, which facilitates rare and powerful
magical events, further enhancing the site's sacred
status..

Grand River: So named for its enormous width and
inexorably steady flow, the Grand runs from east to
west, cutting the nation of Psarmorum roughly in
half. At some places in flatter terrain, the river is as
much as two to three miles wide. There, it is gentle
and fairly slow; it is never low enough to be forded,
but the villages that thrive along its slower reaches
provide bounties of fish for the rest of the nation,
and there are constantly sails on the water there.

Higher in the hills, the Grand River is narrower,
faster,                        and much less forgiving.

The mountain river men who float rafts and barges
filled                             with ore and other goods down to the cities
from the mountains and high towns are legends of
sorts in the rest of Psarmorum. Men who ply the
river in quieter waters share tall tales inspired by the
horrible rapids and white waters the mountain river
men must face. Many of the stories aren’t too far off
the mark.

Lumenhall: In the heart of Psarmorum, Lumenhall
shines                               as a hub of learning and discovery. This grand
edifice, dedicated to the pursuit of knowledge, draws
scholars and mages from across the land. Within its
vast halls, ancient texts are studied, magical
research conducted, and discoveries shared. Known
for its library of rare manuscripts, Lumenhall’s
architecture—illuminated by glowing runes and
light-infused crystals—reflects a relentless quest for
wisdom. Hidden within its archives lie secrets tied to
Luna, the goddess of forbidden knowledge.

Marinveil: In southwestern Psarmorum, Marinveil is
a                              coastal enclave renowned for its maritime culture
and sea-based economy. Located along the shores of
the Gulf of Azure, Marinveil thrives on fishing, trade,
and shipbuilding. The town's picturesque harbor is
dotted with vibrant fishing boats and merchant
vessels, and its bustling markets are filled with
exotic goods from distant lands. Marinveil's
residents, known for their seafaring skills and deep
connection to the ocean, often worship Sol Invictus
in his aspect as the protector of sailors. The town
also serves as a vital link for Psarmorum’s trade
routes, making it a hub of activity and cultural
exchange.

Mont Blanc: It’s not the same shape as the original,
and                               it’s a little bit shorter, but it is always covered in
snow, and at least there’s no Italy to contest its
ownership in Ainerêve. The settlers from Earth
named it Mont Blanc before they knew any better,
and the name stuck. In the southeast, the three
monasteries that dot its slopes serve as common
destinations for the more devoted pilgrims.

Most of the remains of Grand Master de Sablé II,
one                               of the more renowned Grandmasters, were
interred somewhere on Mont Blanc’s slopes. Most
legends claim that he was buried with great wealth
and that his body will rise, armed with his great
sword Valiance and his heavy armor, to defend
Psarmorum should the need arise. The first is true,
and the second is somewhat off: the chaplains who

307


AINERÊVE


oversaw his burial worked sorceries on the grave.
Invoked                               by the proper rituals, de Sablé II’s spirit
comes to defend any holy man on Mont Blanc
(especially in the monasteries). Only a member of the
Order of Chaplains can call on him, and each
chaplain only once.

Sentinelle: Southeast of Vigilance, in southern
Psarmorum,                          Sentinelle is a fortified town
strategically positioned to guard against incursions
from the untamed southern wilderness. Known for
its robust defenses and vigilant watch, Sentinelle is a
bastion of safety and order. The town is home to a
contingent of well-trained soldiers who man its
walls and keep a constant lookout for potential
threats. Sentinelle's residents live under the
protection of these guardians, contributing to the
town’s economy through agriculture and
craftsmanship. The town's stronghold serves as a
command center, ensuring the security of
Psarmorum's southern borders.

Pont Glorieux: Facing the Forest of Meath to the
northwest,                            upriver from the unnavigable Istigh Sea,
sits the Pont Glorieux, the glorious bridge. Massive,
raised of smooth and polished granite and trimmed
with marble, the Pont Glorieux is wide enough for
one hundred men to cross abreast. Massive walls and
two strong garrisoned towers protect the west end of
the bridge from assault. The bridge was named not
only for its physical magnificence but also for the
ambitions of the Grandmaster who commissioned it.
The eastern end of the Safe Road through Meath was
originally meant for a triumphal mass invasion of
Maedoen. Other threats to Psarmorum and internal
politics mean this has never taken place as
envisaged.

The town to the east of the great bridge is one of
the                             army’s five main stations, with ten thousand
warriors and their support troops, much siege
weaponry (and the teams to operate them), and two
generals from the Order of Knights to command
them. Usually, about half the troops are on patrol

throughout the northern forest of Psarmorum or
along                               the Safe Road. Special task forces sometimes
dare the Forest of Meath itself. Besides general
tradespeople and so on in town, some trade
(legitimate and otherwise) goes on with Dalmavand,
Maedoen, and Meath.

Sol’s Gauntlets: These twin fortresses are so named
because they guarded the original northern river
border of Psarmorum at a natural crossing point.

Psarmorum has long since expanded into the
northern                             forests beyond, and the fortresses now
guard a mighty bridge that now provides the main
way across the Grand River. Although the garrison is
only a token force, a significant town has grown
around bridges and fortresses. There is a great deal
of wealth to be had by trading at the bridge, rather
than spending a week or longer finding the nearest
ferry or lesser bridge and paying more for a slower
crossing.

Vigilance: In southwestern Psarmorum near Mount
Aethertop, Vigilance is a fortified town symbolizing
martial readiness. Perched strategically at the base of
the towering mountain, Vigilance serves as the first
line of defense against threats from the wild and the
supernatural. The town is heavily garrisoned with
elite troops, always prepared to respond to any
incursions. Its robust walls and fortified gates reflect
the town’s commitment to security. Vigilance is also
a training ground for soldiers, with rigorous drills
and exercises conducted regularly. The town’s strong
martial culture is complemented by a disciplined and
resilient populace, dedicated to protecting
Psarmorum from any danger..

Voldefeu Volcano: Near Vigilance in southwestern
Psarmorum,                         Voldefeu Volcano is a volcanic region
steeped in elemental and fiery history. This imposing
volcano is rumored to be the home of a volitional
demi-plane of an ancient dragon, whose fiery
essence permeates the surrounding land. The region
is marked by frequent volcanic activity, with rivers of
molten lava and sulfurous vents that remind visitors

308


of the primal forces at play. This area is also rich in
rare minerals and crystals, attracting daring
adventurers and scholars seeking to harness its
elemental energy.

Guilds and Training

There is only one “guild” notable on a national scale
in                         Psarmorum, and it is central to the country’s
entire way of life. It offers training on a very limited
scale to non-members.

The Orders of Knights, Sergeants, and Chaplains:
Originally,                            each of these was a specific rank among
the Poor Knights of the Faith. Knights were the
order’s champions, heavy cavalry, deadly in battle
and inspiring to men. Sergeants were the light
cavalry and heavy infantry, formidable opponents on
their own, but especially skilled in fighting as groups
or units. Chaplains were ordained priests and served
the order’s spiritual needs.

After many centuries in which a nation developed
around                               the order and its practices, these offices have
changed somewhat. Templar knights no longer have
to swear to poverty and chastity, and all but the most
skilled buy their way into the position with some
financial gift to the Temple Mount. They serve
Psarmorum as the army’s generals (the least
experienced knights occasionally serve as lower-
ranking officers, but never lower than lieutenant
colonel). About half the nobility belong to the Order
of Knights, and the Grandmaster is the head of this
order, though he is rarely the most martially capable.

Though they are all called knights, the order has a
complex system of determining superiority. One
knight may outrank another based on military rank
(a brigadier general defers to a major general, for
example), achievements (a knight honored for
defending a pilgrimage against banditry has more
sway than one who has received no honors), or
experience (based mostly on age, but also accounting
for time in active service). The family has no official
effect on influence within the Order of Knights. Still,

a knight whose family has made a significant
donation                               to the Temple Mount is more likely to be
recognized by the Grandmaster and earn the esteem
necessary to boss around lesser knights.

Sergeants are significantly more numerous than
knights.                              This is because joining the Order of
Sergeants comes with fewer expectations of nobility
and wealth. Becoming a sergeant is a matter of
aptitude and dedication, and few who have even one
of those are turned away. Rarely, when the Order of
Knights refuses a nobleman’s son, that nobleman
may buy a place in the Order of Sergeants for the son;
it is better than nothing. Sergeants make up most of
the lower-ranking officers in the nation’s military,
nearly everything from the second lieutenant to
colonel.

309


AINERÊVE


Military Ranks of Psarmorum

Grand Master       Lieutenant-Sergeant

General, major       2nd Lieutenant-Sergeant

General, brigadier     Sergeant

Captain or colonel     Corporal

Lieutenant colonel    Archers

Major            Men-at-arms

Sergeant-colonel     Proletariat

Knights occasionally serve at similar ranks to the
highest-ranked sergeants; officially, when a
sergeant-colonel and a knight-colonel disagree, the
knight takes precedence. There is usually a higher-
ranking knight nearby who knows enough to take the
sergeant’s advice in practice. But not always — some
knights look down on the sergeants and stubbornly
refuse to see the wisdom in their words; others are
trapped by the politics that often surround military
decisions and let that force their hands.

Because no citizen of Psarmorum may participate
in                                 an organized armed force without being a member
of the Templars, the Temple Mount created the
Order of Sergeants. Citizens who join the army are
inducted as “lesser brothers,” which basically lets
them become infantry without initiating them into
the Templars’ serious mysteries. Not all Order of
Sergeants serve the Poor Knights in a military
capacity, and many have other skills. Knights
govern, and the chaplains see to faith, but everything
else falls to the sergeants. Often today, this means
administrative work. Most craftwork falls to non-
initiated citizens, who are directed and funded by
sergeants.

The Order of Chaplains started out seeing the piety
of                                the initiated Poor Knights of the Faith, but today it
serves all Psarmorum. All ordained priests, from the
Bishop of the city of the Temple Mount on down, are
initiated members of the order. They learn how to
read, give services, perform expected rituals
(weddings, funerals, etc.), and generally see to
people’s immortal souls. The Order of Chaplains is
the Church in Psarmorum.

After the ruling of Grand Master d’Echallens
changed                              magic from a source of evil to (at least in
part) a blessing from Lord Sol, it became the
province of the Order of Chaplains. When the army
marches, the chaplains march alongside to lead daily
prayer and support it with their arcane knowledge.

Chaplains use their magic in the course of their work
to                               heal the faithful, exorcise demons, and strike
down the unworthy, but also to manifest the divine
favor of Sol in their services. Just as the Grand
Master is rarely the best warrior, the Bishop of
Psarmorum (foremost ecclesiastical authority in the
nation and head of the Order of Chaplains) is not
always the mightiest theurgist, but more often a man
skilled in debate, philosophy, rhetoric, and politics.

Regional Monsters

Monsters in Psarmorum usually wander in from the
unsettled lands beyond the borders. They are
embodiments of the people’s fears: vaguely
demonic, vaguely human, all unholy or heathen.

Examples include devil worshipers and gethra.

Gethra

Type: Standard

Threat Rank: Ranged 2d10 ~ Melee ~ 2d8 ~ Natural
1d10

Hit Points: 46 (23/23) [normal, medium, mundane]

Damage Reduction: By armor or shield type

Saving Throw: 2d6

Battle Phase: 1d8

Notes: These creatures are not overly common, but
they                             appear with enough regularity to not be
considered unique. Gethra walk digitigrade, on
cloven hooves, and have the furred flanks of a goat or
deer up to their waists. Above the waist, they have a
muscled bare chest, and antlers top their heads. They
fight with crude spears or axes or steel weapons if
they can steal them. Gethra usually work alone and
are best known for kidnapping innocent villagers.

Most presume that the gethra eat them, and they
often                               do, but some gethra try to make their own little
villages out of their prisoners.

310


Items: Gethra carry crude spears or axes or steel
weapons                               if they can steal them. They do benefit from
specific weapon bonuses. These creatures usually
hold onto miscellaneous stolen goods, 4 × $100
worth.

Devil worshipers

Type: Minor to Exceptional

Threat Rank: Minor: Arcane d8 ~ Melee d4 ~ Ranged
d4                                ~ Natural d4

Standard: Arcane 2d8 ~ Melee d6 ~ Ranged d6 ~
Natural d4

Exceptional: Arcane 3d8 ~ Melee 2d6 ~ Ranged d8 ~
Natural d4

Hit Points: Minor 8, standard 32, exceptional 48
[normal, medium, mundane]

Damage Reduction: Standard +1 (cloak), exceptional
d6                               to d8 (armor) as well

Saving Throw: Minor 4, standard 8, exceptional d12

Battle Phase: d6

Notes: Devil worshipers are mostly human in
appearance,                            usually traveling in groups of ten to
thirty. At their worst, they have some light demonic
traits, like red-tinted skin and nubs of horns. They
despise Sol and revere Satan in all his wickedness. To
worship him, they perform evils in his name, from
ruining wagons to eating babies. Most travel rather
than settling; when there is a stationary community
that worships something other than the devil, they
are turned away.

Devil worshippers control sorceries proportional to
the                                evils they perpetrate. Some bands never do
anything worse than breaking things and
blaspheming, and they have minor magical powers.
Others are more dedicated to Hell, and they make
animal or human sacrifices and engage in ritual
orgies. Their powers are more varied and more
potent. Minor worshippers can cast Harm spells via
Hieraticism. Standard worshippers have that basic
power but can also Curse via Arcanum. Exceptional
worshippers have Harm, Curse, and can summon
imps or demons. The GM may add or subtract powers
as needed, of course.

Treasure: Minor worshippers have crude weapons
and                            only minor harm spells. Standard worshippers
wear cloaks unhallowed by demons, granting them

+1 damage reduction against every attack, and get
weapon-specific bonuses. Exceptional worshippers
often carry magical items of unhallowed nature and
sometimes wear leather to chain armor (d6 to d8).
Treasure: minor $50, standard $100, exceptional

$200.

Temple Mount

Description: The Temple Mount is the nerve center
of                                all life for the Poor Knights of the Faith and the
society that has arisen around them in the phantom
world of Ainerêve. Temple Mount properly refers
only to the fortress-cathedral at the foot of a
mountain, but most folks apply it to the grand city
surrounding it. Only scholars and chroniclers
remember and use the city’s old name,
Piusarmorum. It is a beehive of chaplain and
sergeant activity, and it is from here that Grand
Master de Chartres IV directs his knights’ activities.

Large enough to contain all of the order’s official
members                               in siege or emergency, the Temple Mount
was designed by Psarmorum’s first inhabitants as a
combination of temple and fortress. It provided both
consecrated ground where the order’s chaplains
could conduct holy services and a stronghold against
the terrifying creatures who constantly threatened
the Poor Knights in this strange land. The walls first
built around the Temple Mount marked an area 300
by 550 yards and stood at three men’s height. Within
the walls’ safety, the gold-domed temple provided a
respite from the apparently godless surroundings.

Since then, heathen armies have razed the Temple
Mount                            fortress twice and its surroundings several
times more. Each time, the Templar Knights have
rebuilt more strongly than before. Today, the Temple
Mount is visible from leagues away, its hundred-
yard-high cathedral roof and all six of its slender
towers sheathed in beaten gold. Its walls, now
twenty yards high and heavily defended by crossbow
and ballista, guard several square miles appropriated
by the holy order. The order’s experience with sieges
ensures it is prepared: the walls are well stocked with

311


AINERÊVE


missiles and other armaments and food enough to
keep a full complement of troops fed for weeks.

Scaling the wall with siege ladders is made hard by
the long iron spikes sticking out from the
battlements.

The city itself is a sprawling affair. It originally
grew                                up to house the pilgrims who came with the
Poor Knights into Ainerêve. The city’s first
incarnation was as a small agricultural center. With
each rebuild, the Templar Knights have had more
manpower and a stronger economy for
reconstruction. Archived maps of the city show its
evolution from a spread-out farming community to
an efficiently designed, stone-built city with
disordered peripheral areas (and, alas, a perennially

troublesome waste-removal system). Almost one out
of                              every ten buildings is a temple, minor or major, to
Sol, and any inhabitants who don’t pray regularly get
strange looks from their neighbors. Eventually,
Templar chaplains come to visit such malcontents,
who either reaffirm their piety or are told to go on a
state-sanctioned pilgrimage to one of Psarmorum’s
holy sites.

A large oasis, fed by an underground river, sits
beside                                the Temple Mount and city. It is used for local
agriculture. Pipes from the river provide water for
the city’s needs and keep the many underground
cisterns full. The city cisterns, which can be
separated from the river in case of poison, hold water
enough for a three-month siege or drought. Should
the city be lost, the Temple Mount itself could hold
against a siege for six months with full barracks.

Avinoble

Avinoble, a modest kingdom in the east bordering
Psarmorum, boasts abundant natural resources.
However, its fame is eclipsed by eerie legends and
fearsome creatures originating from the eastern
mountains.

King Leonard Avinoble III rules alongside his
queen,                             Clotilde. King Leonard Avinoble III and Queen
Clotilde's sons, Prince Robert and Prince Francois,
lack the charm and renown of their father, much to
the king's dismay.

King Leonard's reign, characterized by strict
adherence                              to an ancient chivalric code and proactive
leadership in battles, has somewhat tarnished his
reputation, sparking frequent rebellions.

While the people of Avinoble enjoy relative safety,
it                              comes at a cost. Due to high military expenditures,
poverty has increased, leading to serfs working
harder. Consequently, many seek refuge in the army,
drawn by its promise of fair compensation, despite
its perils. King Leonard, accompanied by his knights,

312


regularly scours his domain, battling the formidable
creatures                         that lurk within.

Avinoble is split into two baronies. Rivervale, the
larger                              and safer region, owes its peace to the vigilant
knights. This safety has fostered trade, enriching the
land further. Monster incursions from the eastern
mountains are rare but swiftly dealt with.

Gastogne, despite its fertile lands, is troubled. The
area                                is shrouded in darkness due to the ominous
presence of the Harvester of Souls and its cult
followers. The organized raiding parties formed by
the growing goblin population in the willow marshes
hint at the presence of an unseen, intelligent force.

The Butterfly Wood presents its own set of
challenges.                             Elves have claimed sovereignty over the
forest due to a gateway to the fey world, which has
stopped human intrusion, especially lumberjacking.
The local baron's attempts to regain control were
thwarted by the unexpectedly large elf population,
raising suspicions of otherworldly influences or
sorcery reshaping the woods.

Compounding Gastogne's woes, its neighbor,
Rivervale,                             seeks to sever northern ties due to fears of
the Harvester's cult. This has led to heightened
tensions between the baronies, with Baron Marcel
Laberge and Baron St-Pierre Duval often clashing at
their borders. The conflicts in the region primarily
affect the local villages.

In the religious sphere, while most Avinoblians
worship                             Sol, a new knightly order founded by the
king venerates Sekhmet, a deity encountered in the
hidden valley of Aigypt. Sekhmet, a formidable deity
with a lion-human hybrid form, is fluent in the
Avinoble tongue and stands almost ten feet tall.

Although Sekhmet faces rivalry from other deities in
this newfound pantheon, like Osiris, Isis, Horus, and
others, the deities avoid direct conflict, subtly vying
for mortal worship to enhance their power.

Seth, the avatar of chaos and fear, dominates the
southern lands of Aigypt as a formidable hybrid of
fearsome creatures.

Dalmavand

Dalmavand is a land of mountains, rivers, and
forests.                              The northern part of Dalmavand is a cold,
mountainous region with snow-capped peaks and
deep valleys. The southern part of Dalmavand is
more temperate, with rolling hills and lush forests.
The Echoes Forest is located in the southern part of
Dalmavand and is said to be home to a powerful
spirit named Sylvadran

History of Dalmavand

Maedoen was once a fractious land of warring kings,
and                            occupied the whole of the peninsula of which it
now forms the southern part. Then armies of
monsters known as the cythraul invaded from the
sea, slaughtering and enslaving almost at will, since
Maedoen’s many lords paid more heed to their own
quarrels than to the cythraul invasion. For a time it
seemed as if the whole nation would be picked off
piecemeal. Two things stopped this: the appearance
of the Black Standard, rallying an army from people
across the nation regardless of local allegiances, and
the complete overrunning of the north by the
cythraul. These finally caused the remaining lords
and petty kings to put aside their differences (for the
time being) and join (reluctantly) against the
common foe with each other and with Maedeon’s
shee. The cythraul were beaten back and their raids
tailed off, but it was too late for the northern third of
Maedoen, which was largely depopulated and left in
ruins.

Even in dream worlds, Nature abhors a vacuum.
Few                             refugees wanted to return to the colder and
mistier north from the temperate south, but others
found their way to the ravaged land from Earth. The
Varangian Guard were elite soldiers in the Byzantine
army who served as personal bodyguards to the
emperor, recruited mainly from Norsemen with
some Anglo-Saxons. Skilled warriors with a tradition
of faithful service, they played a decisive role in

313


AINERÊVE


many wars. A large group of them returning from
battle                                by sea ran into some Barbary pirates with
ships full of captive Circassian girls destined for the
slave markets. The pirates were swiftly
exterminated, and the young women were being
freed when an unnatural storm blew up: this was a
maritime revorage rift, a gate between worlds, that
transported all the entangled Byzantine and Barbary
ships from Earth to Ainereve, where they made
landfall on the coast of the near-deserted northern
part of the Maedoen peninsula. As with other
transportees, the people found out that they were no
longer on Earth, and decided to settle where they
were. Over time their descendents slowly
repopulated the area which was to become
Dalmavand.

Along the marches of the Forest of Echoes, the
once-proud Maedoen city of Dalma was brought to
ruin as the terrible scourge of the cythraul swept
through the land. Its magnificent central Vas keep
remained intact, defended to the last by a famous
hero named Vand, in one of the north’s final, bitter
battles against the monsters. Centuries later, the
descendents of the Varangian Guard discovered the
place, and found in the miraculously preserved keep
a literary masterpiece which recounted the city’s
final stand, written by one of the few survivors.

Inspired by this tale, “Vand’s Desolation,” which
included                               a prophecy that the powerful warrior’s
spirit would be reborn when the cythraul once again
posed a major threat, the people rebuilt the city of
Dalma, and decided to make it capital of their new
land. The realm was renamed Dalmavand. Their
leader, Clarion, was crowned king, and married a
beautiful young woman named Alastrine. They took
the surname Vand as a royal honorific, and their
subjects took to calling themselves Vandians. The
people as a whole are hardy and fierce fighters, but
defenders rather than conquerors.

By the time the kingdom was established, a large
population of elves had moved into the Echoes
forest. The elves refused to allow the citizens of

Dalmavand to cut timber and deforest the land
eastward,                            thus causing many a border skirmish. An
uneasy truce now prevails, but the forest fay near
Dalma, while much like the shee in the forest of
Meath, are less hostile than those in the
Cresylvadran area to the south.

Population: Dalmavand’s population is a mix of
small                             villages, hamlets, moderately sized towns, and
larger cities. The smaller settlements primarily focus
on specific trades such as agriculture or fishing,
maintaining a traditional way of life. The towns
serve as trading hubs, offering diverse professions
and services, while the larger cities are bustling with
merchants, scholars, and adventurers, providing
opportunities for knowledge, wealth, and intrigue.

The capital, Dalma, although declined from its

314


former glory, still holds significant historical and
cultural                             value, and its population reflects the hardy
and resilient nature of the Vandians.

Economy: The economic framework of Dalmavand is
robust, with key industries including agriculture,
timber, and trade. The fertile lands in the southern
regions, particularly the Verdant Expanse, produce
abundant agricultural products, making the area a
vital trade partner. Timber from the forests,
although a point of contention with the elves, is also
a significant part of the economy. The city of Apix,
with its stone quarries, contributes to the
construction industry. Overall, the economy is
healthy, driven by both traditional trades and the
strategic exploitation of natural resources.

Local Pantheon: In Dalmavand, worship centers
around                                 a mix of Norse and Anglo-Saxon gods. Odin,
Thor, Loki, and Eostre are revered for their wisdom,
strength, trickery, and rejuvenation. Freyr and Freyja
hold significant roles, symbolizing fertility and love.

Freyr is particularly esteemed for bringing
elementalism                           to Dalmavand's early inhabitants,
while Freyja governs The Vaytir, the Elemental
Circles integral to the region's spiritual practices.

Local Authorities: The kingdom of Dalmavand is
ruled                                 by King Bastien Vand, who presides from the
capital city, Dalma. The governance structure is
feudal, with local lords overseeing various regions
under the king’s command. The city of Apix, led by
the high priest of Baldur, Nikolaz Velbri, enjoys a
certain degree of autonomy. Law and order are
maintained through a combination of feudal
obligations and the influence of the regional
pantheon, with religious leaders playing crucial roles
in governance and justice.

Important Entities: Key personalities in Dalmavand
include                          King Bastien Vand and Nikolaz Velbri.

Sylvadran, the powerful spirit of Echoes Forest, and
the                        Cresylvadran elves are also significant. The
Verdant Expanse is home to some of the most potent
elementalists in Ainerêve, guided by the Vaytir. The
Eborian Ape-Men, or Losels, are notable regional
monsters, posing a threat to adventurers and
settlements.

Noteworthy Places

Capital city of Dalma

The kingdom is ruled by King Bastien Vand from
Dalma,                               but the capital has declined from its glory
days and is now a virtual backwater of some 15,000
inhabitants, as many of the kingdom’s subjects have
moved westwards to newer settlements, and the
younger warriors have sought adventure elsewhere.
The tower of Vas keep, located within its city walls,
still holds a vast library of history, runic magic, and
knowledge about the gods and history of the
northern lands prior to and during the cythraul
invasion.

315


AINERÊVE


The City of Apix

The foundations of Apix were laid down with stone
mined                              from rock quarries of a clan of dwarfs called
the Deljun, who lived in the distant western foothills
of the Sechdraic mountains, and with whom the
Vandians found instant rapport. The gray stone walls
now stand nearly 40 feet high and are about 20 feet
thick at the base, with a single main gatehouse
having an iron gate that is normally shut at night but
unguarded during the day. The city has never been
besieged. The city elders, led by the human high
priest of Baldur, Nikolaz Velbri, rarely consider
supporting an expedition across the treacherous
mountainous areas to the south for fear of
encountering Erborian ape-men.

Eborian Ape-Men (Losels)
Type           (TY): Exceptional
Threat Dice (TD):

Melee: 2d8 (using crude weapons or brute strength)

Natural: 2d6 (claws and teeth)

Ranged: 1d6 (throwing rocks or similar objects)

Arcane: 0 (no innate magical abilities)

Extra Attacks (EA): None

Hit Points (HP): 16 (8/8) [average, medium,
mundane; ×1].

This reftects their tough and resilient nature, being
capable of surviving harsh conditions and combat.

Damage Reduction (PR): +2 to HP (thick hide and
agility).

Saving Throw (ST): d8

Reftecting their cunning and survival instincts.
Battle                       Phase (BP): 6 (d8)

This represents their agility and unpredictability in
combat.

Notes:

The Losels, descendants of the ancient Erborian
Ape-Men,                          have degenerated in intelligence and
physical prowess over the centuries. However, they
are still formidable opponents due to their brute

strength, agility, and survival instincts. Known for
their cruel and cunning nature, they are a threat to
any adventurers or settlements they encounter.

Echoes Forest and the Cresylvadran

The Echoes forest is an ancient enchanted wood,
similar                               but different to the forest of Meath. The elves
who moved there, perhaps drawn to it, awakened a
primal nature spirit, one of the strongest of the dran
(elemental guardian spirits), this one akin to the
gods in power. The spirit of Echoes forest called
himself Sylvadran and named his elven awakeners
the credran, meaning kindred of the spirit. Together
they were named the cresylvadran. Sylvadran gave
each elven leader the powers of identification with a
specific element as part of a covenant stating that
they would protect the dran and others of his kind
from any future harm.

Wristhrelin, the elf named king, was made one with
the                              wind and could hear the thoughts of all sentient
creatures upon the currents of the air. His daughter,
Verity, was attuned to the plants and the earth and
could hear the beating heart of every woodland
creature. Aldrin was the essence of fire, symbolizing
the strength of their blood oath to protect the forest.
Caidean was the element of the night, ashen in hue
and wielding the gilded ebony blade, who bore the
verdict of death for those who would harm the dran
or the forest. Arzhela, the elf named queen, was sent
to teach other shee the difficult practices and
knowledge of the credran.

The Woodshades. Prince Mathin the Gray was the
sixth                                of the original credran of Echoes forest. He
made a pact with an evil fiend called Lord Savinoth, a
demon of a realm of shadow. The pact transformed
Mathin and eleven other credran elves who followed
him into dark elves with powers related to shadow
and night.

316


The Verdant Expanse

Following the Cythraul invasion, some Vandians,
descendants                              of the Varangian Guard, sought a
peaceful life farther south. The Verdant Expanse,
north of Sechdraic Valley and on the western side of
the Sechdraic Valley Mountains, offers a temperate
land with lush pastures. Though part of Dalmavand,
the Expanse enjoys autonomy, especially in religious
matters, and is often sought by their northern
Vandian kin for wisdom and counsel. It has become a
key trade partner due to its agricultural abundance.

The Verdant Expanse is also renowned for its
powerful                       Elementalists. The deities Freyr and Freyja
preside over the region; Freyr, the Norse god of
fertility, prosperity, and peace, declared the first
settlers as keepers of elemental secrets. He decreed
leadership to fall within four houses, or “circles,”
overseen by Freyja, the goddess of love, beauty,
fertility, war, and the magic known as seiðr.

These elemental circles, collectively known as The
Vaytir,                               serve both religious and practical roles in the
region. The Earth Guardians (Jordvard) focus on
agriculture, the Water Wise (Vatnwise) on healing
and purification, the Windrunes (Vindrun) on air and
communication, and the Fire Bards (Eldaskalds) as
keepers of lore and masters of fire.

The people of the Verdant Expanse hold festivals
and                              rituals to honor Freyr and Freyja, often aligned
with seasonal changes and agricultural cycles. The
Vandian temples and shrines in the Verdant Expanse
are dedicated to both deities, and four such places
stand out as unique schools of elementalism. These
schools are central to both the spiritual and everyday
lives of the people, blending the divine and the
practical in their stewardship of the land.The
Vandian temples and shrines of the Verdant Expanse
are dedicated to both deities, and four such places
stand out as unique in the land, as they are schools of
elementalism.

Noteworthy Places

Eldaskald Ruins: Ancient ruins, remnants of the
Vandian culture’s Fire Bards, holding echoes of
elemental magic.

•Jordvard: An agrarian region deeply tied to nature’s
cycles,                         honoring deities like Freyr and Freyja, and
home to all four Elementalist circles known as The
Vaytir. These circles, integral to both religious and
practical life in the region, focus on various aspects
of elementalism such as agriculture, healing,
environmental protection, and the preservation of
lore.

•Vaytir Sanctum Temple: A center for elemental
mastery                             and equilibrium, serving religious and
practical roles in the Verdant Expanse.

Castle Astalch

Far north in the colder regions of Dalmavand lies
Astalch                            Castle, which was once a military stronghold
for one of the kings in the north. Today, it’s a ruin.

Only two of Astalch’s five towers still stand, and they
may not stand long, as one leans and the other
sprouts bushes. The other three lie, like the splayed
limbs of a dead man, across the moat and
surrounding field. Climbing through the dry moat
over the old towers’ stones is the only easy access to
the castle now since the drawbridge rotted through
and collapsed long ago.

The forest, once cleared from around the castle so
that                              guards could see anyone who tried to approach,
has grown closer. It is not yet so close that a tree cut
or pulled down would bridge the moat, but trying to
make the castle usable again would involve clearing a
lot of land. Astalch is one of many abandoned castles
dotting the landscape (there is no need now for the
vast number of castles the land supported in its
past), but few of them come with difficulties as great.

The nearest villages are over four days’ travel from
the                            castle. All the inhabitants of those villages know
intimately the legends of what lives there: white-

317


AINERÊVE


faced creatures, like but not like the shee, who
torture                                and devour any they catch. Inhabitants of
every surrounding village know not to travel more
than a half-day toward Astalch Castle because that is
entering their territory. After the war that saw the
founding of the Black Standard and the first pact
with Maedeon’s shee, most cythraul were forced
back into the sea, from where they have not since
emerged. But not all fled. Here, a cell of cythraul
infiltrated and infected Astalch Castle, turning it into
a home for their hate and hungers. They have lived
there for many generations.

Population: Sparse. Not only are there no villages
nearby,                            there are no woodsmen or hermits in the
woods, fields, or hills surrounding the castle. Only a
few animals (few enough for the scarcity to look
strange to an experienced outdoorsman) and the
monstrous cythraul live here.

Economy: There is no economy since nobody lives
here,                              but there is a great deal of arable land and old-
growth and wood not being used for anything here.
The hills even contain decent quantities of copper,
tin, and iron. Reclaiming this land could make
anyone who managed to secure that claim fairly
wealthy.

Important Entities: The only important entities here
are                              the monsters, with one disturbing exception, the
Womb of Cythraul…

Local Authorities: None. Anyone who could have
kept                              the peace has been chased down, tortured, and
devoured.

Relics and Treasures: As the place is an ancient,
abandoned castle, there are plenty of interesting
treasures to be found.

The Library of Astalch: Located within the confines
of                              Castle Astalch, this library remains an invaluable
trove of forgotten lore and knowledge. Castle Astalch
itself was once a modestly fortified structure, far
from a grandiose palace or imposing fortress. Yet, it
was notable as the abode of renowned historians of

the Eldritch Realms, whose contributions have now
largely                               faded from memory. The library, known for
its extensive collection, has become inaccessible due
to a collapsed stairway that once led to its only
entrance, preserving the integrity of its contents.The
collection within the library, comprising volumes of
significant historical and monetary value, remains
remarkably intact. This preservation is not
coincidental. The cythraul, despite their inherently
destructive nature, recognize the potential these
texts hold for strategic advantage. They anticipate
that future captives could decipher them, extracting
information the cythraul could then exploit. To
historians and collectors in the Eldritch Realms, any
book from the Library of Astalch is highly coveted,
offering insights into forgotten histories and
commanding a high price. The challenge of accessing
the library, compounded by the threat of the cythraul
and the treacherous state of the castle, only adds to
the allure and value of these books, making them
prized possessions for those bold enough to seek
them.

Gavin’s Horn: This is a bone horn, probably taken
from                               an enormous mountain goat, and banded in
bronze. Various druidic runes of knowledge, wisdom
and enlightened communication mark its length.

Though the legend is long lost, Gavin, son of Fercos,
once                             stood on a near hill and watched over a decisive
battle. When he knew it was lost, he blew his horn to
tell the women and children to flee. How it ended up
in Astalch Castle is a mystery. This horn, if blown,
can be heard over great distances. Anyone the
hornblower considers an ally can hear the horn,
regardless of distance, and understands its meaning:
victory, defeat, mourning, et cetera. It cannot carry
messages more elaborate than that.

Honest Scale: This plain brass scale is the height of a
short man and stockily built. It has a magical defense
that must be unwoven before the scale can be
harmed in any way physically. This is separate from
its core enchantment, which is to describe perfectly

318


the balance between any two things, physical or
metaphysical. The honest scale can be used for mere
weight and is never wrong, but the person using the
scale can state what quality it is to weigh. The honest
scale then compares the relative values of that
quality in any two things set upon its yard-wide
scale plates. This could be the monetary,
philosophic, historic, or military value of most
items, or even the morality, cruelty, or worth of
people. The scale is always as right as it can be —
some things are governed by chance, and it does not
predict the future.

Astalch Keystone: In the days that saw Astalch Castle
raised,                                  it was common for wizards to enchant the
foundations of major constructions. The keystone of
Astalch was so enchanted, and it retains that magic.
Someone trying to repair Astalch Castle will benefit
from it: the work crews will work faster, tire more
slowly, have fewer accidents, and ask for less pay. All
in all, the repair would take about 25% less time than
usual. Removing the keystone from the castle to use
in the foundation of another building would give the
same benefits to that project.

Vendors and Dealers: Surprisingly, there is one, but
he’s                                not the friendly neighborhood grocer, or even
the sleazy skinflint visiting merchant. He’s
something else. Old Eryi looks like a weak and weary
old man. He is hunched over, with a roughly trimmed
beard, and the clothes he wears have been cobbled
together from a half-dozen different shirts and
pants. The trader speaks haltingly as if he were
always taking a moment to search for a better word
or any word at all. He never looks directly at those he
talks to, instead gazing just over their right
shoulders. He can always be found standing
southeast of Astalch Castle, at the end of one of the
fallen towers. Old Eryi never appears to sit, lie down,
or sleep, and anyone dealing with him is never
attacked by the cythraul.

Concealed among the tumbled stones are what he
has                               to trade: many of the minor treasures of Astalch

Castle, from small gems and pieces of jewelry to age-
old                              cutlery and the ancient Astalch crest from above
the hearth. He’s perfectly willing to take all forms of
minted currency, raw precious metals, or other
valuables. Eryi puts especial value on books, and a
trader braving the forest to bring him current
written materials could make a killing. The trader is
only part Eryi at this point. He is half-merged with a
cythraul, and he trades for precious metals because
the cythraul can use them to spread. He values
written materials because they help the cythraul
learn about the world around them. If someone kills
Eryi, the body slowly turns into a cythraul after about
an hour. It will then rise, the guise destroyed. There
may be a way for heroes to purge Eryi of the cythraul
within him, at the GM’s option, but it should be
difficult.

Adventure Hooks

Astalch Castle is, itself, a giant adventure hook. Still,
there                             are a couple of ways for players’ characters to
treat it.

Raid-style: Get in, get stuff, get out. This is the
classic                            dungeon delve, where the heroes know that
there are both monsters and treasure and they’re
determined to fight the first and take out the second.

Quest-style: This time, they have to accomplish a
specific                              task while they’re in the castle. For Astalch,
that probably means cleaning out the nest of
cythraul who want to eat them. Wiping the blight
from the land can’t be anything but good, and there
is potentially more long-term wealth involved if they
can claim the castle as their own.

Campaign-style: Here, the game focuses on the
threat                               the castle presents for more than a few
sessions. That threat probably looms over the rest of
the land, as the cythraul are just now beginning to
explore the world outside their castle. Those small
villages have probably been destroyed, and the
plague of fiends is spreading. After building up to an
assault on the castle over several sessions, the

319


AINERÊVE


heroes go in to stop the cythraul and save the world
or                              die trying. All the treasure from the previous two
options is there, but the characters can also become
nationwide.

The womb is intelligent. It can communicate
telepathically                             with anyone caught within its pale
light. It is also a master of reading others and
deceiving them. The womb never communicates with
someone unless this will be advantageous, and then
it fabricates some story to manipulate its victim into
obeying it.

One example: It might claim to be the spirit of an
ancient                             princess locked in a gemstone and then

hundreds of new cythraul. The womb can make

of                               the cythraul womb. It can create new cythraul by

metal. The material being consumed disappears over
about a day; consuming a human mind is entirely
mental and more complex.

chance                              of error and can summon, control, and heal
(or destroy) cythraul. The womb can bite with a
razor-sharp mouth that is invisible but soon
discovered by any creature that touches its
crystalline form with exposed flesh.

The Cythraul

The cythraul are humanoids who hate all human life.
Vaguely human in shape, these monsters are always
pale white and malformed in numerous ways that
mark their ranks or types. They are truly creatures
out of a nightmare, looking vaguely human but with
elongated features and some entirely alien aspect.

They are barbaric and insane by human standards,
but                            not stupid, and only the simplest will attack
without considering acquiring an advantage or
killing without thinking about taking a prisoner.

Cythraul have a limited hive mind. At times,
individual                       cythraul “check in” to the communal
mind. At that moment, the cythraul has the
perspective and memory of the entire race, and it
updates the hive memory with the individual’s
experiences since the last communion.

Though cythraul can stray from the hive’s goals
over                              time, they naturally check in every week or two,
reinforcing an individual’s communal
responsibilities and setting it back on course. Thus, a
straying cythraul would have to subconsciously
subdue its natural urge to connect with the hive,

320


which gets harder over time. Some specific aspect of
the cythraul’s inhuman features marks them as
belonging to a certain caste, determining rough
pecking orders and responsibilities.

The cythraul womb described above can change a
cythraul from one caste to another and even devise
new castes for specific purposes. The cythraul in
question must spend a half-hour stationary in the
womb’s glow to complete the transition. Three
sample castes follow, though there are certainly
more.

monster and its opponent determines whether the
