The Northern
Reaches

The Northern Reaches, a rugged land across the sea
north of Dalmavand and the Forest of Meath, boasts
stunning mountain vistas and dense pine forests.

The rugged landscape requires its residents to be
resilient, as severe winters can swiftly eliminate
those who are not prepared.

This territory is home to three human clans and,
initially, three dwarven clans. The destruction of
Forka's impressive dwarven temple by a volcanic
eruption forced the fusion of the dwarves with the

322


humans. The situation deteriorated further with the
opening of a chasm, which released subterranean
creatures and ravaged the few remaining dwarven
settlements.

The Wolf Clan, the most amiable and open to new
beliefs,                              joined forces with the dwarves to build
strong defenses against the emerging terrors of the
chasm, now ominously called the "Gate of Many
Eyes." The formidable Bear Clan stays neutral in
many disputes and frequently acts as hired soldiers.
The ambitious Boar Clan is infamous for conducting
raids and engaging in piracy, often targeting
vulnerable communities along the northern coast of
Maedoen.

The Dur Clan, formerly famous for their
exceptional                        craftsmanship and sculpting, are known
for their strong work ethic. The Kur Clan, former
elite warriors, blend the ferocity of barbarian
berserkers with the honor of knights. The Mur Clan,
celebrated brewers, are famous for their potent ale
and legendary detoxifying abilities.

A large number of dwarves continue to follow the
faith                                of Forka, the dwarven patriarch, although a few
have embraced Sol instead. Forka's followers,
marked by a golden hammer over a gray mountain
against a purple sky, are protectors of their kin.

The devastating collapse of Forka Mountain
happened                                due to dwarves digging excessively deep
out of greed, resulting in catastrophic destruction
and the emergence of monstrous hordes. The once
grand temple is now a ruin, partly occupied by vile
creatures. Nevertheless, numerous courageous
individuals explore this place in search of riches and
sacred relics infused with the essence of Forka. In the
absence of their magnificent temple, the priests of
Forka uphold the faith by tending to many shrines
throughout the northern reaches, ensuring that the
traditions and history endure amid the vestiges of
their former splendor.In religion, many dwarves still
adhere to the worship of Forka, the dwarven father,
despite some converting to Sol. Forka's followers,
marked by a golden hammer over a gray mountain

323

against a purple sky, are protectors of their kin,
always                          equipped with warhammers, shields, and
heavy armor. The ale horn symbolizes their faith.

The catastrophic collapse of Forka Mountain, now
Zorka                               ("the fall of the dwarven folk"), occurred
when greed drove the dwarves to dig too deep,
unleashing fiery destruction and monstrous hordes
from the caves of shadows. The once grand temple,
capable of housing thousands, is now a ruin, partly
occupied by vile creatures. Yet, many brave souls
venture here, seeking the treasures and holy relics of
a bygone era, items imbued with Forka's essence,
beyond mere magic.

Now without their grand temple, Forka's priests
maintain                          numerous shrines across the northern
reaches, keeping faith and history alive amidst the
remnants of their lost glory.

Forest of Meath

At first, Meath’s vast and lush forest seems normal,
with                            sunny and shaded stretches, hills and dales,
waterways, light woods, thickets, and clearings. It is
home to beautiful open valleys, hundreds of square
miles of pristine woodland, and countless secret,
verdant dells that hide earthly and esoteric secrets.
At the edges, it is fairly natural, but it is an
enchanted forest and the abode of the shee.

These changeable forest denizens fit the traditional
beliefs                             they are shaped by, with most valuing
cleverness and courtesy and despising boorishness
and greed, regardless of whether they are cruel or
kind, grim or playful. The most powerful and stern of
the shee rulers treat Maedoen as a plaything and
mingle with its royal bloodlines. Also hidden in the
glens of Meath are the angels (celestials or peris) and
devils (demons or deevs) that the inhabitants of
Psarmorum revere or revile.

This juxtaposition of beliefs is more than a simple
accident                              of fate. The first tree of Meath sprouted with
the beginning of the Celtic religion in the region on


AINERÊVE


Earth that would become Wales. As this belief
commingled                             with the superstitions of the Celtic
people, the land around the first sapling grew more
fertile, and the tree's seeds took hold. The strength
of the belief and the widespread nature of the Celtic
religion gave the young Meath enough energy to
grow. In its youth, the forest was a dark place filled
with gnomes and goblins, full of mischief and
danger; but strong, ruled over by the one druidic sun
god.

When the Romans conquered the Celts and later
forced                           religious integration, the obvious parallel
with the Christian God meant that the new beliefs of
the Romans were quickly adopted. The changes in
religion changed Meath. Mischievous but largely
unaligned fay creatures waned in number, displaced
by demons, imps, and so on. They served or opposed
the distant but powerful God.

After the decline of the Roman Empire, the Celtic
Christian                            church had its core in Ireland and Wales. It
was then, before the faith began to spread again, that
Meath's mischievous fairy creatures became more
like the fay of those countries and recovered their
numbers. By this point, the Forest of Meath was a
vast, sprawling, primeval woodland filled with
strange creatures and bizarre natural magic.

That was the last major influx of belief and
imagination                              the forest received from Earth, although
a steady trickle of fairy lore has added to it gradually
since, helping to leaven and lighten the place
somewhat.

This mix of various beliefs made it a conceptual
destination                        both for the Welsh of the time and the
later (mainly) Christian Knights Templar. Thus, it
became a bridge between the two worlds.

Baphomet’s adoption of the sun god persona, Sol
Invictus                         (supposedly as Ainerêve’s name for God, but
in fact from a Roman cult) took advantage of
underlying beliefs to twist Meath’s Celtic
Christianity to his own religion.

There is constant skirmishing going on in some
areas of the forest. The angels (peris in service to

Baphomet) and demons (those opposed to
Baphomet)                               clash here in Meath as in Psarmorum but
are united in their dislike of the shee. The two
battling realms are likely to encroach upon the
portions of the forest inhabited by the fairy creatures
to fight each other and sometimes make (very) brief
alliances against them since the shee are numerous.
The shee fight back obliquely. Many are content to
evade the assaults of the celestial and demonic
beings, playing tricks in return and spreading
mischief in their ranks. Others war directly, raising
legions of their own, hundreds of strange and unique
creatures who tangle with the demons and angels,
killing some and sometimes dying themselves. No
matter how many die on both sides, there always
seem to be more.

Besides the war that mirrors that of Psarmorum
and                            Maedoen, there is an incidental effect of the
intermingling in the Forest of Meath. As time passes,
the occasional angel or demon may find the shee not
so despicable after all and become more interested in
experiencing life in Meath. Likewise, the occasional
shee may learn to take pleasure in angels’ or
demons’ company and practices. Their natures may
gradually change through such associations. There
are always more pure shee, angels, and demons, but
the number of creatures with two species’ traits
slowly grows.

Local Pantheon: The shee and like fay creatures
mostly                             worship Bel (Belenus, in his aspect as the god
of sun and fire). Various demons (also known as
devils or deevs) worship the Devil, Prince of
Darkness and Father of Lies. Resident humans and
half-humans may worship Sol Invictus (not known
by them to be Baphomet), or Maedoen gods such as
Cernunnos. The angels that are peris serve Sol, for
now. Rarely, genuine angels from various faiths may
appear to aid the truly good and oppose the truly evil.

Population: Sparse. Meath has no dearth of natural
and                        supernatural creatures. Still, it’s so vast in scope
and changeable in nature that even a master
woodsman might sometimes have difficulty finding

324


a sentient inhabitant — assuming one was not
looking                            for him as well. There are human hamlets
near the forest edge, but the camps, courts, and
other domiciles of the shee and so on are often
magically hidden (see Appendix A).

The Shee: The creatures of faerie rule the forest; the
elves,                              fairies, and many others. As a general rule, the
shee is practiced at the magic of glamor, making the
false appear real, the real look false, and can
accomplish myriad effects. Shee generally feed off
emotions or feelings from humans they meet, and
thus they play inventive and often dangerous games
with them. On the rare occasions that the shee make
mortal heroes welcome, they can be charming hosts,
fêting them with wondrous food, drink, music, and
stories. The shee will seldom refuse a contest and are
especially fond of fighting and chess, at which they
are skilled enough that many mortals have lost all
they owned in a match. In their places of power, the
fay folk can often exceed the normal bounds of
magic. For instance, even minor sprites and so on
can cast cantrips that affect ordinary mortals. While
demi-human heroes will be called “cousins” as a
courtesy, they get no special favors.

Economy: Despite the war between Maedoen and
Psarmorum, some merchants from either place and
some from Dalmavand (too brave or too foolish, as
their contemporaries say) dare travel between
nations. They take the sole long safe road forged
through Meath and pay heavy tariffs, imposts, levies,
or sometimes short-cut trails, hoping not to run into
one of the frivolously cruel shee or the gleefully cruel
demons who live in the woods. The inhabitants of
Meath levy no tax or toll per se, though some may
sometimes claim unwilling travelers as living
playthings — which serves as a heavy enough toll on
all who would pass through the forest.

There’s almost as much to trade with the forest
residents                               as there is to trade with the humans on the
other side. The fay folk of Meath, benign or malign or
simply capricious, take pleasure in playing with the

less magical humankind. Wit and politeness are oft
the                                best sword and shield for those who deal with
them, and innocent children have been known to
wander scatheless through the woods. Some humans
(usually of Maedoen) enter the forest specifically to
try their luck with the mercurial shee, hoping to
receive a random boon or endure the fairies’ tricks or
tests long enough for their mood to become more
generous. (Many folktales told on both sides of the
forest have the moral that those who enter Meath
seeking gifts are more likely to receive nothing. That
doesn’t stop the occasional adventurer from trying
for even more occasional success.) There is even a
steady trade outside the forest in charms and
enchantments that their barkers claim will make the
fay look upon one favorably.

Others don’t take chances. A fortune hunter who is
daring and silver-tongued enough might forge a deal
with the shee. (If the stories are to be believed, a
promise or bargain made by the fair folk is
impossible for them to break.) Most typically, a
human volunteers to undergo a quest (or to be the
butt of the shee’s jokes, pranks, and other
mischiefs), and after success (or a set time), the fairy
gives him or her a moderate boon, often in the form
that folktales describe (since that is what people
expect).

Less moral individuals may trade others for their
boons.                           Whether they provide indentured servants,
men trying to alleviate debts or liens, or slaves
(illegal in either human nation), the entrepreneur
can earn significant benefits from certain shee (if
they are what they seem). Shee are not the only
forest inhabitants who indulge in bargaining with
the human folk who come by. The most powerful
creatures and gods of the forest (of which Bel is one)
are often willing to accept sacrifices in exchange for
potential benefits. Demons in the east do much like
the shee in the west, tormenting travelers they find
in Meath and eagerly dealing with them for souls or
tempting their victims into sin.

325


AINERÊVE


Within the forest itself, its inhabitants engage in
myriad different forms of exchange. Some trade in
the comprehendible medium of enchanted silver or
fairy gold, but many others incur and pay debts by
performing songs, teaching rhymes, with bits of
seeds, worthless crystals, or even by being
inhospitable or wittily rude to another. Only the
sharpest travelers manage to break even trading in
Meath.

Noteworthy Places

Coille Creige (The Wood of the Rock): A fertile glen
in                            Meath Forest, gateway to the Otherworld.

Skybound Crosmallite crystals grow from earth to
treetops,                              defying gravity. Caelmorin, an ancient Shee
Reifium born from an oak, rules this Volitional
Realm. The Wyld Elves harvest crystals through
rituals preserving the glen's balance. The Mi-
Dhaonna clan, Aesir Valley dwarf descendants, mine
Earthbound Crosmallite. Their uneasy alliance with
the elves enables powerful artifact creation, vital for
both clans' survival.

Dubhthach: A town in Meath Forest's shadows,
influenced                            by Unseelie power. Winding streets and
old structures blend with gnarled roots and twisted
branches. Magic permeates the air. Dubhthach
connects the mortal world to Meath's enigmatic
inhabitants, its people adept at fae court politics.

Gleamsward: Oberon's realm in Meath Forest.
Elemental                            and mystical forces shape glittering
meadows and enchanted groves that shift with the
Seelie King's moods. Oberon, often aloof, balances
magical factions and protects his subjects. Ancient
trees display rune carvings, chronicling Oberon's
spells and decrees.

Ljosalfheimr: An otherworldly section of Meath
Forest                              in perpetual twilight. The air sparkles with
living light, and plants and animals display
unearthly colors. Light elves dwell here, known for
their craftsmanship and nature connection. The
forest's inner music guides the pure-hearted and
confuses the malicious.

Solas Glade: Ljosalfheimr's radiant heart, sacred to
light elves. The glade glows with earth-born light,
encircled by iridescent trees. Luminous plants react
to visitors, forming intricate light patterns. Some
claim to glimpse past and future here, making it a
place of prophecy and reflection.

The Safe Road: A 30-foot-wide packed earth road
through                            Meath Forest, with 30 feet of cleared land on
each side. It runs from Psarmorum to Maedoen. A
powerful spell agreed upon by all factions, including
the shee, governs it. Forest magic doesn't work here,
and combat is forbidden unless mutually agreed.

Unauthorized attacks move as if through syrup.

326


Stepping off the road removes all protection,
tempting                 travelers with risk.

Thornveil: Mab's domain, is a realm of contrasts
where                              beauty and danger intertwine. Mab, once a
member of the Seelie Court, now wields Unseelie
magic, creating a landscape that shifts between
alluring meadows and treacherous bogs. Ancient
standing stones in Thornveil Wood bear witness to
forgotten rites, their surfaces etched with cryptic
runes. At the heart of the wood stands Mab's arboreal
palace, a nexus of fae politics where Seelie and
Unseelie influences converge.

Strange Properties of Meath

The realms of faerie can be cruel or enchanting or
whimsical, but are always changeable. Meath is no
exception. It has few stable landmarks. Apart from
strange encounters, it has effects of its own that
generally result in a traveler becoming hopelessly
lost and perhaps prey to monsters or wicked shee.

For each half-day of travel off the safe road, roll a
d12:

Glamor. Mysticism subtly changes landmarks and
features as one goes. Travel is hard going save for
certain paths, which vanish after a time, and only
lead deeper in.

Change. As for glamor, above, but changes are real.
Trees                             move to block routes etc.

Travel rate. Seems normal but is at d6: 1 tenth, 2
fifth,                                 3 half, 4 twice, 5 five times, 6 ten times normal.
Distance. The actual distance between places varies

as for the rate above.

Direction. Travel is in a random direction (d8 for
compass heading: N, NE, E, etc.), but sun, moon,
stars, and direction sense all indicate travelers are
heading the way they think they are going.

Plain lost. No idea which way is which, end up
traveling in circles.

7–12.No effect.

Effects last the day (or night). Magic can counter
some                                 of them (GM’s call) but will attract magic-
using denizens of the forest. Some paths are deer
trails and a series of loosely-linked bridle paths that
the shee have woven through the forest for their own
use, but these are very hard to find and not stable,
keeping to the same general route for only a few
days. The bridle paths are not magical per se, but the
shee are bound by their laws not to molest any who
remain thereon. The Guardians’ Guild of Crossroads
has worked out how to find and follow such paths to
travel to the desired location, most of the time (5 in
6), with only brief treks through the more dangerous
forest itself.

The Waters: Reflecting the fluidity of faerie, water is
often magical in Meath. Streams and pools in the
forest (off-road or path) will be clear and refreshing
unless polluted by some fell beast or other, but have
a 1 in 6 chance of being enchanted when drunk from
(and an hour after).

Roll a d6 to see what happens if the waters are
magical:

Sleep. Fall into a deep slumber after a few rounds.

Memory loss. Who are we? Why are we here? Where
is                              here anyway?

Confusion. Lose sense of direction; no idea how to
find one’s way.

Tranquility. Perfectly at peace; want to lie back, eat
lotuses, etc.

As a beneficent potion. Whatever the character
seems                          to need most.

Touch of faerie glamor. The next encounter
reaction                     will be positive.

Effects last the day (or night), as for forest magic.
Meath                            water in a waterskin varies with its source
while in Meath (i.e., 1 in 6 magical if an hour or more
has passed).

327


AINERÊVE


Regional Creatures

The shee are the best example of the local fauna.
They                               are hard to categorize, but the most commonly
encountered are the Shee, the Elves (who are
considered the Lords of the Shee), and the Imps.

Fertile Glens

Description: Fertile glens are typically one of the
many                               small valleys in the Forest of Meath. The
canopy is no less thick above it, and it is no less
verdant, but there is typically a single easy path in at
one end of the glen that threads the valley to the
other side, where it stops, usually at the bottom of a
cliff. These glens are fertile not just in plants but also
in magic. Fertile glens serve as homes to the many
strange shee creatures that live in Meath. A glen
often houses a small fairy court of some kind, with
one powerful creature presiding over the rest. All of
them typically play at some form of internecine
politics, allying and backstabbing to their hearts’
delight. If they have hearts, that is. A glen is not
always a valley, although that is the most common: it
could be a clearing, a small lake, a hollow hill (rath),
and so on. The only true requirement is that the glen
has one way in and out. Most are fairly idyllic places
since most fay like it that way.

Many fertile glens have unique properties. One
might                               cause those who die there to live on in its
memory; another could turn silver that crosses its
boundaries into gold. Most glens cause some
measure of local time distortion. Common legends
talk of visitors spending a day but returning after a
minute and vice versa. Usually, the distortion is less.
Only the most powerful fairy lords rule glens that
have great effects on time. Each glen has its own
unique name that describes and defines it to
inhabitants and potential visitors. Some fertile glens,
like many of the fay creatures they house, also have
secret names. One who knows that secret name has
power over the glen, including the power to seal it
away from the rest of Meath and alter its appearance

and nature. Ways to discover a secret name are
intrinsic                             to the place — perhaps a specific rite
performed at the glen’s heart, or reading tea leaves
under a specific moon, might reveal it.

Usually, only the single strongest shee in a fertile
glen                              knows the glen’s secret name (if any), though
other strong shee may know it as well. It is not
uncommon for a shee lord, not tied down to any glen
or fairy court, to know many glens’ names and use
them as leverage for safe travel. It is the more
strange and magical glens that have secret names,
and the most powerful actually have two — such
glens are intelligent entities in their own right and
dangerous to cross. Glens’ second secret names can
be revealed against the entities’ wills, but the rituals
to learn them are known only to the sagest of
theurgists.

Glens can actually be “killed,” though the methods
for                             slaying them are unique to each glen. Planting a
mistletoe twig in one might destroy it while stealing
three of the place’s seven gem-laden idols might
slay another. Killing a glen eliminates one of its
secret names. If a conscious glen loses its second and
more secret name, it becomes little more than a
fertile glen of special ability. Killing a glen with only
a single secret name is less like murder and more like
disabling or breaking a potent weapon or tool. A glen
with no secret names is just a magical place and
cannot be further harmed in this way.

Demons and angels (peris) also use fertile glens for
their                             domiciles in Meath. Some learn the secret name
of a glen and may try to change it into something
that suits them. Such changes are more than
decorative, so it takes time for a fertile glen to don a
diabolic or paradisiac aspect. Where the change is
complete, an unsuspecting traveler in Meath can
step from verdant forest to hellfire-burned
wasteland (or harp-strewn cloudscape) in the space
of a minute’s walk — and it can often be harder to
leave than to enter.

328


The following table and suggestions are provided to
help GMs characterize the large numbers of fertile
glens in Meath. Roll 1d12 for a starting point on what
glens can be like, but the possibilities are endless.

A d6 would serve for the 6 options you chose (it was
1–2, 3–4 etc.) but I suggest letting a 7–12 be the
other possibilities, as below.

1.Animals can talk.

2.Plants can talk.

3.Plants and talk and move

4.Directions reversed. Must walk backward to go
forwards, left to move right, etc.

5.Magic is erratic: half the time, spells have
punning and/or amusing results.

6.Objects can d6: 1–4 talk, 5–6 talk, and move. On a
6, it includes sun, moon, and stars.

7–12. Choose from the following options or make
up                            something suitable. Time seems normal but
passes in the glen at d6: 1 thirtieth, 2 tenth, 3 third, 4
thrice, 5 ten times, 6 thirty times outside rate. Travel
takes d6: 1 five, 2 ten, 3 fifty, 4 100, 5 200, 6 500
times longer to cover the ground (a field might seem
a plain, a hill a mountain), but returning is at normal
rates. Shrink. All creatures (and gear) entering the
glen are shrunk to miniature size, so normal-sized
glen and plants seem enormous (common for
important fay courts and settlements). Size. Animals
and plants are d4: 1–2 miniature, 3–4 giant-sized.

Objects are d4: 1–2 miniature, 3–4 giant-sized.
Color.                        Everything is d6: 1 pastel shades, 2 riotously
bright, 3 striped, 4 rainbow hues, 5 other than

normal, 6 monochrome shades (d8: 1 red, 2 orange, 3

yellow, 4 green, 5 blue, 6 purple, 7 gray, 8 brown).
Gravity.                              d4: 1 all creatures can fly, 2 moon gravity, 3
objects float in the air if left there, 4 water flows
uphill. Intangibles are tangible. d6: 1 sunlight,
moonlight, songs, dreams can be woven, forged, or
distilled, 2 auras are visible, reflect thought and
emotion, 3 speech (and spells) appear in bubbles —
pop to hear (or take effect; needs magic weapon), 4
dreams become real if one sleeps, 5 death, truth, the

329

world, etc. may appear as characters or symbolic
creatures,                               6 enchanted pool shows how to obtain
desired goals, items. Season. d6: 1 spring, 2
summers, 3 autumn, 4 winters, 5 four seasons in one
day, 6 random seasons each hour. Stream in glen is
d8: 1 ale, 2 liquid gold, 3 liquid silver, 4 mead, 5 milk
and honey, 6 wine, 7 as for forest stream; or 8 small
pool is liquid cold iron.

Note that liquid metal is cold, not molten, and will
solidify once removed from glen. Talking animals
and so on also become ordinary once removed.

Things work as they do in fairy tales: something
politely                             asked for or freely given is good, otherwise it
may well have a curse or severe drawback attached.

The Goblin Market

Fay of all kinds, other forest inhabitants, angels and
demons, creatures from other realms, the odd
wizard, and select traders (of which the party is
assumed to be) gather here under truce to wander
through the tents and tables piled high with
stupendous goods and produce. As for the shee
section of the Porreth Bazaar in Grimsete, vendors,
choice, and clientele are wider. Everything is noise,
bustle, color. Rare wines, ambrosial foods, faery
fabrics, marvelous magic, wondrous weapons are all
displayed.

Counsel can also be sought — how best to win a
princess’s hand, how to lift a potent curse. The more
desirable goods and services generally require
elaborate quests as payment to perform deeds or
gain items for the seller. All sorts of people gather
here under truce to wander through the tents and
tables piled high with stupendous goods and
produce. As for the shee section of the Porreth
Bazaar in Grimsete, vendors, choice, and clientele
are wider. Everything is noise, bustle, color. Rare
wines, ambrosial foods, faery fabrics, marvelous
magic, wondrous weapons are all displayed. Counsel
can also be sought — how best to win the hand of a
princess, how to lift a potent curse. The more
desirable goods and services generally require


AINERÊVE


elaborate quests as payment to perform deeds or
gain items for the seller.

The Town of Dolar

In the northeastern Meath Forest, where it meets the
Drayocht Ocean, sits Dolar, a unique maritime town
with a secret: it exists as a demiplane, willed into
being by its founder, the elven archmage Alen Beirie.
Known for his journeys across Ainerêve and Earth, a
realm unknown to most, Beirie imbued Dolar with
his singular vision.

The town’s name, meaning “currency” in
Meadoen,                             reflects its role as a thriving trade center,
especially for those seeking rare artifacts and
otherworldly crafts. Dolar’s fleet, enhanced with the
same energy that sustains the town, navigates the
treacherous Drayocht Ocean, trading with dwarven
clans in Blackwater and Stormreach.

The town’s aesthetic blends nature with
craftsmanship.                             Many residents, created by Beirie’s
will at the town’s founding, work alongside others
who arrived later, all sharing a love of crafting,
trade, and a communal sense of humor. This is
evident in landmarks like the Dolar Tree and the
lively workshops and taverns filled with laughter and
tales of the sea.

Banríonau

Around a century ago, Ragnar Ironheart, a leader
from                              the northern Kingdom of Dalmavand, was
convinced to lead a conquest of southwestern
Maedoen. This campaign was likely influenced by a
former Maedoen monarch, possibly due to an old
alliance or friendship. Following the conquest,
Ragnar established the kingdom of Banríonau
(pronounced ban-ree-uh-naw). Today, his
descendant, Lady Brynhildr Ironheart, governs this
young realm. Like her forefather, she is revered for
her just and compassionate rule.

Lady Brynhildr, of both Celtic and Nordic lineage,
deeply                       venerates the Celtic deities of the Tuatha Dé

Danann. Under her leadership, Banríonau has
become                               a unique fusion of Tuatha Dé and Norse
traditions. The people of Banríonau, fiercely
independent and family-oriented, take immense
pride in their heritage, renowned for producing
exquisite fabrics, ceramics, and jewelry that reflect
their dual cultural legacy.

Banríonau also boasts a rich bardic tradition, where
skilled                            musicians and performers shine at festivals
and gatherings, keeping the realm’s history and
culture alive through song and story. The landscape
of Banríonau is marked by towering mountains, deep
valleys, and fast-flowing rivers. Its picturesque
farming villages, scattered across the realm, are
home to hardworking residents who diligently tend
their crops and livestock. Over the past century, the
resilient people of Banríonau have weathered wars,
invasions, and natural disasters, forging a strong
and close-knit community.

Important Entities: The Regent’s Elite Guard, led by
a                       battle-hardened knight named Maelgwn Fawr
(MYLE-goon VOW-r), ensures the protection of Lady
Brynhildr. The Bardic Order upholds Banríonau’s
musical and storytelling traditions, vital to the
kingdom’s cultural identity.

Noteworthy Places: Elmsong Woods, home to a
sprite                            glade that transforms from day to night,
revealing powerful magic. The Sunken Ruins of
Gorgon’s Lair, off the coast, shrouded in mystery
and linked to ancient legends. The Arcane Nexus, a
site of potent magical forces, guarded by deadly
wards.

Relics & Treasures: Banríonauian crafts, such as
ornate                            jewelry and tapestries, honor the Celtic
deities, showcasing the region’s rich artistic
heritage. Artifacts that reflect the shared Celtic and
Norse influences of the kingdom, offering a tangible
link to Banríonau’s storied past.

Vendors & Dealers: The bustling markets and docks
of                           Falgardr are central to trade, with importers,
money-lenders, smugglers, and merchants driving
the kingdom’s economy.


Town of Dolar contributed by Barton Cox

330


Guilds & Training: The Bardic Order not only
preserves                          traditions but also trains new generations
of musicians and storytellers. Mercenary companies
gather in Falgardr’s taverns, recruiting skilled
warriors for various conflicts.

Regional Monsters: The forests and hills are haunted
by                            goblins, hags, and fey creatures, while the coastal
waters near Gorgon’s Lair are home to sea serpents
and the fearsome gorgons, posing threats to those
who venture into these perilous regions.

Adventure Hooks:

Tears of Stone: Brave explorers are needed to plumb
the                             sunken remains rumored to be the lost ship of
the dreaded Weeping Widow—a mournful figure
whose gaze turns all to stone. The petrified forms of
her crew linger in the murky gloom, alongside
priceless treasures entombed within. Those who dare
to face the Widow’s curse may claim the relics
hidden in her watery grave.

The Nexus Unbound: An Arcane Nexus, a source of
immense magical power, has been sensed in the
lands of Banríonau. The air hums with strange
energy, and the scent of ozone carries a hint of
something otherworldly. Seek out this Nexus, a
potential gateway to the sublime Meterea and
unravel its deadly defenses to harness energies
capable of shaping reality itself.

The Fading Curse: The rustic villages under Lady
Brynhildr’s protection face a growing menace—

brutal raids by fearsome Redcaps, their bodies
warped                                by fell fey magic. Whispers abound of Lady
Brynhildr’s hidden connection to ancient lineages,
possibly offering insight into the creatures’ motives.
Heroes are needed to defend the innocent and rescue
captives from their vile clutches.

Treasures of Trade: Perilous roads between
Banríonau                             and distant realms carry caravans laden
with exotic goods like ethereal silks and dreaming-
dust, bound for the Shimmering Market, where
otherworldly wares are traded. Safeguard these
riches against cunning spirit-bandits, chimerical
beasts, and corrupt spiretaxmen, preserving the
lifeblood of Banríonau’s economy.

Relics of the Gloaming: Scattered across the lands
are                            priceless artifacts imbued with the echoes of
forgotten rituals from when the veil between worlds
was thin. Lost tomes of unraveling mysteries,
ancestral heirlooms tied to Tuatha Dé lineages, and
mythic dreamforged weapons await discovery. These
relics hold the key to Banríonau’s storied past,
offering an opportunity to recover echoes of history.

332


Beings Diverse
and Malign

Two copies of this bestiary exist, both in the town of
Crossroads.                              One is in the shielded reading room
(advanced section) of the spiral tower of the Octocirculi
Academy. The other is in the private vaults of the
Guardians’ Guild. Each bestiary is a large, locked, brass-
bound volume chained to a lectern; access is available on
request (and possibly after payment) to those deemed
suitable, stable, and discreet. The information outlined
is not only not generally known but not safe to know. To
speak of, or even hint at, some of the things revealed is
to invite the attention of the most unwelcome kind.

Caveat lector!

I, Signoret, sage and wizard, pupil of the late Hawklord,
and                            student of the Octocirculi Academy, being by virtue
of personal experience well informed where the more
extraordinary inhabitants of this world are concerned,
have decided to compile a bestiary. In so doing I have
been moved to create as accurate an account as possible
and thus I go beyond my own knowledge and quote
freely from sources I know to be reliable.

Herein are compiled the travelers’ tales of Nathal and
Virgil,                               the wisdom of the Duchess Sibyl, and the contents
of numerous grimoires, scrolls, and librams. I have
resorted to reading from an occult tome that describes
the city of Phantos; so appalling are the secrets therein
evealed that I quote them verbatim, lest some reader
accuse me of inventing its horrors. So too have I studied
the writings of witches both light and malign; I have
trawled through accursed works that give a seeker
knowledge — a terrible knowledge I would sometimes
rather forget.

Be clear that I have no fondness for the dark things I
describe;                              and yet I ofler what I have read of the motives
and goals of such terrible sorcerous entities as Lilith and
Baphomet without comment — let the reader ascertain
the truth of their claims or prove them a lie.

Grim indeed are the threats that face us, and if one
should                             wonder why any sane man stays in these lands,
then let him remember that not all is given over to
horror — there are good folk and good places aplenty
here in the realms of Ainerêve. The Guardians’ Guild is
one beacon of light against the darkness, but all
kingdoms cry out for more heroes and heroines. Will you
be of their number?

Lest the reader should balk at the sheer number and
variety                                of beasts, let us recall the gates leading to worlds
far and near, to places, times, and dimensions as diverse
as the universe itself. Every kind of creature comes
crawling, slithering, loping, or charging through the
gates at Crossroads — truly the gates are both blessing
and curse.

To better categorize and explain these beings I have
applied                                 a system of numerical gradation and probability
mapping; the discerning adventurer will see from the
number ranges that the danger of each creature, its
resistances and abilities, are all clearly expressed. Now,
on to a consideration of the beings an adventurer
passing through Crossroads or crossing the lands of
Ainerêve might meet. Gird your sword, ready your
shield; if magic be your trade, then prepare a spell — for
surely battle is upon you and the diflerence betwixt life
and death no more than a quick wit or a quicker blade.

333


BESTIARY


Accursed, the

Type: Minor (undead)

Threat Dice: Natural d6 ~ Melee d4 ~ Ranged d4

Extra Attacks: d8 rotting attack, once per round (see
below)

Hit Points: 10 (7/3) [fast, medium, magical; ×1.5]
Damage Reduction: d4 (natural toughness)
Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d3

Legends and Lore: The accursed are shambling,
moaning                          zombies determined to eat the flesh of the
living. They are found in unhallowed graveyards and
defiled temples where the priesthood and acolytes
were murdered by some rival, evil god’s minions.

Abilities and Powers: The accursed are undead
creatures                            devoid of will and without any ability to
speak of, other than inflicting harm. They are
immune to curses, mental affliction effects, and
other necromantic energies that would seek to harm
or control them. Each accursed also possesses a
rotting power. If this d8 attack penetrates a target’s
chosen active defense, it causes d4 to be lost from
the Passive Defense Pool (DP) each round until a
revitalization effect is used to stop it.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The accursed do not
generally wear armor; if one does, it’s falling apart
and basically useless. They cannot wield any weapon
that provides specific bonuses (being minor), but
they can be described as wielding whatever the GM
describes (mechanically, it makes no difference).

They carry only trinkets: 1–6 coins and 1% chance of
1                             minor magic item per group for treasure.

Ambulant Thresher

Type: Standard (plant)

Threat Dice: Natural 2d10

Extra Attacks: d10 (suffering slumber attack)
Hit                         Points: 40 (30/10) [fast, large, magical; ×2]
Damage Reduction: 4 (natural)

Saving Throw: d10

Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: Three summers past, the druid
Cathbad,                              when returning from some far distant
sphere, brought back with him three strange
seedlings. These plants, each with oddly tentacle-
like leaves, grew swiftly into life-threatening man-
eaters and multiplied rapidly. They now rove
woodlands seeking prey, and if unable to get it, will
quest even into villages or farms. According to
Nathal, who has hunted down a score of these
horrors, when fully grown a thresher resembles a
bulbous black cactus crowned with a quartet of long
purple tentacles. One can grow to twice the size of a
man. Its movement is a wobbling undulation of its
lower quarters that lets it ripple across the ground
with surprising swiftness. Why the threshers seek
out sentient prey is unknown; however, in the
Grimoire of Giseld, it is written that there are
unsettled realms where thoughts are food and where
pain-wracked consciousness can be channeled to
alien gods for whom suffering is sustenance. The
plant-beings were first known in Crossroads,
although they have spread across the land despite
the efforts of Nathal.

Abilities and Powers: A thresher can strike at
multiple                               foes with its tentacles; range equals its
trunk’s height — typically 5 to 12 feet. Strikes
penetrating to reduce Passive DP cause pain and
lethargy, so that those struck multiple times will be
slowed (save vs. Fortitude) and eventually slip into a
suffering slumber where they dream of torture and
death. Simultaneously, the thresher digs small roots
into their brains to drain nutrients and in time

334


extinguish life. The spiky projections on a thresher’s
trunk                            pose a hazard to one fighting it at close
quarters.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The cactus-like
trunk                                of the thresher is equal to hide armor; spikes
may strike an adversary in close melee (+1 to
potential harm when engaged unarmed or with short
weapons). They have no treasure, but legend has it
that eating the plant flesh of the thresher grants one
a glimpse of the final memories of its recent victims.

Afriti

Type: Exceptional

Threat Dice: Arcane 3d12 ~ Natural d6 ~ Melee d4 ~
Ranged d4

Hit Points: 72 (54/18) [fast, medium, preternatural;

×2]

Damage Reduction: Immune to fire, normal or
magical

Saving Throw: d12 or 3d12 versus Elementalism Fire
spells                              (other than Harm)

Battle Phase d16

Legends and Lore: There are combustible realms in
Ainerêve where fury flashes ignite into raging
elemental storms; such are elemental spheres of fire
and magma. The afriti, it is said, are but one of many
fire-beings that dwell in such inhospitable realms,
although the gnome explorer Sprouta claims they
have fashioned a city of sorts that floats upon an
ever-burning sea of flames.

Sparks of anger form the afriti; fire and smoke
bound                                into a shifting, sometimes man-like, form.
When they attack, their upper body blazes outwards
in a fan-like glare in which a hateful countenance
can be seen. As to their will and purposes, who can
say? But one summoned into our own realms is a
thing of spite and fury; if you meet one, lay it low, for
its anger cannot be quenched, not even in the depths
of the sea.

Abilities and Powers: The afriti are invulnerable to
fire;                            however, an attack, magical or otherwise, that
incorporates water or ice will cause double normal
harm. The afriti creates a field of fire about itself that
burns anyone close enough to strike a blow against
it. At will, it can project fire up to twenty feet away:
such a strike ignites combustible materials and
causes ongoing burns. It can envelop a foe in its body
of magma and flame, immolating its victim within
its fiery core.

He who binds an afriti can force it to do three tasks;
the                             greater amongst their number can cause reality
shifts sufficient to grant a wish, but not one that is
overly powerful or that disturbs the stability of a
given realm too much. Let summoner or binder
beware: all such wishes and tasks are fuelled by hate;
that which comes forth from anger is ignobly born,
and surely any creation of hate will bear bitter fruit.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: For occult reasons,
brass                            does not melt in the hands of an afriti; they
have an affinity for it, adorn themselves in curious
brazen jewelry, and sometimes bear other artifacts
of brass — likewise, fire opals, bloodstones, and
rubies are unharmed by an afriti’s fiery touch.

Treasure carried is in the range of a trove: 200–2000
coins                             and a 30% chance of d3 magic items.

Amphisbaena

Type: Exceptional

Threat Dice: Arcane 3d8 ~ Natural 3d6

Hit Points: 72 (18/54) [tough, huge, preternatural;

×3]

Damage Reduction: Immune to mental and spiritual
afflictions

Saving Throw: d10

Battle Phase d4

Legends and Lore: Ouroboros unbound; cyclicity
become                             chaos; in essence, a large snake with a head
at each end of its broad barrel-like body with mouths
big enough to swallow a horse whole. Around the

335


BESTIARY


amphisbaena, vegetation spoils and dies. Only in
water                              does it regain tranquility. If submerged
beneath the water, one head swallows the other, and
Ouroboros is reborn. From whence does it come?

From dreams of greed, I am told, that cause
Ouroboros                                to unbind; the natural order is usurped by
lust for something — usually wealth or power. That
which should be tranquil and peaceful, wise and
eternal, becomes a raging coiling avatar of death.

Abilities and Powers: One of the cavernous
serpentine                             maws can breathe poisonous vapors; the
other has fangs dripping a dreadful green caustic
venom that pits the very ground it falls upon.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: True to the greed
that                               gave it birth, the amphisbaena always seeks, or
possessively guards, some object of desire — it will
be a thing of great value, whether financial, magical,
or living: a person, an artist, a beauty, a creator or an
inventor may be taken this way. A traveler from
Meath, one whose beard was green, hinted to me
that at times the very victim of the amphisbaena is
its creator, although how or why that should be is a
mystery upon which I cannot comment.

Angel

Type: Legendary

Threat Dice: Melee 2d12+8 ~ Ranged 2d10+5 ~
Natural 2d8+7 ~ Arcane d12+5

Hit Points: 60 (30/30) [normal, nedium,
supernatural; ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: By armor, shield, or magic item.

Saving Throw: 2d10

Battle Phase d10 or d12

Legends and Lore: Angels are beatific celestial
beings,                                as one would probably imagine. There’s not
some imperative that each has to have a pair of
wings, much less a harp, but all will be powerful, not
only in might but also in wisdom. Angels are
symbolic of all that is just and holy in the spiritual
world. They often serve as proxies to the celestial

gods. Their incarnation in the mortal realm is usually
humanoid and of the most handsome and superior
sort but depends on its associated deity and culture.
A high-ranking priest may summon one, or the
master deity may send an archangel on a mission to
the mortal realm. They are proud and willful, rarely
merciful if provoked, and do not take direct
commands unless issued by a higher power. An angel
does not ordinarily stay around once its mission is
finished unless it must guard some important, holy
place. Archangels are supposed to exist, few in
number but even more powerful: the radiance of
their glory is said to burn up mere mortals who gaze
on them.

Abilities and Powers: An angel’s average ability is at
a                               d12 (basic) + d12 (specialty). Angels typically have
adept, Theurgist, and warrior advantages and
theurgist feats; but just about any skill imaginable is
possible. Languages spoken include the common
trade language, plus Celestial. Also, angels can
invoke the following powers using their Arcane
threat dice:

Spiritual blast (Challenge Die d8, Save None): A
harmful                             stream of brilliant, electric-blue light that
sears the target’s soul, bypassing Agility DP. Add +4
to Challenge Die to make it an area effect spell.

Command the infidel (Challenge Die d10, Save
Fortitude → Willpower): The angel intones a
command, and the target cannot help but obey.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Any weapon and
any                              armor, usually magical with up to +5 in bonuses
to protection or damage. Their usually ranged
weapon is a bow. Angels may have any piece of
equipment desired but do not carry food, coin, or
other sundries because they don’t have bodily needs.
They will carry a magic item other than their
weapons 85% of the time — usually an orb or wand
of some kind. Typically, angels carry a special holy
weapon (any type) with the following properties:

336


Holy Weapon: The general properties of the weapon
match                                that of the type. It has up to a +5 bonus to
damage. It can also do +8 non-physical Energy harm
once a round (this is a permanent effect). In the
hands of an angel, a holy weapon does triple damage
versus demons (including the bonus and non-
physical harm).

Anthropophagi

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Natural 2d6 ~ Melee d4

Hit Points: 18 (9/9) [normal, medium, magical; ×1.5]

Damage Reduction: –2 versus natural or
bludgeoning attacks

Saving Throw: d4 to d8, immune to mental affliction

Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: My source for information about
these                            man-like cannibals may not be reliable. Much
of what I am told comes from the goblinoid half-orc
Throk. He tells me he has seen the dreaded Revel of
Flesh, a dance and unholy feasting conjured up from
the darkest pits. He saw the anthropophagi, their
near-naked bodies deformed by the spirit-energy of
the victims they eat — frightened faces bulge from
bellies, extra eyes open on arms, a second face on the
back of the head, writhing mouths opening like
wounds on torso and limb. Among them are the most
fearsome of their kind, the blemmyes, so deformed
as to now resemble little more than a headless torso
of combined flesh, a trunk from which sprout arms
and legs at awkward angles, askew, misaligned. A
great face forms in the midst of the torso, its thick-
lipped mouth full of teeth and ready to devour yet
more men. The Revel of Flesh is spreading, I am told;
it is a dance writhing in the shadows and at night the
anthropophagi stumble, bumble, and tumble into
moonlit groves to begin a hunt for more eyes and
mouths to join their horrid feasting.

Abilities and Powers: Attacks are a mixture of bites
and                         clubbing strikes; if a victim is grappled, he will
be bitten many times. A bite from a blemmyes will

337

induce a blasphemous craving in a victim, an unholy
desire                                 to dance and feast on the flesh of men, or
worse still, a desire to be eaten, a wish to be
consumed (save vs. Fortitude → Willpower, once at
the time of the bite, then once per day).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Incidental wealth
may                            abound; anthropophagi have no use for a
victim’s possessions — they will be scattered, as
may be entrails and body parts, in the wake of their
dreadful dance. It is possible that within one of these
cannibals, an item of value might be found, eaten
thoughtlessly as its struggling owner was devoured.

Arimaspians

Type: Standard; some exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural d6 ~ Arcane 2d6 ~ Melee d10 ~
Ranged d8

Hit Points: 20-60 (15/15 to 30/30) [normal, medium,
magical;                               ×1.5]

Damage Reduction: Immune to Elementalism (Air)
spells

Saving Throw: 2d10

Battle Phase d10+2

Legends and Lore: Of the arimaspians, I speak with
authority, for I was a “guest” of their Duke
Pathafarial in his cloud-borne palace. A single eye
glares from the forehead of these cyclops-like
human-sized warriors. They are ruthless reavers,
plunderers of gold — they are adorned with gold
jewelry and lust after the metal. Dressed in
flamboyant nautical garments, they have a bronze,
almost gold, hue to their skin and an evil demeanor.
They enslave griffins and are oft encountered
mounted upon or leading such beasts. They are
pirates of the skies, flying upon their fearsome
subjugated steeds.

Abilities and Powers: They can conjure forth mists
and                             winds, and the greatest amongst them can cause
clouds to become as ice and bring forth sleet or snow

— among their own kind, these wielders of
elemental                            magic are called navigators. An ice cloud


BESTIARY


formed as a flying creature passes through it
becomes                                 a prison (Challenge Die d10; save vs.
Fortitude). The ice clouds stay aloft unless cast to
earth by the arimaspian sorcerer. Their warriors,
invariably led by a flamboyant or aggressive captain,
wield cutlasses, and some bear fearsome weapons of
metal and wood that can shoot balls of lead into a
man’s heart. These somehow make use of an
alchemical black powder. Only the arimaspians and
the sea elves know the secrets of such “pistols,” as
they name them. Flying ships have been reported,
upon which are mounted siege engines of iron and
flame, so-called “cannons,” able, they say, to lay
low a city from the air.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Gold, jewels,
enchanted                           weapons, magical items that grant the
power of flight, even flying ships, islands, and
palaces, all await the adventuring band that can
defeat the arimaspians. Their cutlasses add bonus
threat points to Melee attacks with microbursts of air
at every point of impact (+1 threat point per strike).
Some also wield bizarre weapons that belch noise,
fire, and brimstony smoke, as below.

Alchemical black powder “pistol.” Roll Ranged
ability                           against Challenge Die d4 to hit; a 12 bypasses
all armor. Threat points equal Prowess → Agility →
Ranged Threat.

Banshee

Type: Legendary

Threat Dice: Arcane 3d14 ~ Melee 2d4 ~ Natural
d6+4                           ~ Ranged d4

Hit Points: 105 (53/52) [normal, medium,
supernatural; ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: –2 against all potential harm

Saving Throw: d12, or 2d14 versus spiritual
afflictions

Battle Phase d10

Legends and Lore: Fearsome spirit-women of
Maedoen,                              the banshee are harbingers of death. Oft
appearing as old crones holding out bloodied

clothing, with sly grins upon their age-wracked
faces;                                 it is said that a warrior recognizing his own
garb in the banshee’s claws is doomed. Alternatively,
the banshee might take the guise of a fair maid to
lead a warrior astray — to where something horrid
lies in wait. In the library of Duchess Sibyl, I found a
scroll reportedly penned by the Eldritch Man. It says
the banshee seek vengeance for every bitter and
heartless deed warrior-men have done and that they
shall take vengeance until moon and sun shine
together in a darkened sky.

Abilities and Powers: One who sees his own clothes
in                                the banshee’s grasp, hears her mournful and
frightsome keening wail, or is led away by her from
his comrades into the dark wood, mist, or mire, falls
under a curse, and death will stalk him by day and by
night. (Save versus Willpower, or else suffer +2
potential harm from all traps and hazards, plus –1
rank per tier on all Saving Throws until the curse is
lifted.)

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Some locations, the
sites                               of remorseless deeds perhaps, become nexial
gathering places for the banshee, and in such locales,
the bodies of many warriors might lie, adorned still
with armor and treasures, with sword and steel.

Baphomet

Type: Legendary (avatar)

Threat Dice: Arcane 3d12 ~ Melee 3d12 ~ Ranged
2d12~                          Natural 2d10

Hit Points: 108 (81/27) [fast, large, supernatural; ×3]

Damage Reduction: d12 (plate armor)

Saving Throw: 3d14

Battle Phase d14

Legends and Lore: Here I shall write of that which
men                                call Baphomet; I find little, even in the darkest
grimoires, to tell me the truth of this being that some
claim is demonic, but for certain he has truck with
much that is demoniacal and of the shadow. There
are the oddest hints, webs of thought linking

338


Baphomet with the Templar Knights, but how can
this                             be? They that so staunchly, even heartlessly,
cleanse (or persecute?) all they deem heretics,
witches, or demonists, let alone demons, how can
they have any communion with the Sabbatic Goat?

Baphomet can put on the guise of any man or spirit

— why, some scrolls even claim any god — that he
chooses. The avatar so assumed can take many
forms, but when contemplating Baphomet, the
reader of this bestiary is best served by considering
Baphomet’s accepted image — half male, half
female, the body parts of human and goat, phallic in
its strength, creative in its potency; an embodiment
of occult and alchemical concepts and power.

To the inner cabal of those who secretly worship
Baphomet,                              his existence is known to be the result of
all humanity’s desires, all magical workings, the
wizardly attempts to lift humanity’s status of the
divine. To the true Baphomet believer, there are no
real gods, no true devils — both are manifestations
of limitation; artificialities created by human
consciousness fearing its own power; thus, they say,
men have made two masters, two rods for our backs.
And yet, their texts say the power of freedom will not
be denied, so we have fashioned an occult key in
addition to our prison. That key is Baphomet, and
both Heaven and Hell fear the nullification
Baphomet will bring: death, night, and a new dawn
in a new Eden — one built by the true will of man.

Baphomet hates the powers of Hell and all so-
called                               gods, whether divine or darkly satanic: they
are artificialities that existed before him (or so he
and his adherents claim) and obstacles to his will. He
would undo the whole of creation, turn it back to
primal matter, so that man can start again and build
a better and more fitting world — or so Baphomet
believes. All gods are demiurges, craftsmen of
inferior skill who have built a prison for life rather
than paradise to their followers. In this view,
Baphomet is “good” because he will liberate life by
destroying the illusion/matter that binds us. Good
and Evil both are part of the system Baphomet would

destroy. And thus it is that Baphomet seeks some
method                                to undo creation here in Ainerêve; to reshape
Earth via humanity’s dreams — to reorder reality in
reverse from the dream world back into the physical.
To do this, he must gain power here, and he plays a
long game, willing to take centuries, for what are
years when placed against eternity? Heaven and Hell
have become aware of his strategies. They have
woven a web of energy, light, and dark across
Ainerêve to bind Baphomet’s power as best they may
go through a strange and unexpected alliance. In
response, Lilith, Baphomet’s bride — and some say
creatrix — has sent her presence too, seeking a way
to free her consort’s full energies once more.

Abilities and Powers: Although many forms might be
taken, I have read of three (all extraordinary
mortals): the knight, the bard, and the emissary. The
knight brings war, is garbed in impenetrable steel, is
fear made manifest, and can stand in tourney against
any champion. The bard would appear to bring
merriment, and jovial clowns may follow in his
wake; quick of wit and sharp eye, he makes a play of
every drama he sees and stirs drama where peace
once prevailed. Quick to feel boredom and
carelessness of those he might hurt, he moves on
swiftly after spreading his stage across a tavern,
village, or even a kingdom. The emissary he offers
much, is peace made real; soft, kind, cheerful, quick
to please others, and ever wanting the approval of
those he meets, and yet, if it is not given, he will fall
into the depths of sorrow, and swiftly thereafter fade
beneath the shadow, and in his going call forth bard
or knight — or something even more fearsome,
bestial, and dark.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Any. Without
exception,                         Baphomet’s avatars will be adorned with
strange, often cursed and dangerous, items of the
most complex sorcery. Baphomet may choose to
leave such behind when seemingly defeated; indeed,
his whole purpose for coming might be to leave a
trinket, an item worthy of Pandora, when he departs.

339


BESTIARY


Treasure possessed is a hoard: 1000–10,000 coins
but                           100% chance of 4 magic items.

Basilisk

Type: Standard to Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 2d10 to 3d10 ~ Ranged (special)

~ Arcane (special)

Extra Attacks: Killing miasma, gaze, and rotting bite

Hit Points: 60 to 90 (15/45 to 23/67) [tough, huge,
preternatural; ×3)

Damage Reduction: +2 hit points (tough hide)

Saving Throw: d10 to d12

Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: Existing in multiple forms, or
perhaps                            breeds, the basilisk is the king of serpents,
distinguished by a crown-like crest and a single
white spot between its narrow reptilian eyes —
unlike other serpents, its eyes are man-like, with
heavily hooded lids and a pronounced slant. In youth
no more than twelve fingers in length, the thing
grows both in size and danger, so that when fully
grown, it rears up to the height of a man atop a
horse, and in length exceeds that of three horses.

Abilities and Powers: Greater basilisks exude a
killing                             miasma, so their very presence causes death,
not only in man but in beast and plant too; where
goes the basilisk, there goes death and decay and
desert. Their glance is fatal, stopping breath; their
bite so caustic that the venom penetrates not only
the victim but also anything or anyone touching the
victim. A basilisk biting a horse will kill its rider too,
the very skin and flesh rotting from man and mount,
leaving nothing but bones and skulls, half-clothed in
the flesh.

Killing miasma: Any creature within 5 feet must save
versus Fortitude or fall incapacitated and take d10 to
3d10 harm every round thereafter, depending on the
basilisk’s size and age.

Gaze: Victim must roll vs. Competence → Perception
to                             avert gaze else suffer harm directly to Passive

Defense (d10 to 3d10, depending on the basilisk’s
size                           and age).

Rotting bite: Regular shields and armor can protect
the                            defender but make item saving throws versus the
basilisk’s threat rank dice or be destroyed. Make a
Fortitude save if even one point reduces Passive DP;
failure to save inflicts another threat dice roll
affecting Passive DP.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: I am told by the
elven                             traveler Nathal that a visitor to the Seelie Court
brought a tale told in the east, that each basilisk
guards a gem of great size (value 10,000–60,000 in
coin), and that if this gem is properly incubated, a
dragon will come forth from it. Of the truth of this, I
cannot say.

Brownie

Type: Minor to Standard

Threat Dice: Any attack type, d4 to 2d4

Hit Points: 4 to 8 (2/2 to 4/4) [normal, tiny, magical;

×1]

Damage Reduction: –1 if wearing properly sized
brownie armor

Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d4 to d8

Legends and Lore: The brownie is a tiny shee that
dwells                             unseen in the homes of mortals. Small men
and women with weedy arms and legs, clothed in
scraps of cloth and often with an acorn, thimble, or
spider-web shawl worn on the head; their spindly-
fingered hands are quick to perform all household
chores, and they can mend and fix too. If spied out of
the corner of the eye, one might be seen clutching
needle and thread, set upon useful tasks like
repairing socks, or busily knocking the dents out of a
damaged pot.

But a home blessed with brownies had best not
mention                               or watch the little things; they are shy and
wary, dislike attention, and will seek another home if
disturbed. Small gifts, a little milk, some cheese, and

340


bread perhaps, or maybe some cloth that they might
sew,                             will earn the brownies’ favor — but only if
given discreetly, without seeming to recognize the
little people’s presence at all.

Abilities and Powers: Brownies have magic of a kind
sort                              that helps with fixing, hiding, and bringing luck.
But if harmed, they can leave curses and misfortune,
cause hammers to hit fingers, pots to crack,
cauldrons to overflow, and hearth fires either to burn
too hot or fade and go out.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: It is a common
error                                 of all-too-greedy men to mistake the brownie
for some other type of shee altogether and seek from
it some fabled and non-existent pot of gold as if the
thing were a miserly leprechaun — doing so is
unwise. The foolhardy mortal who treats a brownie
so will regret it until the end of his stubbed-toed,
broken-tooled days. They do often carry trinkets: 1–
6 coins and 1% chance of 1 minor magic item.

Capture Vine

Type: Minor (plant)

Threat Dice: Natural d12 (capture & constriction)
Hit                          Points 18 (6/12) [tough, large, magical; ×1.5]
Damage Reduction: +3 (tough nature)

Saving Throw: d4 to d8 versus physical

Battle Phase It doesn’t move; d10 for initiative when
in striking distance.

Legends and Lore: There’s always some sort of plant
life                               out in the world that wants to kill you. Capture
vines prefer a slow death for their victims. The
sentient vine will detect warm blood, lash out, wrap
its vines around the neck or torso, and pull its victim
to its central stalk, where thousands of hollow
needles prick the skin and drain the blood. If the
plant wins surprise, it can bring out a vine to capture
and constrict with amazing speed. However, it is
otherwise immobile, its central stalk being rooted
into something organic: the soil, timber, even a dead
body.

Abilities and Powers: In the first round, the vine rolls
d12                            against the target’s Prowess → Agility (Reaction):
success means capture. In the round after a capture,
an opposed roll of d12 is made versus the victim’s
Prowess. If the victim succeeds, he can escape.

Otherwise, he will take d12 points of constriction
damage                          to Passive DP, with armor adding to the
damage (roll its value and add).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The Capture Vine
has                            natural “armor” of d8 because its stalks and
vines are very tough to break or cut. Plants don’t
carry treasure.

Centaur

Type: Standard to legendary

Threat Dice: Natural 2d6 ~ Melee 2d4 ~ Ranged 2d4

~ Arcane d4 (10%)

Extra Attacks: Kick d10+4

Hit Points: 24 (6/18) [tough, large, magical; ×2]
Damage Reduction: +2 (large and tough hide)
Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d10+d6 (speed)

Legends and Lore: The centaur has the lower body of
a                               horse but the torso, arms, and head of a man. Two
distinct species exist, albeit some claim that they are
the same, their natures changing when provoked or
roused to lust. No matter, whether two species, or
one in which two natures war, the practicalities are
the same: in some the animal nature dominates —
this is the animal-side of man given form here in the
vision-world of Ainerêve; he is bestial, drunken,
savage, prone to heavy drinking, acts of debauchery,
and even rape. However, at times, or in one
variation, the centaur represents what nature and
the animal kingdom can teach man: he is a scholar, a
teacher — such centaurs are wise, learned, and
might even impart knowledge and skill to children of
men. In Crossroads, the arrival of centaurs causes
unease; the Guardians’ Guild has requested that all
such beings be prevented from drinking alcohol.

341


BESTIARY


Abilities and Powers: Centaurs are excellent archers,
huntsmen, and warriors, unparalleled in their skill
with the spear, club, and bow. Some few, of both
variations, can cause trees to walk, animals to do
their will, and the forces of nature to accommodate
their wishes — but this capacity is rare (10%
chance), and the workings of such wonders seem
more incidental than planned, instinctive rather
than deliberate.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The cerebrally
inclined                        species of centaur may possess ancient
knowledge and scrolls, although they rarely work
magic. Centaurs travel light, but many possess in
their domiciles a trove: 200–2000 coins and 30%
chance of d3 magic items.

Changeling

Type: Standard (fay)

Threat Dice: Arcane 2d8 ~ Melee 2d6 ~ Natural 2d8 ~
Ranged 2d4

Hit Points: 40 (30/10) [fast, large, preternatural;

×2.5]

Damage Reduction: By any armor worn

Saving Throw: d16

Battle Phase d10+4

Legends and Lore: Doppelganger infiltrators
spreading                            paranoia and dissension everywhere while
fostering distrust and mystery, changelings are part
of the various societies of the Fay, living mostly in
the great forest of Meath. They waylay travelers from
settled lands to steal their shiniest possessions or
walk throughout the kingdoms seeking to seduce or
lure hapless folk into the dark of the forest, where
human souls are forsaken and memories lost.

Abilities and Powers: Changelings are masters of
deceit                             and trickery, with a high level of skill in
Competence → Adroitness → Skullduggery, ranging
from 2d6+2 to 2d12+5 depending on their expertise.
They possess the ability to shapeshift into the
semblance of any humanoid species, short or tall,

with their powers limited to the range of “self” and
requiring no Ability tests. This makes them highly
adaptable and dangerous in social encounters.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Changelings can use
any weapon or armor, limited only by the size of the
form assumed at the time. Their equipment melds
into a new form during a shape-shift but can be
willed back onto the body and into hands after the
change. Changelings often keep their treasure in
their domiciles, typically a small trove of 100–600
coins with a 20% chance of d2 magic items. When
encountered, they may carry trinkets, and 20% of
those encountered will have some sort of magic item,
often designed to block psychogenic power or
scrying.

Cockatrice

Type: Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 3d4

Extra Attacks: Petrification

Hit Points: 24 [normal, large, magical; ×2]

Damage Reduction: None

Saving Throw: 2d8 or d4 versus mental harm

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: The cockatrice is a dragon-like
combination                               of serpent and cockerel; its head is a
fighting cock with a sharp beak and wide eyes.

Likewise, its two limbs are feathered, positioned at
the                               fore of its serpentine, coiling body, where they
can be used in movement, or to strike with vicious
bird-like talons. Its body has a warty, toad-like
appearance. The creature is large, twice the height of
a man.

Abilities and Powers: Fearsome indeed is this fabled
bird,                              for it can turn a man to stone — some by
pecking, others by a talon strike, a few by glance
alone, and, so I am informed by the priests of Astra,
who claim to have subdued such a creature, there are
cockatrices with the dragon-like breath, a poisonous

342


fume that brings either petrification or a slow
choking death.

Petrification: Every time threat points exceed active
defense and armor, the victim must make a save
versus Fortitude → Willpower or immediately take
3d4 points to Passive DP. The victim is turned to
stone permanently if Passive DP depletes to zero.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The cockatrices like
their                          reflections and will gather up gold and position
shiny metals, so they glimpse themselves passing by.
Curiously, in the presence of a cockatrice, gold
develops a greenish sheen, and silver slowly fades to
a tarnished black. A party of treasure seekers set out
from Crossroads one autumn, seeking the cockatrice
called Ignatious by the fay folk of Meath; a treasure
hunt was this, sadly unsuccessful, but the two that
returned alive from the dark statue-studded glen
where Ignatious roams and pecks claim it to be filled
with treasures.

Demon

Type: Legendary

Threat Dice: Melee 3d16 ~ Arcane 2d12 ~ Natural
2d18                           ~ Ranged 2d12

Hit Points: 120 (60/60) [normal, medium,
supernatural; ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: By any armor worn

Saving Throw: 2d12*

Battle Phase d10

Legends and Lore: Demons are malignant spiritual
tumors,                              the cloacal concentrations of every foulness,
sniggering malice, brutality, perversion, and
derangement in the mind of man. Their form is thus
often humanoid but twisted: leering, evil-visaged,
bat-winged, horned; their nature is protean, so some
have fearful forms out of nightmare or can even
assume a pleasing shape for a while to seduce or
deceive. They serve infernal powers and themselves.
Luckily they are so chaotic and violent that they
spend as much time infighting as defiling or

destroying the good. Demons, like angels, are nearly
demigods and are not to be thrown into the path of
adventurers on a whim. Possessing supernatural
strength and skill, these creatures inflict devastating
amounts of damage, are cruel beyond measure, have
high resistance to magic, and grant no mercy.

Furthermore, they can summon hordes of minions to
aid them — up to 2d20 devilish imps per round (TY
Minor / TD Melee d4 ~ Natural d4 ~ Ranged d4 ~
Arcane d4 / HP 4).

Abilities and Powers: Demons can know just about
any                               skill and possess any imagined ability. They can
see in the dark or cast any Elementalism (Fire),
Sorcery, or Hieraticism spell with an effect of Afflict,
Harm, or Modify. They use the Arcane rank of 2d20
for all spells and innate powers causing damage or
other effects. Their innate powers have no Challenge
Dice:

Infernal blaSaving Throw: A harmful bolt of fiery red
energy sears the target for 2d20 harm.

Command the weak: (Save Fortitude → Willpower):
The                          demon intones a command, and the target’s
body cannot help but obey.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Demons wear any
armor, wield any weapon (with weapon-based
bonuses), and possess vast treasure in their abodes
(hoard: 1000–10,000 coins and 40% chance of 4
esoteric or better magic items).
