BESTIARY


Dragon

Type: Exceptional (often Legendary)

Threat Dice: Natural 3d10 to 3d12 ~ Arcane 3d10 to
3d12 (dragon breath)

Extra Attacks: Tail lash or buffeting wings 2d4 to
2d14*

Hit Points: 90 to 108 [normal, large to gargantuan*,
magical;                          ×1.5 to ×4*]

Damage Reduction: d12 natural scale armor, +1 per
stage*

Saving Throw: 3d10, +1 per stage*

Battle Phase d10

* Die rank or value generally depends on age; see
below.

Foolhardy are the adventurers of every world, every
realm, and as those passing through Crossroads are
no different, I will include in this bestiary a
description of those fabled beasts called dragons. But
first, a word to the wise, a suggestion to every

would-be dragon hunter: don’t! Do not seek out the
great                             wyrms, go not near their cavernous abodes,
pretend for all the world that they do not exist, and
hope beyond hope that one never decides to seek out
you.

Now, as this advice will doubtless be ignored, we
move                                on to the creatures themselves, although truth
be told, they deserve their own volume. When met in
the flesh (or in the scale?), a dragon is much as
traditionally depicted — a fiery, flying, scaled
monstrosity; its wings are bat-like, its body
serpentine. They have varying limbs, hues, and
abilities: four-legged, fire-breathing specimens are
the most widely reported. And yet, be prepared for
more snake-like horrors, with but two forepaws, or
six-legged examples that will sweep down upon you,
blast you to the floor with their wings, and then
snatch you up with your companions, fly high, and
drop you. Some dragons are tied to a single element.
Thus there are storm dragons of the air, water
dragons of the deep, rock-like dragons, and even
lava dragons. Cultural influences too shape the

dragon and its powers; thus, I am told, in certain
oriental                          realms, the dragons’ harbor wisdom rather
than hatred — a manifestation of cultural
expectation, not of the act that created the creature.

Legends and Lore: I have many reports, and yet I
must                                 be concise. Perhaps a consideration of what
forms most dragons is in order. Dragons are born in
unsettled lands; they are stray currents of energy,
usually, but not always, of a negative kind. When
some great and powerful evil occurs on Earth — a
massacre, an act of genocide, or some other
terrifying evil — the psychic repercussions would
disrupt any settled land, no matter how close it hews
to its earthly archetype, and so the waves of
unfulfilled destiny manifest in Ainerêve as a
vengeance-seeking beast. The fearful, hateful,
angry, primitive core of its mind is a collective
creation of those Earth-bound people whose
horrifying death created the dragon — their anxiety,
grief, fury, and despair. Normally dragons are drawn
to travel the unsettled lands until they reach the
borders of a settled realm, one with a culture the
dragon’s subconscious collective memory recalls.

Often this initial manifestation takes the form of an

egg; I am told some dragons breed true, and thus, if
two meet, they can create more eggs, a ripple of
destruction that has crippled kingdoms, laid low
empires, and killed more adventurers than legends
can count.

Abilities and Powers: We will speak first of typical
dragons                                if any can be called such; a plume of fiery
breath, hot enough to sear the flesh from bone; if
airborne, a deadly swoop, snatch, lift and drop;
hovering, blindness caused by whirled up soil and
debris, plus strikes from every claw; a lashing tail
that can knock even an ogre prone. Yes, those but
recently hatched are easier to destroy, but where you
see whelps, be ready for their larger kin. The dragon
is sharp in all its senses, with the eyes of a hawk;
although prone to slumber, they awaken easily. I
have read of great invincible beasts that, sleeping for

344


centuries, grow so vast that the awakening of such
leads                             to cultural nullification and extinction in
surrounding realms — if the beast is evil, and most
are.

A dragon’s breath is magic energy, made of fire, cold,
lightning, or other destructive forms. Whatever the
type of breath weapon, the dragon is immune to that
type of damage. (Dragons increase in size and power
with age, in 6 stages: whelp, young, adult, old, elder,
ancient / TD, d10, d12, d14, d16, d18, d20 / EA d4, d6,
d8, d10, d12, d14 / HP ×1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4.)

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Dragons gather
treasure                               out of instinct, for, despite their often great
intellect, they are driven by the primitive lustful part
of their brain. The dragon is greedy in every regard,
not just in the eating of men but also in their goods’
plundering. Caches of weapons, antique armor,
masses of gold and silver, statuettes and gems, not
to mention antiques, librams, and magics rare, will
all be found in the abode of a long-lived dragon (a
typical dragon’s hoard: 10,000–60,000 coins and
50% chance of 8 magic items).

Dwarf

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Natural d8 ~ Melee d8 ~ Ranged d4 ~
Arcane d4

Hit Points: 12 (3/9) [tough, medium, magical; ×1.5]
Damage Reduction: By armor and shield type
Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d4 to 6 average

Legends and Lore: Sons of the deep earth, born from
maggots hatched in a giant’s innards, according to
some; to others, a species forged by the primordial
gods themselves to be the lords of the earth and the
guardians of its secrets. In my own realm, so
common is the dwarvish race that to describe them
in a bestiary such as this would seem insulting; and
yet I am mindful that here in Crossroads, there is a
meeting of realms and realities, and not all who pass
this way will be familiar with this short, squat

345

humanoid race. How to describe a typical dwarf?
Could                               one describe a typical man? Let us picture a
man-like being, not dissimilar to the warrior races
that inhabit the northern Thule-like realms of some
Earth-realities. Standing less than five feet tall,
sometimes only four, the dwarf is small but
powerfully built, with muscles typically sheathed in
finely crafted mail of plate, for the dwarves are
smiths, master armorers, and weapon-crafters.

Not a few of their race know the secret of forging
magic                           weapons and other artifacts of strange
enchantment. One can’t discuss dwarves without
commenting on their beards, typically worn long,
ornamented, and styled. Length of beard is an
indicator of age, gold beads an indicator of the
station, and style an indicator of personality. Beware
the dwarf whose beard is unkempt; most likely, he is
a berserker or renegade.

And yet, there are many species of dwarf, some
black-hearted rather than stoic, some greedy rather
than taciturn. I have noted a species of dwarf that
passes oft through Crossroads and might be said to
dominate here in Ainerêve. They are the scions of a
stable realm connected to Crossroads called the Iron
Dome. They call themselves Nordwur and are garbed
in Viking-like gear (for those unfamiliar with
Scandinavian lore’s stable realms, picture a warrior
armed with round shield, cap-like metal helm with
partial face guard, mail armor, axe, and spear). They
are somewhat leaner of limb, paler of skin, and slyer
in demeanor than is otherwise common. They trade
in strange treasures, are greedy and dishonest, and
can forge powerful weapons, but beware their gifts
and trades, be careful of their bespiked, rune-cut
weapons forged of black steel.

Race reads better than Species for the most part.
Also,                              why dwarves here but not elves? Including
them in a bestiary is much less insulting than calling
them maggots…

Abilities and Powers: Typically, skilled with an axe,
maul, crossbow, and other arms; some have an


BESTIARY


ability to weave enchantments into the items they
forge                            (magic is of Earth Elementalism sort). For the
Nordwur, these enchantments come at a price to the
user, a curse of sorts that might give what the owner
seeks while taking away what he loves most.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Expect arms and
armor                                of the highest quality; often a goodly portion
of gold and gems, for even the most honorable of
dwarves has a dragon’s heart where the treasure is
concerned.

Elemental

Type: Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 3d6 to 3d12 ~ Arcane 3d6 to
3d12

Hit Points: 63 to 126 [any constitution, huge,
supernatural; ×3.5]

Damage Reduction: Immune to one elemental
sphere;                     same as composition

Saving Throw: d16 or 2d8

Battle Phase d12 to d20

Legends and Lore: Elementals are creatures of pure
Fire,                               Air, Earth, Water, or Energy. The building
blocks of Earthly creation, when combined they can
form material worlds — although doing so provokes
the wrath of their near-godlike elemental overlords,
who regard such creation as an abridgment of their
liberty. As the dream realms of Ainerêve settle into
substantial form, elementals can become ensnared
in the new realities, combined in physical
substantiality. They dislike this, and if broken free by
spell or mishap, will seek vengeance unless correctly
bound.

Abilities and Powers: Individual elementals vary in
threat dice, prowess, etc. Elementals can use any
elemental spell of their element, with no Challenge
Die needed. Their ranged attacks are magic
elemental threat points: elemental bolts or areas of
effect (up to Ranged × 2 feet radius) of 3d6 to 3d12
harm.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Elementals do not
carry weapons, armor, or treasure.

Elf

Type: Minor to full-fledged

Threat Dice: Melee d8 ~ Ranged d8 ~ Arcane d6 ~
Natural d4

Hit Points: 8 (4/4) [normal, medium, mundane]
Damage Reduction: By armor and shield type
Saving Throw: d10

Battle Phase: d8 to d12

Legends and Lore: Elves, rulers of the Forest of
Meath                                 as noted in the Bestiary of Signoret, are
known for their near-immortal nature, mastery of
bow and spell, and deep love for music, woodcraft,
and the wild. They cohabit closely with humans and
other races, sharing cultural traits such as a passion
for artistry and a profound connection to nature. The
various types of elves differ in their affinities and
lifestyles, each group adapting to its unique
environment and societal structure.

Varieties of Elves: High Elves are tall, graceful, and
noble,                                akin to kings among their kind. Though often
aloof, they possess deep magical knowledge and a
purity of heart. Forest Elves, also known as Wyld
Elves, embody the spirit of nature and are carefree
yet formidable in battle, with a strong bond to
woodland creatures. Sea Elves are masters of the
seas, exploring and occasionally raiding in their
magically powered ships, while Elves of Seadeep
dwell beneath the waves, with gills for breathing
underwater, residing in coral palaces among marine
life. Dark Elves, in contrast, are sinister and
accursed, living in subterranean caverns and
indulging in dark arts and cruel pursuits.

Credran (Elf)

Type: Exceptional Fay/Elves

Threat Dice: Melee d8 ~ Ranged d6 ~ Power d8
(elemental magic)

Hit Points: 40 to 60 [Constitution: High, Size:
Medium,                          Nature: Preternatural; HP Multiplier: ×1.5
to ×2]

Armor Rating: D6 (natural)

Saving Throw: d6+2

Battle Phase: d8

Legends and Lore: The Credran are exceptional elves
deeply connected to the Echoes Forest, a mystical
woodland where the material and dream realms
intertwine. They are known for their strong
connection to nature and mastery of elemental
magic. The Credran are the guardians of the Dran, a
powerful elemental spirit, and their covenant with
this spirit grants them elemental abilities, with each
leader embodying one of the primal elements—
wind, earth, fire, or night.

The Credran’s history is marked by both triumph
and                            tragedy, with the most notable event being the
fall of Prince Mathin the Gray, who succumbed to the
temptations of dark power. This betrayal
transformed him and eleven others into
Woodshades, a reminder of the delicate balance the
Credran must maintain between light and dark.

Abilities and Powers: The Credran wield elemental
magic                               tied to their forest home. They can manipulate
wind to disorient enemies, summon earth to entrap
or protect, conjure fire to purify or devastate, and
cloak themselves in shadows to move unseen. They
also possess the unique ability to summon echoes of
the past, using these reverberations to gain insight
or confuse their foes. Their shape-shifting abilities
enable them to assume the forms of animals native
to the Echoes Forest, enhancing their ability to blend
into their surroundings or ambush intruders.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The Credran craft
their                       weapons and armor from the enchanted
resources of the Echoes Forest. Their bows, made
3f4r7om sacred trees imbued with forest magic, strike

true and with great force, while their blades, forged
from                        elemental stones, carry the earth’s power.

Credran armor, woven from living vines or
enchanted                             leaves, offers protection while
maintaining agility. The treasures of the Credran
reflect their deep connection to elemental forces and
their history, often including ancient artifacts, rare
magical plants, and finely crafted items of beauty.

Their holdings typically contain valuables worth
between                            500 and 2,000 coins, with a 50% chance of
1–3 magical items related to elemental magic or
sound.

Cultural Significance: Credran society revolves
around                               their covenant with the Dran and their duty
to protect the Echoes Forest. The forest itself is a
place where the boundary between the material
world and the dream realm is thin, allowing for a
deep, mystical connection with both. The Credran
honor this connection through rituals and
ceremonies that celebrate the elemental forces and
the spirits that dwell within the forest. The fall of
Prince Mathin the Gray and the creation of the
Woodshades serve as a powerful reminder of the
dangers of dark power, ingrained deeply within
Credran culture. Despite these challenges, the
Credran remain vigilant, their resolve strengthened
by their responsibility to uphold the balance between
light and dark, nature and magic, for the safety of
their people and the preservation of the Echoes
Forest.

Woodshades (Elf)

Type: Exceptional (Fallen Credran)

Threat Dice: Melee 3d8 ~ Ranged 2d4 ~ Power 2d6
Hit                             Points: 102 (77/26) [fast, medium, magical; ×1.5]
Armor Rating: 2d4 (Woodshade armor)

Saving Throw: 2d4+2

Battle Phase: d10

Legends and Lore: The Woodshades are a corrupted
form                               of the Credran, created when Prince Mathin the
Gray, once a revered leader, made a pact with the


BESTIARY


demon Lord Savinoth. This pact turned him and
eleven                              other Credran followers into dark elves with
powers related to shadow and night. These fallen
elves, now known as Woodshades, have become the
wardens of Umbra Keep, a place of perpetual shadow
and despair. The average Woodshade has an ebony
complexion, pale violet eyes, and raven-black hair,
standing over six feet tall with a lithely built frame,
reminiscent of their former elven grace but twisted
by darkness.

Abilities and Powers: A Woodshade can use the
power                              Form of Night, as the spell, at will. They can
also use the powers Manipulate Shadow, Continuous
Shadow, and Shadow Shield three times per day,
requiring no casting roll and incurring no
maintenance penalty. The Shadow Shield solidifies
shadow to create a dark shield (or augment an
existing shield), adding a shield damage reduction
effect of +2 while maintained. The Woodshades
retain their agility and combat prowess, now
enhanced by their dark powers, making them deadly
opponents in both melee and ranged combat.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Most Woodshades
wear                        Woodshade armor, which is magical dark leaf-
patterned leather offering 2d4 damage reduction.

Exposure to sunlight disenchants this armor, forcing
Woodshades to avoid daylight. Each Woodshade
typically has a cache of $20–200 and a 10% chance
of possessing a minor magic item. Their weapons are
often dark and twisted versions of the ones they
wielded as Credran, imbued with shadow magic.

Cultural Significance: The existence of Woodshades
serves                               as a constant reminder to the Credran of the
dangers of succumbing to darkness. Once noble
guardians of the Echoes Forest, these fallen elves
now embody the very corruption they once sought to
prevent. Their transformation has made them
creatures of shadow, bound to the dark powers they
serve, and their presence in Umbra Keep symbolizes
the eternal struggle between light and dark within
the Credran lineage..

Extantar

Type: Minor, up to Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 2d4 to 2d12~ Melee varies ~
Ranged varies ~ Arcane varies

Hit Points: 20 (10/10) to 105 (120/120) [any type, any
size,                         supernatural; ×2 to ×4]

Damage Reduction: Magic, if any. By armor or shield
type                         (Draumur armor and shields; see Ainerêve,
Unique Magical Armor).

Saving Throw: d8 to d12

Battle Phase d4 to d12

Legends and Lore: The mutable borders of the
Metere                                are home to a race of enigmatic beings known
as the Extantars. These mortal yet unfathomable
entities are the living embodiment of our dreams and
imaginings.

Their forms are not fixed but are influenced by the
observer's interpretation. Everyone perceives an
Extantar uniquely, their understanding shaping the
creature's form. One might behold a humanoid
figure with features shifting like the sands of time,
while another might discern an animal form, its skin
a canvas of ever-changing patterns. No two
observers will see the same Extantar in exactly the
same way.

The Extantars are not inherently aggressive, but
their                               alien nature and ever-changing appearance can
be disconcerting, even terrifying, to those unfamiliar
with the ways of the Metere acreature’s perception of
an Extantar can significantly influence their
interaction. One who perceives the Extantar as a
fearsome beast may react with caution or hostility,
while another who sees a benign, albeit alien, entity
may approach with curiosity or even camaraderie.

To those who are wise and wary, the Extantars can
serve                                 as a beacon of insight and understanding. They
may act as guides, their cryptic utterances a source
of wisdom. Their shifting forms, reflecting the
observer's deepest thoughts and fears, can serve as a
mirror to the soul, offering a unique perspective on
one's self and the world.

348


Abilities and Powers: The Extantar manifests as
nearly                                any form identifiable within its generative
culture’s culture and collective mythical
imagination. Its perceivers’ expectations, fears, and
thoughts can also influence its powers, even round to
round. The stats can mirror that of any creature in
the listings of this bestiary.

Armor, Equipment, and Treasure: Extantars carry
whatever weapons, armor, and equipment are
germane to their type and purpose.

Fox Folk

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Natural d8 ~ Melee d6 ~ Ranged d6 ~
Arcane d4 (but see below)

Hit Points: 12 (6/6) [normal, medium, magical; ×1.5]

Damage Reduction: By armor or shield type

Saving Throw: d8

Battle Phase d10

Legends and Lore: Fox folk are mischievous,
sometimes                               even a little malicious, shee capable of
taking the form of a man-fox (a human with a fox
head), an ordinary fox, or a fully human form. They
are beautiful — females are seductive, males
handsome; like succubae and incubi, they can lead
mortals astray, yet their purposes are more often
mirthful than wicked. Tricksters, thieves, and
rogues, the fox-folk dress well and adorn themselves
with finery — they are alluring in all guises, real foxy
ladies and exotically handsome men. It is said that
those with black fur around their eyes when in fox-
form are unkinder, likely to be assassins, while those
with golden fur are kinder of heart, and although
inveterate tricksters, unlikely to harm.

Abilities and Powers: Masters of illusion and
physical                        transformation, they are oft-times drawn to
involve themselves in theatrical display, and roguish
fox-folk sometimes join or create their own,
traveling circuses and theatrical groups. Love spells,
invisibility charms, and other enchantments that

confound mislead, and mentally entrap the victim
are                                all part of the fox-folk armory of magic. They are
capable of casting any Sorcery spell, rolling 3d12
against the Challenge Die.

Armor, Equipment, and Treasure: Fox-folk favor
small                               fast weapons, shuriken, daggers, whips, hand
crossbows, and the like; some are adept with ropes; a
few, of a crueler and darker disposition, with the
garrote. Jewels, gems, small antiques, priceless
antiquities — all are of interest to the fox-folk, and
if they are not carrying them, you can be sure they
are scheming to steal such at the earliest
opportunity. It’s not unusual for the fox-folk to
possess a treasure trove: 200–2000 coins and 30%
chance of d3 magic items.

Gargoyle

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Natural 2d8+1 (claws) ~ Melee 2d6 ~
Arcane d8

Hit Points: 24 (6/18) [tough, medium, magical; ×1.5]

Damage Reduction: +4 (stone skin) vs. slashing / -1
vs.                         bludgeoning & heavy piercing

Saving Throw: d10

Battle Phase d14

Legends and Lore: In appearance, the ugly gargoyles
resemble                                 the apotropaic waterspout carvings from
any church building. The hideous living gargoyles
are the secret creation of Psarmorum’s inner circle,
originally intended as a way to help convert the
heathen while protecting Psarmorum; an occult
plague secretly sent to terrorize Maedoen but
hunting through the woodlands of Meath too,
indiscriminate in their destructive acts, save for
never striking against a true believer in the church of
Sol Invictus.

Abilities and Powers: The gargoyles can sense
religious                          affiliation and do so by sniffing — only the
scent of a believer in Sol Invictus stills their cruel
claws. They can fly, have tough stone-like hides,

349


BESTIARY


and, by covering themselves with their typically bat-
like                            wings, increase this protection to near
invulnerability (DR +4). When still, a living gargoyle
is indistinguishable from a stone carving.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Gargoyles generally
attack                             with their claws. Their tough, stone-like hide
is more vulnerable to smashing weapons like maces
or mauls or piercing weapons like picks that pack a
hefty punch behind a single point of impact. They
rarely have treasure, although occasionally they are
used as couriers and might carry some secret
message, potion, or item to one of Psarmorum’s
agents.

Ghul

Type: Standard (Undead)

Threat Dice: Melee ~ d8+d6 ~ Natural d6+d4 ~
Ranged d8

Hit Points: 28 (7/21) [tough, preternatural, medium;

×2]

Damage Reduction: Immune to non-magical
weapons

Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: It is in the Book of Red Flowers
that                                  I read of the ghul, adherents of a bloody
cannibal cult; once mortal men, they transform
through participation in unholy rites into flesh-
feasting hunters of graveyards. Cult members
consider the ghul state a form of immortality; in
decadent cities, they partake in secret horrid feasts
that mirror the mass of Sol celebrated in
Psarmorum, but with a bloody host and with real
blood in their chalice too — one who “eats the body
and drinks from the cup” for many years will
eventually become undead and transform into a ghul.
It is rumored that the Guardians’ Guild suspects one
or more ghul to have passed through Crossroads, but
surely so blasphemous a cult could grow no root here
’neath the watchful gaze of Virgil. And yet, dark
auguries have of late troubled M’lady Sibyl…

Abilities and Powers: The ghul are undead, can
shape-shift                              to the form of a hyena, take on a man-
like hyena-headed form, or appear as mortal — but
the longer they have been in full ghul state, the less
human they appear. Enchanted weaponry is needed
to cause ghul permanent physical harm, although a
limb lopped off will not regrow and the severing of
the head is effective; even then, a horrid, convulsive
and continuous clawing occurs, dangerous to one
nearby (d8 potential harm). Depending on form
taken, attacks can be weapon strike, claw, or bite —
or all three.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Treasures owned in
mortal life, plundered grave goods, and items of
malevolent occult power might be found in a ghul’s
possession (small cache: 2–20 coins and 5% chance
of 1 magic item). Armor and weaponry, often of good
quality, can be found, especially so on one but
recently “rewarded” with the ghul-state.

Giant

Type: Standard to Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 2d10 to 3d12 ~ Melee 2d10 to
3d12 ~ Ranged 2d6 to 3d6 ~ Arcane nil to 3d12

Extra Attacks: Sweeping strike

Hit Points: 90 (23/67) to 108 (27/81) [tough, huge to
gargantuan, magical; ×2.5 to ×3]

Damage Reduction: By armor or shield (specially
fitted                           or made but same die or DR)

Saving Throw: d12 to 2d8+

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: Let us reflect upon the several
forms                                 of giant, the different kinds of huge man-like
beings born in the cultural imaginations of Earth and
given birth here in Ainerêve — from the elemental to
the misshapen. Now, what one man might call a
giant, another might call an ogre. And where an ogre
to some is a lesser giant, or one able to pass itself off
as a man, to another it is the most fearsome of giant-
kin, and the most ravenous. No matter, let us say
that in general, the giantish races stand anything

350


from one and a half times the height of a man to
mighty                             titans that loom taller than a cathedral spire.
There are ice giants swathed in frost and animal
hides, fearsomely ugly fire giants with flaming fists,
trolls with sly faces and murderous claws, and every
other kind of giant being from folklore and myth.

While most are crude and dull-witted, some are
fairly                          personable: one such, an enslaved hulking
Viking-like Jotunn, dwelt here in Crossroads for
some months, fetching and carrying at its capricious
goblin-overlord’s whim, until the elf-son Nathal
forced the goblin to free it and let it pass home
through the gates.

Abilities and Powers: Typically armed with clubs,
large                            throwing rocks, and sometimes more
conventional weapons and armor. For the primitive
sort, just blows and kicks are enough to shatter most
foes. Elemental giants typically have some power,
great or small, to influence their environment: they
might produce flame, a patch of ice, a swirling mist,
or a deadly rock fall. Giantish mages have greater
powers and might summon elementals too.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The first two: rough
animal hides through to iron plate; humble
huntsman’s gear through to the armaments of a
barbarian prince or knight. Fire giants forge armor
and weapons, other giants may trade for them or be
fitted out by an employer. Treasure always, for the
giants are plunderers born; a sack of loot — for the
largest perhaps a sack of struggling victims too. In
an ogre’s or giantish mage’s lair, wonders of
treasure, magic, and items rare — singing music
boxes, talking books, every item of fairytale lore. A
giant’s treasure is valued as a hoard: 1000–10,000
coins and 40% chance of 4 magic items.

Giant Ant

Type: Minor to Standard

Threat Dice: Natural d4 to 2d12 (bite)

Hit Points: 4 (2/2) to 24 (12/12) [normal, medium,
mundane]

Damage Reduction: +4 (chitinous hide) or special

Saving Throw: d6 to 2d8

Battle Phase d12

Legends and Lore: The giant ant is a peSaving
Throw:                                 it undermines castles, ruins fields, carries off
livestock, and even makes war — for the ants
together have a hive mind capable of the most
complex strategy. A typical specimen stands about a
pony’s size, although varieties smaller and larger
can be found.

Soldier ants have glowing runes on their segmented
bodies,                              gifts from the hive-queen, who works magic
spells. An established hive will even barter and trade
with human settlements. However, care should be
taken, for the ants often prefer to overrun and
occupy an established settlement when swarming
time comes. The queen, a cumbersome creature
surrounded by larvae, weaves magic and cuts runes
into her favored followers’ carapaces. The following
runes are known: yellow cross — the ant regenerates
harm (d4 per round); glowing blue circle —
invulnerability to normal weaponry (up to two
attacks per round); red triangle — fiery bite that
doubles harm (to Fortitude); purple star —
teleportation and phasing (the ant disappears and
reappears at will each round, always behind a new
victim if possible). Other runes certainly exist and
combinations of runes are common; the queen will
have warded herself with every rune she knows
(d4+1 of them)

Abilities and Powers: For the soldiers, bite and sting;
the                             latter injects a toxin that can paralyze or kill
(save vs. Fortitude). Red ant varieties inject a venom
that causes intense pain, disabling the victim and
making all tasks doubly hard; black ant toxin induces

351


BESTIARY


slumber and paralysis; green ant toxin can be deadly.
(Effects                             are respectively stun, but allows non-
combat actions without movement; incapacitate; and
poison: green ant’s attack roll versus victim’s
Fortitude, the difference in rolls applies as extra
damage to the Passive DP.) More humble worker ants
can bite, grab, and pull an opponent away — they
will mob a victim.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The giant ants are
avid                             traders. The ant nest will contain a fortune in
treasure and plundered goods. Typically, a hive
trades to build up a surplus in wealth to buy food
stocks when war and raiding are unprofitable. The
queen will buy magic items too, since she eats them
to power her runes. The hive usually pools its
treasure together near the queen’s chamber, a
veritable dragon’s hoard: 10,000–60,000 coins and
50% chance of 8 magic items.

Giant Bird

Type: Standard to Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 2d6 to 3d10 (talons and beak)

Hit Points: 18 to 45 [normal, medium to gargantuan,
magical;                           ×2 to ×3]

Damage Reduction: None

Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d12 (large), d10 (huge), or d8
(gargantuan) in flight

Legends and Lore: Several giant bird species sweep
aloft                                on the air currents of Ainerêve. The best known
is the roc, so prodigious in size that it can bear an
elephant aloft or take a dragon in its claws. Giant
versions of more typical fowl exist too, eagles and
hawks, owls and robins. The latter talk, and can take
the form of red-jacketed men. Indeed, certain giant
owls have enchanted speech and a knowledge to rival
my own. Beware men in black and white harlequin
garb if they sport a feather in their cap — for they are
magpie robbers. Texts tell me sentience is common
in many of the greater birds, but not so in the roc.

Abilities and Powers: Sharp senses, swooping
attacks,                             grab and drop tactics, razor-like beaks and
talons. For some, transformation into men or
smaller birds.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: No treasure is
typical                                 in a giant bird nest, save perhaps that which
accidentally accrues to the predatory types as they
pluck up victims and carry them back — in such case,
any amount of valuables might be found amidst
stick, twig, bone, and moss. The more intelligent
may have garnered precious stuff, or dwell in
comfortable and furnished aeries. Those with a
magpie-like bent might actually be thieves and
deliberately rob goods and amass wealth (small
trove: 100–600 coins and 20% chance of D2 magic
items).

Giant Rat

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Natural d4 (bite/claw)

Extra Attack: Disease (10%)

Hit Points: 4 [normal, small, mundane]

Saving Throw: d2

Battle Phase d10

Legends and Lore: What adventurer worth his salt
hasn’t                           bravely faced down some rodent of unusual
size? For the neophyte, it’s practically a rite of
passage! Next to goblins, it’s what many aspiring
kings and would-be Destroyers of Worlds start with,
early in their careers. In a land rich in heroes, these
creatures might well be placed on the king’s
endangered species list.

Abilities and Powers: Giant rats only have the power
to                              scare children or give warriors a reason to wear
thick boots, although in greater numbers they can
rise above the level of mere annoyance. Some (10%)
are capable of inflicting disease on somebody after
penetrating armor and if a Fortitude → Endurance
check against threat dice is failed, at which point it

352


deals 1 point of harm per round until the victim falls
unconscious and starts to die from a wasting disease.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: These rodents have
no                         equipment or treasure, save perhaps a gold coin
or two in their stomachs.

Gnome

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Melee d6 ~ Ranged d4 ~ Arcane d10 ~
Natural d4

Hit Points: 15 (8/7) [normal, medium, magical; ×1.5]
Damage Reduction: By armor and shield type
Saving Throw: d10 or 2d4

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: As with dwarves and elves, the
gnomes passing through Crossroads come from a
settled land where certain traditions regarding the
races seem firmly entrenched. These small beings,
slighter than dwarves but with a kinship in
appearance — someway betwixt halfling and dwarf
one might say, with cherub-like features in the
youngest, but all wrinkled wisdom in the oldest.

Tinkerers, inventors, pioneers of science; part
engineer,                           part magician. Heroes familiar with
gnomish adventurers have grown fearful of their
potions and inventions, ofttimes as likely to cause
havoc to friend as to foe.

Those that have settled Ainerêve practice alchemy

— they seek the philosophers’ stone, though why
here                              rather than elsewhere I cannot say. I challenged
one once, saying ‘Surely the stone is the seeker’s
own will, used to turn the elements of his common
spirit into a soul of gold?’ but to this the gnome gave
only a cryptic smile and said no more.

Abilities and Powers: Gnomic magic centers on.
Gnomes                             use their own magical machinery, arcane
inventions, and potions that cause magical effects,
both for weal and woe. Every item should be given a
misfire chance — a probability of opposite or non-

action (5% to 20% — roll each time the invention,
potion,                           or other item is used).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Good quality
weapons                               and armor are the norm, with everything
from flying clockwork planes to exploding gloves as
additional equipment; potions, elixirs, and strange
unguents are likely. Gnomes are often rich, and
sometimes envied; gold coins and gems are secreted
in belt and pouch (individual cache, 20–200 coins
and 10% chance of 1 magic item; domicile trove,
200–2000 coins and 30% chance of d3 magic items).

Goblin

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Melee d6 ~ Natural d4 ~ Ranged d4
Hit Points 6 (3/3) [normal, small, mundane]
Damage Reduction: By armor or shield

Saving Throw: d4 to d8

Battle Phase d6 to d12

Abilities and Powers: Goblins lack any remarkable
skills,                               but grow into adulthood learning how to kill
with any implement they may find. They are
ruthless, lazy, greedy, and sadistic as a species,
growing as they do out of the nightmares of
humankind. They breed among their own kind, but
the first is said to have stalked out from the unsettled
lands.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Goblins normally
wear                            leather or hide armor. Favored weapon is the
hand axe or short sword. Individually a goblin’s
treasure amounts to little more than trinkets (1–6
coins and 1% chance of 1 minor magic item). If found
in a lair, a small cache (2–20 coins and 5% chance of
1 magic item).

BESTIARY


Golem

Type: Standard to Legendary

Threat Dice: Natural 2d8 to 3d18 ~ Melee 2d6 to 3d14

~ Ranged 2d4 to 2d12 ~ Arcane 2d10 to 3d14

Extra Attacks: Possible elemental blasts equal to
main attack

Hit Points: 112 (28/84) to 135 (33/101) [tough, large,
preternatural; ×2]

Damage Reduction: d4 to d18 natural armor, plus
possible immunity to element

Saving Throw: d4 to 3d12

Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: A shell of stone and clay, large,
hulking,                          man-like. It is inscribed with runic marks,
glyphs, spells: secret names of God — and the devil
too? It is the work of a magician, often misguided;
kneeling before the unfinished construct, he
implores the powers of heaven and hell to give it life.
Yet it is the servants of Lilith most likely to enter
within, there to work the sinister will of their
mistress. The golem might be mindless or possessed
of a wicked spirit, and who can tell the difference?

For a seemingly mindless automaton, doing the
bidding                               of its master, may one day, at a time ripe for
wickedness, strike and act at Lilith’s will.

Abilities and Powers: Possessed of great strength
and                            durability, the golem is a dutiful servant in labor
or war, and can be set as a guard. One possessed by a
spirit of occult cruelty will act to bring chaos and
dishonor to all it has served. While so possessed, it
may gain demonic powers to harm and kill: an ability
to pass through walls, to mimic voices, to move
items by will, and to weave strange choking fogs, are
all recorded in De Rerum Horrida, a volume of weird
occult lore. Elemental golems, of ice, rock, earth,
lava, clay, etc., are known, and each will have an
additional power and immunity appropriate to the
element from which it is formed. Golems of metal,
crystal, and even diamond have been reported. The
flesh golem is the work of a necromancer, misguided
scientist, and almost certain to attract a stray soul. A

golem may be a near-unstoppable juggernaut, but it
is                              one possible to outrun, as surviving adventurers
have noted.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Armor levels as
appropriate                                 to the element or combination of
elements/materials from which the golem is formed.
Smashing fist strikes and leg stomps form the basis
of attack — additional harm and magical results may
ensue: fire, ice bursts, muddy entrapment, stunning,
etc.

Griffin

Type: Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 3d10 (beak and talons)

Extra Attacks: Hind lion claws 3d12 (contingent
attack,                        see below)

Hit Points: 45 (23/22) [normal, magical, Medium;

×1.5]

Damage Reduction: +2 (natural toughness)

Saving Throw: 2d6

Battle Phase d8 ground; d10 ftight

Legends and Lore: With the wings, forelimbs, and
head                                 of an eagle and the hindquarters of a lion, the
griffin is a fearsome combination of two mighty
predators. Their ears prick up, a sign of their near-
prescient senses. Griffins lair in mountainous homes
and whether by accident or design, their airborne
prides oft-times have aeries above deposits of gold,
so that a prospector can be guided to gold ore by
following their flight. This leads to conflict, as
griffins will not tolerate intruders in their hunting
ranges. Here lies the origin of the griffins’
enslavement by the Arimaspians; seeking gold,
plunder or mine, inevitably led the one-eyed reavers
into conflict with griffins; and sore woe came unto
the winged bird-lions when the Arimaspians learned
some occult method of binding them.

Abilities and Powers: Griffins see and hear with
great                             acuity. All a griffin’s senses, including those of
smell, vibration, and taste, are heightened so that it

354


is impossible to surprise one, unless magically
hidden.                              Beak and talon strike, backed by a hunting
bird’s accuracy and a lion’s ferocious strength. A
griffin that strikes with bird-like forelimbs can,
thereafter, bunch up its lion-like rear limbs and
make a devastating clawing strike as it holds its prey
fast (whenever the main attack exceeds the
defender’s Active DP).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Only incidental
wealth                         will be found in a griffin aerie, left among
victims’ remains.

Hag

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Arcane 2d10 ~ Natural d6 ~ Melee d4 ~
Ranged d4

Extra Attacks: Critter swarm (2d6, zero Challenge
Die)

Hit Points: 68 (51/17) [fast, medium, preternatural;

×2]

Damage Reduction: None.
Saving Throw: 2d10
Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: These horrid spirits in the form of
crones stalk the Forest of Meath and are found in
Maedoen too; typical witch-like women with black
teeth, stony eyed, that seek to lead mortal children
away to feast upon their blood and bone. The hags
have other objectives too: they form covens, weave
spells, and some have ranged from their native
homes into other lands to increase wickedness and
spread their sinister power across the realm.

Abilities and Powers: Each hag cradles a basket in
her                               arm; ’neath its lid are horrors: from the basket
the hag can pluck forth imps, spiders, serpents,
bugs, even goblins and other hateful things. Fear the
hag, for she carries evil wherever she goes. In
addition, each hag can perform magical spells and
workings with a Harm or Afflict effect from the
Sorcery and Hieraticism paths, and if in the company

of twelve of her sisters, a full coven, the power of
such                                is doubled — trebled on certain occult and
accursed nights in the sabbatic calendar of dark
wizardry. The swarm a hag plucks from her basket is
as below:

Critter swarm: The number of critters summoned is
equal to the result of the ability check, and each
creature has 1 threat point, 1 hit point, and 0 active
defense. The creatures act as one (minor) group,
with Prowess rank equal to the hag’s. See Swarm
Summoning.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Hags may have
jewels                               and treasures, magic items, and cursed
objects hidden in their baskets (200–2000 coins
value and 30% chance of d3 magic items). If her life
is seriously endangered, one will offer to trade goods
for it (plucking forth cursed objects first, of course).

Halfling

Type: Minor to legendary

Threat Dice: Melee d6 ~ Ranged d6 ~ Natural d4
Hit Points: 6 (3/3) [normal, small, mundane]
Damage Reduction: By armor or shield type
Saving Throw: d10

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: Halflings are a small, resourceful
folk                             known for their dual nature—shy and reclusive
yet surprisingly adventurous when the need arises.
They are often mistaken for Shee near the region of
Psarmorum, leading them to live as outlaws to avoid
persecution by the Templars. Despite their small
stature, halflings are known to raid dragon lairs and
are skilled in stealth and survival. They have a strong
sense of community and value their homes and
families above all else.

Abilities and Powers: Halflings possess an innate
knack                               for stealth, making them difficult to detect by
larger foes. They are adept at moving quietly and can
hide easily in natural environments. Their small size
grants them agility, allowing them to dodge attacks

355


BESTIARY


and escape from dangerous situations with relative
ease.                             While they are not naturally inclined toward
combat, when cornered, halflings can be surprisingly
fierce, using whatever tools or weapons are at hand
to defend themselves.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Halflings typically
arm                          themselves with small weapons, such as
daggers, slings, or short swords. They wear light
armor, often made from leather or other materials
that do not hinder their movement. Halflings are
known to keep small treasures hidden away, often in
the form of coins, gems, or items of sentimental
value. A typical halfling home might contain 20–200
coins and a 10% chance of a minor magic item. Due
to their nomadic tendencies when threatened, these
treasures are often well hidden and protected by
simple but effective traps.

Harpy

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Natural 2d6 (talons)

Hit Points 24 (18/6) [fast, medium, preternatural;

×2]

Damage Reduction: None

Saving Throw: d20 versus Sorcery; else d8

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: Harpies are infamous for their
deceptive                        appearance and wicked nature. Often
found in isolated mountain ranges or along
treacherous coastlines, harpies lure their victims
with their magical ability to appear as exotically
attractive winged maidens, easily mistaken for
angels. The transformation is so convincing that
even the most seasoned adventurers may be fooled.
However, their true form is that of a vile and
predatory creature, half-woman and half-bird, with
a shrieking voice that can unsettle the bravest souls.

Abilities and Powers: Harpies are equipped with
potent                           illusion magic, particularly the Full Body
Illusion spell, which allows them to disguise their

true form as a beautiful maiden with wings. This
illusion                            can be cast without requiring any tests,
making it an almost effortless deception. The
harpy’s natural attack involves both vicious claws
and a paralyzing screech that can leave its victims
vulnerable. Those who fall prey to a harpy’s allure
often find themselves caught in her talons, carried
off to her lair to meet a grisly end.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Harpies do not
wield                            weapons or wear armor, relying instead on
their natural abilities and magical deceptions. They
may carry small treasures, often trinkets taken from
previous victims. The typical harpy nest contains a
small cache of 50-200 coins, and there is a 10%
chance of finding a minor magic item, usually
something related to enhancing deception or
illusion.

Horse

Type: Minor to Standard

Threat Dice: Natural d10 (riding horse) to 2d12
(warhorse)

Hit Points: 10 to 24 [normal, large, mundane; ×2]
Damage                         Reduction: By any armor (barding) up to d12
Saving Throw: d4 to d8 to 8

Battle Phase d10

Legends and Lore: Horses are important in any
medieval                          society, and even in lands where magic
functions, nothing beats their reliability and
strength. Magic remains taxing, and the effects
relatively short-lived, so most folk still need
conventional modes of transportation. The average
riding horse can carry 250 pounds thirty miles in
eight hours.

Abilities and Powers: Horses can also be used in
combat,                              and warhorses typically have a higher ability
to deal damage

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Horses, especially
warhorses,                              may be fitted with armor (barding),

356


granting general protection, with the usual armor
types.

Hunting Dog

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Natural d6 (bite)

Damage Reduction: None

Hit Points: 6 [normal, small, mundane]

Saving Throw: d4 to d8 to 8

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: Nobles often use hunting dogs in
sport, or when tracking down escaped prisoners.

They’re either scent hounds like coon hounds, or
sight hounds like pointers.

Abilities and Powers: Hunting dogs can follow even
the                           faintest scent trails, with a roll of 3d12, or spot
small quarry (including Swipes) with the same level
of ability. Their hearing is also very good, with a
default Perception check of d6+4.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Most owners don’t
fit                             their hunting dogs with armor, or allow them to
carry treasures.

Hydra

Type: Standard, Exceptional, or Legendary (4, 8, or
12                             heads)

Threat Dice: Natural 2d12 to 3d20 (main head’s bite,
or                        constriction)

Extra Attacks: 2d6 per extra head

Hit Points: 48 (12/36) [tough, large, magical; ×2]

Damage Reduction: d6 (tough hide)

Saving Throw: d6

Battle Phase d4

Legends and Lore: The hydra is a water serpent with
many heads that often hunts on land. If stretched
out, in length it is like that of two men. Its
constrictor-like thick serpent trunk breaks into
multiple ophidian heads, each with venomous jaws.

Abilities and Powers: Able both to constrict and bite,
the                             hydra is a fearsome foe. Multiple toxins can be
found in a single specimen, so bites from one head
may cause paralysis, from another somnolence,
while a third induces a berserk frenzy against the
victim’s companions, and so forth.

While some hydras can be killed by decapitation of
each                                head or chopping through the central trunk by a
prodigious feat of strength, others (1 in 6) will grow
d3 fresh heads each time a head is severed, thus
making them harder to kill with each telling blow.

Fire might be used to cauterize the neck stumps and
prevent re-growth… or so legends say…

Poison: Any hydra head’s bite penetrating active
defenses                            forces a Saving Throw versus the attack
roll, else victim suffers a poison effect. Usually this is
another instant d10 poison damage (save vs.

Fortitude). Some (1 in 4) hydras have a random effect
per                             head, e.g. roll d12: 1–5 poison, 6 GM’s whim, 7
stun, 8 blind, 9 paralyze, 10 incapacitate, 11 confuse,
12 terrorize (save vs. Fortitude or as per magical
affliction).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Often found as
guardians                              of (un)holy sites, the hydra might be
tasked with protecting wealth, or some sacred object
of power (hoard: 1000–10,000 coins value and 40%
chance of 4 magic items).

Lilith

Type: Legendary (avatar)

Threat Dice: Arcane 3d18 ~ Melee 3d10 ~ Natural 2d8

~ Ranged 2d6

Extra Attacks: Extra spell action

Hit Points: 135 (68/67) [normal, supernatural,
medium;                     ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: By armor and shield type;
immunity to mundane weaponry

Saving Throw: 3d10

Battle Phase d16

357


BESTIARY


Legends and Lore: Lilith, Mother of the Night, first
woman,                             creatrix, elder sister of Eve. Embittered
against heaven, weary of hell, she is wed in unholy
union with Baphomet. She seeks to free him from the
constricting webs of heaven and hell to grant him
ultimate power and freedom, and with it the end of
all, the coming of night, the journey across the abyss
and ultimately rebirth. She is the Whore of Babylon;
dressed in red, a lion at her right hand, a many-
headed dragon behind her. Hidden from sight, first
wife of Adam, the true Sophia, Lilith has existed
through countless incarnations, trapped in the
warped matter of reality, downtrodden, forgotten,
humiliated, accursed; in Ainerêve she seeks the
source of her suffering; is she born in the mind of
man? Have all her pains been mortal dreams? Was
Eden first here or on Earth?

Abilities and Powers: Lilith chooses to appear in the
guise                                 of a demonic vampire queen, beautiful beyond
reason. She inspires a charmed lust that forces men,
and some women too, to seek her approval and
voluntarily do her will (mesmerizing command). She
is a mistress of all dark magics, can heal herself by
drinking blood, take on the form of wolf, bat, or
screech owl, and put those she talks to into a
submissive trance (entrance).

Despite appearances to the contrary, Lilith is not
truly                            undead, she is a manifest spiritual entity, and,
so certain drug-maddened sages argue in the Scrolls
of Licentia, mother to all living things. Immune to all
but the most highly enchanted weapons, Lilith’s
avatar is still, like a vampire, vulnerable to wooden
stakes, submersion in running water, and
decapitation.

Extra spell action: Choose 1 extra spell action, 1
battle phase after initial attack — mesmerizing
command, any Mysticism or Hieraticism spell at

+d10 (3d18+d10).

Mesmersizing command: Inspires charmed lust in
susceptible mortals: Challenge Die 0, control mind
effect using 3d18; save Fortitude → Willpower

Entrance: Induce trance state (semi-conscious until
stimulus or 10 minutes) by talking uninterrupted to
mortal for one round, Challenge Die d10 effect using
3d18; save Fortitude → Willpower.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Lilith’s avatar can
conjure any item for her use. She will be clad in
valuable finery, usually of a gothic bent, and carry
many mystical and magical objects (small trove:
100–600 coins, but 20% chance of d10 legendary
magic items).

Lilith’s Daughters

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Arcane 2d10 ~ Melee d10 ~ Natural d8 ~
Ranged d6

Extra Attacks: Extra spell action

Hit Points: 40 (20/20) [normal, preternatural,

Damage Reduction: +2 (preternatural toughness) [ I
wonder if I should present hit point increase for
anything but Legendary and then the die type for
legendary? Like +2 / 1d4? )

Saving Throw: d10

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: The Daughters of Lilith are
vampiric succubi, visions of passion and lust but
with a touch of terror — their eyes are without
pupils, and their fingers end in claws.

Abilities and Powers: As with their dark mistress, all
the                          vampire’s classic powers belong to Lilith’s
daughters, and yet they too are flesh-clothed spirits
rather than undead entities. Each can wield dark
magic and otherwise has Lilith’s powers in a reduced
capacity but will often choose to attack with her bite
and iron-hard talons rather than rely on
enchantments.

Extra spell action: Choose 1 extra spell action, 1
battle                           phase after initial attack — mesmerizing
command, any Mysticism or Hieraticism spell (the

358


last two at Challenge Die d2 using a d10 if other than
a                             Harm effect spell).

Mesmerizing command: Inspires charmed lust in
susceptible mortals: Challenge Die d4 control mind
effect using d10; save Fortitude → Willpower.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Usually, each has a
small cache (2–20 coins and 5% chance of 1 magic
item), but their mistress may have set them to guard
a greater treasure.

Orc

Type: Minor to legendary

Threat Dice: Natural d8 ~ Melee d6 ~ Ranged d4
Hit Points: 8 (4/4) [normal, medium, mundane]
Damage Reduction: By armor or shield

Battle Phase d6

Legends and Lore: Orcs are stupid, barbaric, tribal
creatures.                             Bigger and meaner than goblins, they
enjoy robbing human villages and terrorizing every
living thing.

Abilities and Powers: Orcs are very strong, capable of
feats of strength at 2d8, and have a keen sense of
smell (Perception d10).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Orcs usually wield
inferior                             axes and swords to spread mayhem, and don
hide or leather armor. Their shields often provide
only 1 point of DR, even if medium-sized, for they
are not known for good workmanship. They may
possess trinkets (1–6 coins and 1% chance of 1 minor
magic item), or for exceptional specimens as much
as a small cache (2–20 coins and 5% chance of 1
magic item).

Peri

Type: Minor to legendary

Threat Dice: Arcane d10 ~ Melee d8 ~ Ranged d6 ~
Natural d4

Hit Points: 10 (7/3) [fast, medium, magical; ×1.5]
Damage Reduction: By armor and shield type
Saving Throw: 2d4

Battle Phase d10 (d12 in ftight)

Legends and Lore: It is with a heavy heart I speak of
the                              peris, for they unwittingly spread evil and fear on
the borders of our land of Maedoen, persecuting
those of ancient wisdom and tradition by order of
their master, Lord Sol Invictus. Beautiful, with
sapphire eyes, bird-like wings, and the passion of a
young star, a peri is at once angelic and formidable.

Nathal of the Seelie court insists that the near-
immortal                             peris are not evil, despite their incursions
into Maedoen. Originally summoned as servant
angels of Psarmorum, they were and are willing to
fight the powers of Hell. In turn, some of the ablest
knights of Psarmorum have gone to aid their battles
in their own realm, so the bond is strong. However,
of those peris that linger here long, many have
grown suspicious of the Order of Chaplains’ good
intentions, as they encounter more of the good
people of Maedoen. Peri defectors are welcomed by
the high elves, usually joining the Seelie Court, and

359


BESTIARY


are protected by the Guardians Guild. Although
resembling                              and welcomed by high elves, peris prefer
wyld elves’ company, for they are more impulsive
and passionate, which matches the peris’ fiery
sensibilities. Called rogue angels here in Crossroads,
peris often hide their wings when traveling through
the kingdoms of Maedoen for fear they’d be assumed
to be spies.

Abilities and Powers: Peris are adept magic users,
preferring                             the Elementalism and Hieraticism paths
of magic and focusing on the spells from the Energy
element and with the Restore effect repectively. They
also possess the power of flight, their base prowess
rank increasing a full die rank when in flight.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Peris wear light
armor,                           often magical as provided by the Church of
Psarmorum, and usually prefer ranged spells to
missile weapons. Up close, the peris are capable
fighters and will often conjure their weapons as
needed. Like elves, peris don’t like to travel with a
heavy burden, though many keep a cache in their
homes: 100–200 coins and 20% chance of 1 magic
item.

Raptor

Type: Minor

Threat Dice: Natural d8+1 (beak or talons)
Hit                    Points: 8 [normal, small, mundane]
Damage Reduction: None

Battle Phase d16

Legends and Lore: Raptors are birds of prey and hunt
game for their trainers, either called falconers (for
falcons) or austringers (for hawks). Some raptors are
trained for battle and are more than hunting hawks,
it is said. They are greatly feared for their ferocity
and their ability to tear their enemies to pieces.

Abilities and Powers: Those birds of prey trained to
attack or retrieve are highly valued. They have a
“static” speed score of 16, which means they rarely

lose the initiative in a fight and are incredibly fast
when flying.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: None.

Sacred Ophidian Sisterhood of Seven
Serpents Entwined

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Ranged 2d12 ~ Arcane 2d10 ~ Melee 2d8

~ Natural 2d6

Extra Attacks: Petrifying gaze or poison bite
(contingent attack, see below)

Hit Points: 48 (36/12) [fast, preternatural, medium;

×2]

Damage Reduction: By armor or shield

Saving Throw: 2d6

Battle Phase d8

Legends and Lore: The Sacred Ophidian Sisterhood
of                             Seven Serpents Entwined is a mysterious and
feared faction, often set apart from true monsters.
Formed by women from war-afflicted communities
who have lost everything, the Sisterhood recruits
young girls and women seeking vengeance. Their
serpentine tattoos, which are said to move and coil
under the skin, are both a symbol of their
membership and a source of their magical power.

The Sisterhood is known for its strict discipline,
secretive                           rituals, and unwavering dedication to their
cause. They are often involved in shadowy dealings
and covert operations, manipulating events from
behind the scenes.

Abilities and Powers: Each member of the Sisterhood
is                             highly skilled in both martial and arcane arts.

Their primary magical abilities are tied to the
serpentine                            tattoos that adorn their bodies, allowing
them to summon serpents, inflict venomous curses,
and manipulate others with hypnotic charm. These
abilities are enhanced when members work in
unison, reflecting the Sisterhood’s philosophy of
strength through unity. The Sisterhood’s leader,
known as the High Serpent, is particularly powerful,

360


capable of casting spells that affect entire regions or
armies.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: The Sisterhood’s
members                           typically wield ceremonial daggers,
imbued with venom that can paralyze or kill their
foes. They favor light, flexible armor that allows for
swift, fluid movements, often crafted from the skins
of serpents. The Sisterhood’s treasure is usually kept
in secret caches, guarded by both mundane and
magical means. These caches might include rare
alchemical ingredients, powerful relics, and wealth
taken from those who have wronged them. While
individual members may carry small amounts of coin
or minor magical items, the true riches of the
Sisterhood are hidden away, accessible only to those
who prove their loyalty.

Sea Serpent

Type: Legendary

Threat Dice: Natural 2d20 (crushing attack)

Extra Attack: d14+24 (bite)

Hit Points: 48 (12/36) [tough, preternatural,
gargantuan;                  ×3.5]

Damage Reduction: +5 / d10 (thick, scaly hide)

Saving Throw: 2d10

Battle Phase d10 in the sea

Legends and Lore: Sea serpents are the bane of the
oceans                               and great lakes of the world. Those who travel
by sea had better keep a thaumaturge on board who
can summon the wind and speed their travel before
such a beast appears. Rare though they may be, just
one of these death-dealing beasts quickly sinks ships
and their treasures. In the Murex Scrolls, it is written
that one of these beasts, known of old as Leviathan,
has lived so long that it nears twice the size of its
lesser kindred, but this is surely a myth.

Abilities and Powers: Sea serpents can capsize a
large                               galley in only five rounds, crushing the hull like
matchsticks. If attacked or hungry, they will bite at
the attackers as well.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: None

Sentinel

Type: Standard to Legendary

Threat Dice: Any attack type, 2d to 3d, any die rank

Extra Attack: up to 3 (2d or 3d, any die rank)

Hit Points: 8 to 240 [any constitution, any size, any
nature; up to ×5]

Saving Throw: d12 to 3d12

Battle Phase d8+

Legends and Lore: All places, sacred or profane, have
their                            guardians. Sometimes this is non-sentient
protection, such as a glyph or runic trap, but often
it’s a creature summoned or created to guard
something important. Because a sentinel can be just
about any imposing creature or something unique,
the GM is free to tailor a sentinel (or sentinels) to
suit the encounter.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Weapons and armor
depending on the particular sentinel. Treasure
guarded ranges from trinkets to the equivalent of a
dragon’s hoard (wildly varied, 1 to 60,000 in coin
value, 1 to 50% or greater chance of magic items).
