BESTIARY


Shee (Fay or Faerie)

Minor Shee

Type: Minor Fay/Faerie

Threat Dice (TD):

Arcane: D10 (glamor)

Ranged: D8
Melee: D6
Unarmed: D4

Hit Points (HP): 15 to 25 [Constitution: Any, Size:
Miniscule to Large, Nature: Preternatural; HP
Multiplier: ×1.5 to ×2.5]

Armor Rating (AR): D4 to D12

Wealth and Treasure (WAT): 100–1000 coins value
in                            gems or “arboreal” art

Notes: Minor Shee are lesser faerie creatures, skilled
in                            glamor for distraction or stunning.

Legends and Lore: Often found in hidden glens,
enchanted                          forests, and mystical groves, the Minor
Shee represent the lowest tier of the Shee hierarchy.
They are known for their ethereal beauty and
mischievous nature, traits that are both captivating
and unsettling to those who encounter them.

Frequently aligned with either the Seelie or Unseelie
Courts,                            these beings serve as messengers, spies, or
distractions for more powerful Fay. The duality of
their nature reflects the unpredictable whimsy of the
Fay, where moments of grace can quickly turn to acts
of cruelty.

Abilities and Powers: Skilled in the art of glamor,
Minor                              Shee can distract or stun their opponents with
ease. Their ability to shift size—from minuscule to
large—makes them elusive and difficult to combat,
especially when they use their illusions to create
confusion. Their agility and small stature also aid
them in evading danger and manipulating their
surroundings to their advantage.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure (WAT): Minor Shee
typically do not wear armor, preferring to rely on
their agility and magical abilities for protection.

They might carry small, enchanted trinkets or
weapons,                              such as tiny daggers or bows crafted from
enchanted wood. Their treasures, often hidden in
secretive groves, usually consist of gems or “nature-
inspired crafts” valued between 100 to 1000 coins.

Standard Shee

Type: Standard Fay/Faerie

Threat Dice (TD):

Arcane: 2D6 (glamor)

Ranged: 2D4
Melee: D8
Unarmed: D4

Hit Points (HP): 48 to 80 [Constitution: Any, Size:
Miniscule to Large, Nature: Preternatural; HP
Multiplier: ×1.5 to ×2.5]

Armor Rating (AR): D4 to D12

Wealth and Treasure (WAT): 100–1000 coins value
in                            gems or “arboreal” art

Legends and Lore: Ascending the hierarchy, we
encounter                              the Standard Shee, who embody the more
common faerie folk within the Fay courts. These
Shee often align themselves with either the Seelie
Court, known for its harmony with nature and
benevolent magic, or the Unseelie Court, which
embraces darker practices, including necromancy.
Guardians of the Fertile Glens—areas rich in life and
magical energy—Standard Shee protect these sacred
spaces with unwavering devotion, punishing those
who dare defile them.

Abilities and Powers: Standard Shee possess the
ability                              to shape-shift, allowing them to assume
various forms for deception, concealment, or
combat. Their glamor magic is powerful enough to
manipulate perceptions, crafting illusions that can
confuse or mesmerize their enemies. Proficient in
Nature, Life, Illusion, and Plant magic, Standard
Shee are formidable defenders of their territories,
summoning the forces of nature or obscuring their
enemies’ senses with ease.

362


Weapons, Armor, and Treasure (WAT): Standard
Shee                               often wield weapons made from natural
materials, such as bows crafted from enchanted trees
or swords forged from moonlight silver. Their
armor, if worn, is typically light and made from
leaves or bark, enchanted to provide protection
without hindering movement. Their treasures are
hidden deep within their groves or arboreal palaces
and consist of rare gems, plants, or “nature-inspired
crafts” worth between 500 to 1500 coins, reflecting
their higher status compared to their minor
counterparts.

Shee Lord

Type: Exceptional (Fay Nobility)

Threat Dice: Arcane 3d12 ~ Melee 2d8 ~
Natural 2d6

Hit Points: 72 (48/24) [fast,
large,       preternatural; ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: By any
armor worn

Saving Throw: d12

Battle Phase: d12

Notes: Shee Lords are
formidable          faerie nobility,
possessing potent glamor
and command over faerie
magic.

Legends and Lore: The Shee
Lords                are the aristocracy of the

Fay, ruling with a captivating blend of

grace and terrifying power. They embody the duality
of                                the Seelie and Unseelie Courts, with some aligned
with the light and others steeped in shadow. Revered
and feared in equal measure, Shee Lords can be
benevolent protectors or ruthless adversaries,
depending on their whims. Their unearthly beauty is
said to ensnare the minds of mortals, and their
presence commands awe and trepidation. They are
often found in their arboreal palaces, magical
fortresses grown from the very heart of Fertile Glens,

which serve as both their source of power and a
reflection of their will.

Abilities and Powers: A Shee Lord is a master of
glamor                               and illusion, capable of bending reality and
perception with mere thought. Their magic extends
beyond mere deception, allowing them to control
natural forces, summon creatures of the wild, and
reshape landscapes to their desires. In combat, they
are deadly, wielding both spell and blade with
unparalleled skill. Their glamor is not just an illusion
but a manifestation of their power, capable of
enchanting entire courts and bending even the
strongest wills to their desires.

The Price of Power: Though Shee Lords seem almost
godlike                          in their domains, their power

comes at a cost. Some whisper that
their                   ties to the mortal realm

weaken with each passing
century,         requiring offerings

of beauty, artistry, or even life
force                 to maintain their
splendor. This dependence may
fuel their capricious nature,
driving them to acts of great
generosity or terrible cruelty in

an endless cycle of need and
fulfillment. Mortals, such as the

Eldritch Man, may find themselves
in                  service to the Shee, their lives

extended and powers enhanced in
exchange for their loyalty and life force.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure (WAT): Shee Lords
often                             wield enchanted weapons, heirlooms passed
down through generations, each imbued with
powerful magic. Their armor, if worn, is of the finest
craftsmanship, often appearing as part of their
glamor rather than physical protection. The
treasures of a Shee Lord are vast and ancient,
including relics of immense power, rare gems, and
artifacts hidden deep within their arboreal palaces.
These palaces, grown from the very trees they

363


BESTIARY


inhabit, are living structures, their halls winding
through                         massive trunks and canopies, hidden from
those uninvited. The wealth within is guarded not
only by enchantments and traps but by the very
forest itself, loyal to the Shee Lord’s will.

Source of Evil

Type: Legendary (avatar)

Threat Dice: Arcane d20+30 ~ Melee d8+24 ~ Natural
d6+18                                 ~ Ranged d6+12

Hit Points: 50 (25/25) [normal, supernatural,
medium;                    ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: Immune to non-magical
weaponry

Saving Throw: d10+10

Battle Phase Battle Phase 1 default or d20+10 for
random initiative

Legends and Lore: The Source of Evil, known by
many                        names—Satan, the Accuser, Lucifer—was
once a radiant angel. Even now, he can appear with
an image of purity, though it is a cold, cynical purity
filled with self-righteousness and pride. At other
times, he takes on the bestial figure of folklore,
horned and tailed: the Devil. Satan is wary of
Baphomet, the usurper, and his consort Lilith, both
of whom have turned their attention to Ainerêve.

Initially, Satan viewed Baphomet’s interest in this
dream                            realm with disdain, assuming the Sabbatic
Goat sought only to rule in dreams. But a dread fear
soon gripped Satan’s black heart—what if this realm
of dreams was his true origin?

Satan, once a persecutor of mankind, now fears
that                                he is their creation, a miscarried spawn of their
darkest fears and loathing. The possibility that
Baphomet and Lilith seek to reshape Earth through
Ainerêve’s dream realms fills Satan with a sense of
dread. To counter this, Satan has reached out to
Heaven, and together they have woven a web of
energies across Ainerêve, a net of power meant to
bind Baphomet. Both Heaven and Hell now watch

with bated breath, waiting to see if they, too, are but
dreams or mere facsimiles of a greater reality.

Abilities and Powers: Satan’s powers are vast,
bordering                                on omniscience and omnipotence—at
least, so he believes, and perhaps he is right. When
the Avatar of Evil manifests in the mortal realm, it
often toys with humanity, presenting itself as a
daring alternative to societal norms. But beneath the
aristocratic facade lies a wrathful, hateful being, the
complete antithesis of love. In combat, Satan is
overconfident, often allowing vulnerabilities in his
avatar form to taunt his attackers, as though mortal
combat were merely a game. And to Satan, it is—a
game in which he is the master.

Satan’s avatar regenerates 10 HP per battle phase
and                            gains temporary hit points equal to the damage
it inflicts on a target’s Passive Defense. Even if his
avatar is slain, it regenerates from dust after four
rounds, but only in Hell.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Satan’s avatar can
wield any item, treasure, or device, including those
of immense power. The treasure hoards associated
with him are vast, potentially equivalent to a
dragon’s hoard, valued between 10,000 and 60,000
coins, with a 100% chance of containing d8 magic
items.

Specter (or Limbo Spirit)

Type: Standard (undead)

Threat Dice: Natural d10 (+d8 non-physical harm via
spectral touch).

Hit Points: 25 (13/12) [normal, supernatural,
medium;                    ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: Immune to non-magical attacks
and                           Energy Elementalism spells

Saving Throw: d6

Battle Phase d10+12

Legends and Lore: Specters, ghosts, and spirits act
as                             guides, allies giving clues to the living, wandering
souls, or guardians of holy or unholy places..

364


Abilities and Powers: These ghosts seem almost
solid,                                if not for a faint shimmering, but can turn
invisible at will. Striking at one with non-magical
weapons is pointless, as they are immune to such.
They are also immune to Energy attacks since they
exist as (spiritual) energy, the “fifth essence.”
Thaumaturges can unravel a spirit’s manifestation
with non-physical harm spells, especially entropic
spells, which inflict double damage. The weapons of
a limbo spirit appear real but are actually dense
energy fields. Their weapons can be used to parry,
but ghosts don’t often use such tactics. All damage
from their attacks bypasses non-magical armor.

Spectral touch: The spirit’s extra non-physical
damage                               die, whether delivered by touch or weapon,
is preternatural and can be blocked by armor — but
only roll the extra damage die if the base Natural
threat roll exceeds the target’s chosen active
defense. Some specters have extra powers consistent
with their nature.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: These spirits don’t
carry                               real equipment or treasure.

Swipes (Astral Footpads)

Type: Minor (extraplanar)

Threat Dice: Ranged d10 (+d8 if using “kestros”) ~
Natural d4+2 (claws) ~ Melee d4

Extra Attacks: Astral snap d6+d4 (by touch)

Hit Points: 20 (10/10) [normal, preternatural,
medium;                     ×2]

Damage Reduction: d4 astral field (phasing in and
out)

Saving Throw: d10; immune to teleportation and
summoning

Battle Phase d12+4

Legends and Lore: Small and fleet of foot, swipes
look                                like small, fuzzy monkeys with huge eyes. As a
species, they are mostly thieves with the most
annoying hideout possible: the astral plane. They can
shift at will into unsettled territory. These “astral

footpads” are capable of traveling great distances,
teleporting                             upon mental command.

A swipe will steal a coin purse, and then with a brief
shimmering and a “pop” sound, it’s gone. They are
as intelligent as humans and organized into tribal,
nomadic societies that invade small towns, quickly
depleting food sources and other items, then moving
on.

Abilities and Powers: A swipe gets +4 to initiative to
increase Battle Phase or random initiative roll (see
Chapter 3, Combat). They use small weapons only
and are expert dart throwers (using a “kestros”
sling). Swipes can see in total darkness. Their
teleportation ability may be used once per round for
short distances and as a natural defense (d4 damage
reduction), but if the swipe shifts into the astral
plane for longer than a battle phase, it cannot return
for d2 rounds (it must get reoriented). They speak
the common language, which allows them to
converse with travelers of all sorts, and are easily
bribed. Unbeknownst to most, the swipes are experts
at navigating the chaos of unsettled lands. Once a
place is described to them, they can guide anybody
there in a short amount of time.

Astral snap: Once per round, a swipe can touch a
creature                              and send its spirit into the astral plane, but
only for a split second. The victim’s spirit snaps back
into the body with a jarring, disorienting effect
(d6+d4 stun effect vs. Fortitude → Willpower →
Resistance).

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Swipes are strange
creatures,                              as their bodies exist almost in two places
at once: the astral and the settled realms. They have
some natural resistance to normal forms of damage
and get a d4 damage reduction against every physical
attack. They are immune to teleportation and
summoning spells if they are unwilling to be affected
by them (though they can choose to be summoned,
hitching a ride to adventure, no conjurer has figured
out how to control or command one). If found
traveling alone, a swipe may only have a trinket or

365


BESTIARY


two (1–6 coins and 1% chance of 1 minor magic
item),                                but if adventurers invade a swipe community
in the astral plane, they will have a small trove: 100–
600 coins and 20% chance of d2 magic items.

Troll

Type: Standard

Threat Dice: Natural 2d12 ~ Melee 2d8 ~ Ranged 2d8

~ Arcane 2d8

Hit Points: 60 (30/30) [normal, magical, huge; ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: +2 / d4

Saving Throw: 2d4

Battle Phase d10

Legends and Lore: A hulking creature with black
pitiless                              eyes over a huge angular nose, and small
ears, a troll is a creature with ancestors born from
the primordial earth, and is attuned to natural stone.

Abilities and Powers: They can create effects
mirroring                          those of earth elementalists. Powers (as
the spells) are Minor Earthquake, Fissure, Earth
Merge, Earth Strike.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Trolls can use large
weapons, but usually prefer to rend and tear with
bestial strength. An individual troll may have
incidental treasure, such as a magical arrow used as a
toothpick, but a troll lair will usually contain a
treasure trove: 200–2000 coins and 30% chance of
d3 magic items.

Vampire

Type: Standard (undead)

Threat Dice: Arcane 2d12 ~ Melee d10+d6 ~ Ranged
d4                              ~ Natural d16+2

Extra Attacks: Vampiric bite or hypnotic gaze

Hit Points: 60 (30/30) [normal, supernatural,
medium;                    ×2.5]

Damage Reduction: By armor worn and shield
wielded if any

Saving Throw: 2d12

Battle Phase d12

Legends and Lore: Several types of this horrid
undead                             parasite exist, from zombie-like corpse-
things shuffling in search of blood to highly magical
specimens able to maintain a semblance of humanity

— sometimes with an enticing charisma. Thus one
might encounter a seductress, fanged and sultry,
reminiscent of Lilith’s brood, with attendant
vampiric horrors that are obviously dead: things
risen but recently from the grave. Some vampires
choose to revere Satan, some Baphomet, and not a
few regard Lilith as their creatrix. Many display a
self-assured disdain for all, as they term them, so-
called and self-proclaimed deities.

Abilities and Powers: In Ainerêve, where every
folktale                             becomes a reality, a realm’s cultural base
will dictate the vampire’s powers and vulnerabilities.
Typical are powers of charm that can fascinate and
disarm a foe, the ability to fly, either in human or bat
form, shape-changing to bat or wolf. Some can take
on the form of a mist and flow ’neath doors or
through cracks; all can drink blood, regenerating and
thriving upon it. Some can only enter an abode if
invited, are repelled by garlic or holy symbols, burn
in the sun, expire beneath the water, and die only if
staked or perhaps beheaded.

Vampiric bite: The vampire rolls a d16 versus the
target's                            Strength specialty in Prowess to grapple,
and upon success, bites the victim, which has a
stunning effect (no Challenge Die for the vampire).
Once grappled, stunned or not, the victim takes d6
blood loss per round directly to passive defense hit
points. Although stunning is a physical affliction, the
save to break the effect (versus the vampire's
original grapple roll) is Willpower (Fortitude),
allowed initially, and once per round. Once stunning
is eliminated, an opposed roll of Fortitude with
Strength may let the victim break free.

Hypnotic gaze: If the vampire concentrates and
gazes                              into its victim’s eyes, it can create a mind
control effect (zero Challenge Die; the vampire rolls
2d12 versus the target’s Willpower).

366


Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Grave goods for
some,                               for others all the finery of an aristocrat —
much depends upon the vampire’s goals, its mode of
operating, and its need, or not, to acquire material
power (treasure is typically a trove: 200–2000 coins
and 30% chance of d3 magic items).

Werewolf

Type: Exceptional

Threat Dice: Natural 3d8+8 (bite, claw, punch) ~
Melee d10+8 ~Ranged d6

Hit Points: 80 (40/40) [normal, medium, magical;

×2]

Damage Reduction: Immune to normal weapons
except                            magic and silver

Saving Throw: 2d4

Battle Phase d8 human or d12 wolf

Legends and Lore: As with the vampire, to which it
bears a degree of kinship, the werewolf is shaped by
Ainerêve’s dream-reality. In some realms, it is
undead; in others, an accursed human who has
donned, willingly or not, a cruelly enchanted belt
that forces wolf-form upon its wearers. Some
werewolves appear as ravenous man-wolves, a
bipedal mixture of man and wolf; in others, the
were-creature comes as an exemplary wolf —
bigger, fiercer, swifter than its kin, but a wolf
nonetheless. In most cases, it is a living thing, a
human that becomes a blood-hungry hunter of the
night at the time of the full moon.

Abilities and Powers: It has all the wolf’s abilities,
and                                its bite may spread lycanthropy. Fearsomely
strong and agile, with a matchless ferocity, it may be
vulnerable to silver and otherwise unharmed by
weaponry. It will only use melee weapons in
humanoid form.

Weapons, Armor, and Treasure: Usually none, save
that                             which it possesses naturally in human forms. In
some realms, skinning the werewolf and donning its
hide will allow the wearer himself to assume wolfish
guise. Often, the werewolf drops all its gear when

367

assuming wolf form — although some, in a half-
man,                         half-wolf state, maintain possession of
weapons, armor, and other accouterments (a small
trove: 100–600 coins and 20% chance of D2 magic
items).

And thus we come to the end of this bestiary, and may it
bring knowledge and help to all its readers. Remember,
the written word is only as valuable as its source, and I,
Signoret, can vouch only that I have tried to garner the
truth of all herein reported. One more caveat, Ainerêve is
a world of dreams and dreams shift and change — be
careful of everything, depend upon nothing, and at all
times, except that which you least expect.


Gods of
Ainerêve

In Ainerêve, only a few gods hold sway, with myths
distinct from Earth’s. In Maedoen, the Celtic gods

BESTIARY

great king of Enwys, chosen by the moon goddess
Arianrhod                          herself. It is said she was then charged
with imparting the sacred druidical secrets to the
first Sisters. Yet, the current tradition, requiring a
male shee to impregnate the king's wife, casts doubt
on this legend, despite its veracity. Brigit's devotees
believe in fostering harmony between the shee and


Dagda, Arawn, Brigit, Cernunnos, The Morrigan, and

Math Mathonwy are most revered. Dalmavand
honors                             Norse and Anglo-Saxon gods like Baldur,
Odin, Thor, Loki, and Eostre, while Psarmorum
worships Sol Invictus, with Luna and Astra as lesser
aspects.

Arawn: God of Death

Arawn, the god of death and justice, is the arbiter of
all                            mortals’ fates in the afterlife. He rules over the
enigmatic Otherworld, Annwn, a realm perceived as
either a blessed paradise or a hellish landscape, with
the experience dictated by individual fate. Alongside
the chthonic goddess Cerridwn, they serve as the
lord and mistress of the cycles of life and rebirth.

Though bound to Annwn, Arawn is known to
occasionally                           venture into the mortal realm,
particularly the Forest of Meath, where he hunts
monsters with his supernatural white-eared, red-
eyed dogs, earning him the title of Lord of the Hunt.
Cerridwn, however, remains ever vigilant as the
gatekeeper of Annwn, protecting her magical
cauldron, a vessel of immense power that, if
misused, could disrupt the delicate balance of life
and death by granting immunity even to the finality
of death itself.

Brigit: Goddess of Life

Brigit, the goddess of life, fertility, and spring, is the
revered daughter of the Dagda and the goddess
Morrigan, a beacon of wisdom and peace among the
Sisters Gan Creadigeath. Legend whispers that Brigit
was once the wife of Hlacheu ap Dagda, the first

other creatures of the Otherworld and the people of
Maedoen. Her presence is celebrated during the
joyous holiday of Imbolc, marking the hopeful
midpoint of winter and the promise of spring's
return.

Cernunnos: God of Nature

In the heart of ancient Maedoen, where the wild
thrived                              under the watchful gaze of Cernunnos, the
Horned God, a tale of love, betrayal, and the birth of
a new order unfolded. Cernunnos, protector of the
first Maedoen druidical order, ruled over unspoiled
nature, embodying the untamed essence of the land.
Yet, even the mighty Cernunnos was not immune to
the allure of love. He fell for the enchanting fay moon
goddess Arianrhod, daughter of Cerridwn.

Learning of Arianrhod's yearning to reunite with
her                              mother in the underworld of Annwn, Cernunnos,
moved by compassion, stabilized the Equinox gates
of Ainerêve. This allowed Arianrhod access to an
equinox gate at his fortress at Carrefol Cyfain, near
the borders of Meath forest, a gate that led directly to
Annwn.

Arianrhod rejoiced at their reunion, but her
mother,                      Cerridwn, rebuked her, fearing for her
daughter's fate. The Dagda and Arawn, powerful
deities of Maedoen, disapproved of Arianrhod's
connection to Oberon, the king of the fairies.

Cerridwn herself had once roamed the realms freely
and                             fallen in love with an elf named Beli Mawr, a
prince of Oberon’s realm. As punishment for her
tryst with a creature outside the Tuatha Dé Danann,
she was condemned to guard the gates of Annwn
forever, separated from her daughter. Now, allowing

368


no interlopers from the Seelie Court, the Dagda
issued                                a dire warning through Chydonax, the first
hierophant of his order. Cernunnos was commanded
to close access to Annwn.

Cernunnos prepared to obey his overlord's
demands,                               but Arianrhod, who also loved Oberon and
had borne him Mab, the demigoddess Queen of the
Fairies, sought to prevent the gate's closure. Mab,
learning of her mother’s plight, moved to seduce
Chydonax, distracting him from his duty to oversee
Cernunnos’s compliance. The distraction delayed
Cernunnos, and Mab begged her father, Oberon, to
intercede and prevent the Seelie Courts from being
shut out of realms to which she and her mother felt
entitled. But he refused to help, and Mab, enraged,
joined the Unseelie Court to aid her mother.

Together, they intended to seal the fate of Cernunnos
and                              his druidic order before the Dagda could again
limit the range of the shee domains.

In a heart-wrenching betrayal, Arianrhod used
sorcery                                to bind Cernunnos while Mab enacted her
deadly seduction, leading to the murder of the
archdruid Chydonax. Mother and daughter then used
the gates to banish Cernunnos. This act, taking place
at the first Nexus Portal at Carrefol Cyfain, marked
the beginning of the matriarchal order of the Gan
Creadigeath, which Arianrhod intended to lead with
her daughter.

But the Dagda, angered by Arianrhod’s actions and
arrogance, appointed the Goddess Brigit to oversee
the new order instead, ensuring its members would
not fall under the sway of the shee. In revenge, led by
Mab, the Unseelie Courts dismantled Cernunnos’s
druidic order, scattering them to their doom in the
distant reaches of chaos. The Dagda’s druids
threatened to destroy the Gan Creadigeath in
response, but Brigit interceded. She revealed that
Mab was bearing Chydonax’s son and declared that
this child would be taken from her and raised by
Oberon’s Court in tribute to Cernunnos’s lineage,
even after his defeat and exile. Mab, now aligned

with the Unseelie Courts, plotted revenge against her
father, Oberon, for his disregard.

Thus, the Gan Creadigeath was born from a
tapestry                               of love, betrayal, and power struggles,
forever entwined with the fate of Cernunnos, the
exiled Horned God. The matriarchal order, under
Brigit's guidance, would strive to maintain balance
in a world forever altered by the clash between
deities and the ambitions of the shee.

Math Mathonwy: God of
Wizardry

Math Mathonwy, a unique deity in the pantheon of
Maedoen, is revered not for divine might, but for his
embodiment of the boundless potential within
mortals. Legends suggest that Mathonwy, once a
mortal wizard, transcended his limitations through a
relentless pursuit of knowledge, achieving a form of
immortality rooted in his mastery of the arcane. His
teachings emphasize self-reliance, intellectual
curiosity, and the belief that true power is earned
through understanding and dedication rather than
divine favor. Central to his philosophy is the idea
that magic is a craft to be honed through discipline
and practice, a belief deeply ingrained in the
Octocirculi Academy, the most prestigious
institution for magical study in Maedoen.

The Academy, structured around the eight schools
of                              magic, challenges students to unlock their
potential through rigorous study, with no shortcuts
allowed. Mathonwy's influence extends beyond the
Academy, inspiring a culture that values education,
intellectual achievement, and the pursuit of
greatness through one’s own efforts. In this way,
Mathonwy serves as a beacon for those who seek to
understand the mysteries of the universe and master
the arcane through their own merit, embodying the
spirit of Maedoen’s magic—vast, mysterious, and
waiting to be uncovered.

369


Deities of Dalmavand

Odin, the Allfather, reigns supreme over the Norse

BESTIARY

However, this period marked the inception of a
complex power play, as a mighty demon named
Baphomet saw an opportunity to wield power by


gods of Dalmavand. He sacrificed his eye for wisdom,

and he commands war, poetry, and magic. His quest
for                         knowledge is relentless, and he rules Valhalla,
where the bravest warriors await Ragnarok.

Thor, the Thunderer, defends Dalmavand with his
mighty hammer Mjölnir. He embodies courage,
strength, and loyalty, and his voice thunders over the
land. He is the shield against the storm, the bulwark
against the night. He respects Odin, his father, and
shares his burden of protecting Dalmavand.

Loki, the Trickster, is a paradoxical god of mischief
and                            change. He shape-shifts and schemes, bringing
trouble and innovation. He helped create Mjölnir and
Asgard's walls, but he also fathered monsters and
threats to Dalmavand. He challenges the status quo
and tests the mettle of gods and mortals.

Freya, the Lady, is the goddess of love and magic in
Dalmavand. She is a master of divination and
enchantment, and she bestows her gifts on those
who seek her favor. She is also a goddess of fertility
and prosperity, and she blesses the land with
abundance. She is a lover of beauty and art, and she
inspires those who create them.

Sol Invictus (Baphomet)

In the middle ages, a large band of Templar Knights,
alongside                            thousands of pilgrims, were journeying
from France to Jerusalem. A reveorage storm, a
phenomenon known for its ability to transport
individuals across realms, swept them into the land
of Ainerêve. The knights, adapting to their new
environment, claimed the land for civilization,
establishing a provisional bishop and a Master
Templar, making the region livable. This land,
marked by a forgotten Latin name as a sign of piety,
was eventually shortened to Psarmorum.

For centuries, these Templar Knights defended
themselves against the nightmares of Ainerêve.

impersonating the God revered by the Templars.

Baphomet, distinguished from other demons by his
cunning, patience, and adherence to bargains,
conspired to transport the knights and pilgrims to
Ainerêve. This was achieved with the assistance of
two other entities, thus intertwining the dream
storm rift with demonic machinations. In exchange
for his intervention, Baphomet gained worship as
Sol, with Luna and Astra as aspects of his unholy
trinity. Notably, Luna is identified as his consort,
Lilith, while Astra's true identity remains a mystery.

To secure the allegiance of both good and evil,
Baphomet                           crafted an illusion of righteousness. He
elevated the Templar’s master to grandmaster
status, and under the guise of Sol Invictus, he
presented himself as a warlike and implacable deity,
with Luna and Astra symbolizing mercy and
salvation, respectively. His vassal demons, disguised
as angels, supported the pilgrims, ingratiating
themselves as celestial beings.

Over time, Baphomet subtly altered religious
scriptures                               to emphasize obedience, piety,
conformity, and intolerance towards mystical
beings, outsiders, or the spiritually lax. Yet, within
these teachings, he maintained redemptive elements
and left clues for the discerning.

Simultaneously, the original Templar leaders, who
secretly worshipped Baphomet, initiated worthy
knights into occult rites, promising them wealth and
power. Baphomet's long-term strategy involved a
gradual corruption, knowing that a rapid decline into
depravity would be unsustainable.

Psarmorum flourished as a nation under
Baphomet's                           influence, becoming a formidable force
of warriors and devout followers of the One God. The
blood of demons, periodically infused, runs through
the veins of Psarmorum's nobility, strengthening
their allegiance to Baphomet.

370


However, Baphomet's ascendancy enraged Satan
and                                his demons, who opposed him as vehemently as
they opposed the forces of good. To maintain
control, Baphomet ensured that Psarmorum’s rulers
actively hunted and destroyed any demons not under
his dominion, as well as individuals straying from
his prescribed path. This campaign of fear and
suspicion cemented his control over the populace.

In this intricate web of deception and power,
Baphomet                              has successfully established a temporal
and spiritual stronghold in Psarmorum. His ultimate
goals, whether world domination or ascension to
true godhood, remain known only to him and
perhaps the wisest of sages.

Vassal Demons and Peris: Baphomet’s celestial host
included not only disguised demons but also peris,
mythical beings from Persian lore. This assembly of
beings under his command further reinforced the
illusion of a celestial pantheon supporting the
Templars.

Manipulation of Scriptures and Ideology: The
gradual                          alteration of religious texts by Baphomet
was an effective strategy. By slowly distorting the
scriptures, he fostered a culture of unquestioning
obedience and intolerance, yet cleverly left hints of
the original teachings. This manipulation ensured
that his followers adhered strictly to his doctrines,
while still believing in their divine origin.

Demonic Bloodline in Nobility: The infusion of
demon                             blood in the nobility of Psarmorum is a
significant aspect. This practice not only solidified
their loyalty to Baphomet but also granted them
enhanced abilities, making them formidable
opponents in both political and military arenas.

Struggle Against Satan and External Demons:
Baphomet’s                            success attracted the ire of Satan and
other demons. This external threat played into
Baphomet's hands, as it allowed him to position
himself and Psarmorum as defenders of the faith
against other demonic entities. The continuous
struggle against these external threats served to

371

unify Psarmorum under Baphomet’s rule and justify
his                            harsh doctrines.

The Dilemma of Psarmorum’s Rulers: The rulers of
Psarmorum, while ostensibly fighting against
demonic forces, were unwittingly serving
Baphomet’s agenda. This irony underscores the
depth of Baphomet’s deception, as the rulers
believed they were upholding righteousness while
actually perpetuating the influence of a demon.

The Role of the Templars: The Templar Knights,
originally                        guardians of the pilgrims and the faith,
became key agents in Baphomet’s plan. Their
transformation from protectors to unwitting pawns
in a demonic scheme highlights the insidious nature
of Baphomet’s influence.

The Psychological Impact on the Populace: The
constant                             state of vigilance and fear instilled in the
people of Psarmorum served to maintain control and
discourage dissent. Baphomet’s regime, therefore,
was not just a physical dominion but also a
psychological one, where the fear of external and
internal threats kept the populace in check.

Baphomet’s Long-term Vision: While Baphomet’s
immediate                           goals are clear - control over Psarmorum
and its people - his long-term objectives remain
shrouded in mystery. Whether he seeks to challenge
the celestial hierarchy, attain true godhood, or
simply revel in the power he has accumulated is a
subject of much speculation among scholars and
sages.

Baphomet's rule in Psarmorum is characterized by
a                               web of deceit, manipulation, and strategic
alliances. His ability to maintain a facade of divine
righteousness while orchestrating a realm under
demonic influence showcases his cunning and
foresight. The implications of his reign extend
beyond mere political control, delving into the
realms of spiritual corruption, psychological
warfare, and the manipulation of faith.


Nigma

BESTIARY

transformations often erupt from the most
unexpected                       sources, forever altering the fabric of


Nigma's presence permeates the Eldritch Realms, an

elusive force as enigmatic as the shifting tides of
fate.                             Unlike deities bound to specific domains or
cultures, Nigma embodies the universal yearning to
control and shape destiny—a force intertwined with
their existence and the very creation of the Eldritch
Realms, born from the collective dreams of
humanity.

Often depicted by a complex variation of the
eternity                    symbol—interwoven lines converging at a
central point—Nigma symbolizes the cyclical nature
of choices and their reverberating consequences.

This emblem reinforces the belief that destiny is not
a                       predetermined path but a flowing river shaped by
countless decisions.

Nigma's doctrine, inherently adaptable, resonates
across                              the diverse cultures of the Eldritch Realms.
Scholars, innovators, and those who dwell in the
shadows all find something within Nigma's
teachings that speaks to their desire to bend fate to
their will. Yet, this adaptability breeds a spectrum of
interpretations, sometimes sparking conflict among
Nigma's followers. Some perceive Nigma as a subtle
guide, others as a force of unbridled chaos, each
striving to manifest their own unique vision of
destiny.

In the ever-evolving Eldritch Realms, Nigma's
presence                             stirs the currents of change, disrupting
established orders and challenging the rigid
hierarchies of other deities. Followers of Nigma,
whether organized into clandestine cults or walking
solitary paths, often grapple with internal strife due
to their divergent views on manifesting destiny. Yet,
they share an unyielding belief in the power of
individual agency, united by the conviction that they
can shape their own fates, however perilous the
journey.

Nigma's presence vibrates through the Eldritch
Realms,                               a persistent echo challenging the notion of a
fixed destiny. They whisper that the most profound

existence. Those who dare to embrace Nigma's
teachings                              may ascend to unimaginable power, but
they must also be prepared to face the consequences
of their choices, for in the Eldritch Realms, destiny is
a double-edged sword.

Appendix A. Names and
Notes

This appendix contains names and notes on people
and                           places in Ainerêve. They should help with
adding background color, expanding the setting,
naming characters and NPCs, and so on.

Pronunciation

Most local names in this book are spelled fairly
phonetically: Fergus, Shee, Roberre, rather than the
orthographic but misleading Fearghas, Sidhe,
Robert.                                 Just say the words as you see them, perhaps
with a trace of a suitable accent (Welsh, Irish,
French, or Scandinavian). Some tips are provided for
important names.

Ainerêve. Varies with regional accents: Aey-nar-av
in                        Dalmavand; an-Ah-reev in Maedoen; Ann-ah-
reev in Meath; Eh-nuh-rave in Psarmorum.

Cartrefol Cyfain. kar-Treff-oll Kiff-ain.
Cernunnos. Ker-Nun-nuhs.

Chartres. Shah-trez.
Cythraul.   Kai-thrawl.
d’Echallens. Deh-Shall-onz.
Dagda. Dahg-duh.

Dalmavand. Dal-ma-vand.
Dis.           Diss.

Grimsete. Grim-seat.

Gan Creadigeath. Gann Krraid-gaith.

372


Mali. Mal-ih.

Maedoen. may-Doe-en.

Math ap Mathonwy. Mah-ap Mah-thone-wee.
Meath.                     Meeth.

Psarmorum. sar-Mor-um.

Shee. She; rhymes with tree.

Norse (Dalmavand) is lilting. Stress is on the first
syllable. Accented vowels are longer. The /j/ is
pronounced /y/. The /i/, /o/, and /u/ rhyme with
‘free’, ‘rope’, and ‘moon’; /æ/ rhymes with ‘eye’,

/ai/ rhymes with ‘way’. The /ö/ and /ø/ sound like /
oeh/, and /aa/ and /ey/ sound like /eoh/. Double
consonants are pronounced separately. The final ‘r’
of a name is not pronounced.

Welsh (Maedoen) is smooth and musical. Words are
stressed on the next to last syllable. A /y/ as the last
syllable is a long /ee/ sound, and the /i/ is always
short. The /ch/ is as in ‘loch’. We have written the
breathy Welsh /ll/ as it sounds, /hl/.

Gaelic (Meath) is fairly smooth but throaty. Stress is
on                                the first syllable. Accented vowels are longer. The

/c/ and /g/ are hard, and the /r/ is rolled. The /ch/ is
as                                in ‘loch’; /h/ softens consonants; /ae/ is
pronounced /ai/ and /oe/ is pronounced /oi/.

French (Psarmorum) is nasal. The /é/ and /ei/ rhyme
with                               ‘hey’; other e’s are as in ‘men’; a final ‘e’ is
silent unless accented. Final consonants are often
silent. The /i/ is a long /ee/ sound. The /eau/ rhymes
with ‘go’. We have written French /oi/, /gn/, /j/ as
they sound, /wa/, /ny/, /zh/ (e.g. Agnes, Joie, Guy =
Ahnyes, Zhwa, Ghee).

Note: The sages of Psarmorum, renowned for their
study                              of ancient texts, maintain that the true
pronunciation of "Ainerêve" is "Eh-nuh-rave," as
revealed in a fragment of an ancient tome predating
the earliest records of the French Templars. This
pronunciation, holding a deeper significance to the
world's essence, is favored by those seeking to

unravel Ainerêve's secrets and honor the wisdom of
the Psarmorum sages.

Towns and villages

Ainerêve is a ‘sandbox’ setting, with some important
things                         specified, such as cities and adventure
locations, and the rest left for you to arrange to suit
your campaign. For instance, lesser and less
adventurous settlements can be added to the map as
required. Guidelines are given below.

Settlement sizes for Psarmorum (halve for
Dalmavand, Maedoen, or Meath):

Hamlet 50–300(d6 x 50)
Village400–900(d6 x 100 + 300)

Town1000–6000(d6 x 1000)

Dalmavand and Maedoen are moderately populated,
and                              their settlements are small. Roll d6 for size: 1–3
hamlet, 4–5 village, 6 town. Psarmorum is well
populated. Roll d6 for size: 1 hamlet, 2–4 village, 5–
6 town. For Meath, roll d8 for size: 1–4 hamlet, 5–7
village, 8 town. Human settlements are few, near the
edge of the forest, and all hamlets. If the settlement
is elsewhere or larger, it is a Fay community or
encampment, and probably hidden by illusion at
least.

General notes. Assume an average of five persons per
dwelling place; one tradesman (blacksmith, brewer,
carpenter, hedge wizard, etc.) per 150 population;
and one inn or tavern, plus one shrine or temple, per
200 population. Hamlets tend to centre on one
activity (farming, fishing, forestry, hunting and
trapping, mining); villages will deal with several;
and towns are centers for more extensive trade and
will be on main roads and beside rivers. Villages are
with 10 miles of a castle or keep in Dalmavand and
Maedoen, 5 miles in Psarmorum. Each town in either
country is walled and has an associated castle. Each
castle has a lord and fighting men, a thaumaturge or
two, and various officials, but draws on the local
populace for its servants.

Attitudes. Although this book focuses on the many
monsters and problems that adventuring heroes will
fight and face, most people in the realm live fairly
ordinary lives concerned with everyday matters.

They provide a base of normality, and are not usually
hostile.                          Their general dispositions, by settlement,
are as follows:

Dalmavand d6: 1–3 friendly, 4–5, neutral, 6
unfriendly.

Maedoen d6: 1–2 friendly, 3–5, neutral, 6
unfriendly.

375


BESTIARY


Psarmorum d6: 1–2 friendly, 3–4, neutral, 5–6
unfriendly.

Meath d6: 1 friendly, 2–3, neutral, 4–6 unfriendly.
Obviously,                           you can choose what you like, individuals
will vary, and adventurer actions can modify the base

reaction. Friendly can mean smiles, greetings, and

visitors made welcome, or simple politeness in
towns.                            Neutral means wariness (perhaps the party
are thought to be tax collectors?), indifference, or a
business-as-usual approach. Unfriendly can mean
surliness or fear of strangers (maybe the village has
something to hide, or there are guards because of
recent raids), or (as is usual with Fay) a wish to be
left undisturbed.

Settlement Names

Here are lists of native names for towns and villages
of                            Ainerêve. Choose, or roll dice to allocate randomly.
Mix as you like with ordinary names like Wayford,
Rivertown, and Hillfort.

Dalmavand. Names are mostly Norse; 1 in 6 is Welsh
(see                         Maedoen). Roll d30 (or d10, and on a d6 roll of
1–2/ 3–4/ 5–6 add 0/ 10/ 20 to the result).
